Senator Schacht will be attending the 11th general meeting of the Pacific Economic Cooperation Committee in Beijing from 27 to 29 September. The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) will be absent today as he will be delivering the keynote address to the annual ANZAAS conference—the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science—in Newcastle.

para.tab: I will be overseas tomorrow on official government business and will be absent from question time on 26, 27 and 28 September. I will be attending the 50th session of the United Nations General Assembly from 26 September to 4 October, and I will be then travelling to Madrid for the regular ministerial consultations between Australia and the European Union presidency.

In both Senator Cook's and Senator Schacht's absence today, I will represent the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance; Senator McMullan will take questions on industry, science and technology; and Senator Robert Ray will represent the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. For the remainder of this week, Senator Ray will represent the Prime Minister and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training; Senator McMullan will take questions on foreign affairs; and Senator Cook will take questions on small business, customs and construction.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —by leave—I thank the Senate for granting leave. It did not seem to come particularly graciously minister, but I appreciate it all the same. We are traditionally quite generous in relation to the need for ministers to travel overseas on ministerial business, but this has reached ridiculous extremes today. Three ministers are absent this week. Let me start with Senator Cook. Senator Cook was listed to open that conference last night in Newcastle. It was too difficult apparently for him to do that on a Sunday night. It was good enough for opposition representatives to be there on a Sunday night.
—Why was that?

—Apparently, for personal reasons, he wanted to change the opening until today. I do not believe the rumour that it was because of the replay of the football; that could not be right. Anyway, he asked that the opening be changed until 10.30 this morning. If he opened that conference at 10.30 this morning, why is it that he cannot be here answering questions this afternoon?

para.tab: There is absolutely no reason at all for that, except, of course, if he is wanting to avoid certain questions—and anyone who has read this morning's press would know the sorts of things he is wanting to avoid. His much lauded innovation statement apparently is a wreck before it is off the starting blocks. We heard that he took it to the parliamentary caucus committee last week. What did they say about it? They said, `Cook's draft is a bronze medal strategy. It's absolutely lacking in substance.' Apparently the Glimmer twins decided to put out a briefing or two against Senator Cook.

The important thing is that that innovation statement—so important to Australian science—has been put off for month after month after month. Now we hear that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has had to take it over from Minister Cook. The question is: why shouldn't we be able to ask Senator Cook questions on that important national matter this afternoon? Did Senator Evans give any explanation as to why Senator Cook could not be here this afternoon? There was no explanation at all.

We now get to Senator Schacht, who has been a most unsuccessful minister for small business. All he has given to small business is increased taxation. He was asked over the weekend about his taxation policies for small business. He was asked what was the government's response to an important parliamentary committee report which gave him advice on taxation and small business, and he said, `We're not going to speculate wildly about such matters.'

Surely, in the interests of Australian small business, which has had to suffer so much under your policies, we should have every right to have Minister Schacht here today and to be able to ask him questions. If he has to go to Beijing to give a speech, why can't he go to Beijing, give the speech and come back and meet his responsibility to the parliament? It is this government that sets the timetable for the sittings of the parliament—not us—and it should set a timetable that is convenient to ministerial responsibility to the parliament.

Finally, we have the foreign minister away again. We are, as I said, particularly generous to the foreign minister. Last week he wanted to go away on an economics conference and we said okay because we thought that might be helpful to him. But here he is again going away for the whole of the balance of this week, and it is totally unsatisfactory. We can do no more when these abuses occur but to protest, and I record the protest on behalf of this side of the chamber because our tolerance has been exhausted.

He will be delivering a keynote speech on Australia's involvement in APEC at one of the plenary sessions, and will be accompanied by an Australian delegation of 13 business representatives. His absence from question time has been governed by airline schedules, which were discussed with him to see if it were possible that he could be here today—if not tomorrow—in that respect.

We do our best on all these occasions to try to accommodate the legitimate needs and concerns of the parliament. I am afraid, regrettably, in this instance—these two very important occasions—it was not possible for two very important, highly competent and well qualified ministers to be here.

—My question is directed to Senator Gareth Evans, Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the Prime Minister's response to his previously respected economic adviser Dr Vince FitzGerald when Dr FitzGerald reminded him of the linkage between foreign debt and interest rates. The Prime Minister responded, `Well, Vince is a sour ex-bureaucrat. I mean, Vince gets the old lemon in the mouth every morning and gives a good hard suck on it. I mean, you'll never get any cheerful comments out of Vince about the economy, because Vince thought he should have been secretary of the Treasury and a few other things, and never made it.' Why must the Prime Minister attack in such personal and vicious terms anyone who offers him any constructive criticism or gives any advice with which the Prime Minister does not agree? Why shouldn't Australians expect the Prime Minister to debate issues in a civil way, rather than intimidate the messenger with such personal abuse?

—I agree that whether Vince FitzGerald drinks lemon juice or orange juice in the morning for breakfast is not strictly relevant to the policy matters in issue here. What is relevant is whether or not he gets it right in what he says publicly about the relationship between a high level of foreign debt and relevant domestic interest rates, and whether or not, under the circumstances of his getting it wrong—as he has—the Prime Minister is entitled to correct him, which he has.

para.tab: The truth of the matter is, so far as the substantive matters in issue here are concerned, that there is no direct relationship between the high level of foreign debt which Australia has at the moment and relevant domestic interest rates. I would like to hear anyone in the opposition saying to the contrary.

talk.start.para: —That is not the question.

—Well the question in issue and the reason which justifies the response of the Prime Minister in these matters is when people get it basically wrong in terms of the implications they are seeking to convey to the public and when the opposition party, as in this instance, picks it up and gets it even more fundamentally wrong in order to try to make some political point.

para.tab: The truth of the matter is that short-term interest rates are the product of monetary authorities' response—in the Australian case, the Reserve Bank's response—to the inflation rate environment and outlook. Because Australia's inflation outlook is very much under control and looks like remaining so for the indefinitely foreseeable future, so too will interest rates remain in that condition and not be governed by whatever happens so far as foreign debt is concerned.

The latest
Economist
released just a couple of days ago makes clear the absence of any such relationship between short-term real interest rates and whatever might be the case so far as foreign debt is concerned. It is the short-term real interest rates which are the determinants of variable mortgage interest rates which Australian consumers and people are interested in; it is short-term interest rates which, in Australia, are standing up remarkably well in any international comparison.

If you look at the table from the
Economist
, which you usually love quoting, you will see it shows Australia right in the middle of the field at the moment so far as short-term interest rates are concerned with lower real, not just nominal, interest rates than countries like Sweden, Spain, Canada, Italy, France, Denmark, Britain and the United States, most of whom of course have much lower levels of foreign debt than Australia does at the moment. There is simply no correlation between the two.

When Vince FitzGerald went on to make a number of other points, as he had in his public contributions, about the impact of foreign debt levels on sovereign debt ratings and risk premiums, when he went on to make further points about the absolute level of government debt as compared with foreign debt and its relation to interest rate payments, in each case he was simplifying, for whatever purpose, for whatever reasons, what is a vastly complex set of equations and relationships. The simple attempt that is being made by the opposition, calling in aid people like Dr FitzGerald making their own contributions to the public domain, to draw some linkage between the two is simply ill-founded. That remains the government's very clear position.

Our record on interest rates speaks for itself. Compare this with the appalling record of interest rate management under the last government that Mr Howard had a capacity to influence when he was Treasurer. There was a regulated interest rate regime and a monetary policy committee of cabinet sitting every week and setting these things, not letting in market forces. Every relevant interest rate in the book, whether it was housing loans rates, cash rates, 90-day bank bill rates or anything else, was much higher than the rates which are prevailing today.

That is the record you have to explain. That is why we are so concerned to ensure there is no misrepresentation by anyone in the public domain of these fundamental important economic relationships. If you go on misquoting the extent of our foreign debt, the extent to which that is impacting adversely on the Australian community and misstating the impact of it, in particular on domestic interest rates, you have to expect the returns that you get.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para:
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That was very interesting but it had nothing to do with the question that was asked. The Prime Minister was not responding to us at all; he was responding to his formerly highly respected adviser when that adviser said something he did not agree with. My question is: why must the Prime Minister always respond with personal abuse? Why can't he listen, rather than let the venom drip from his lips as he attempts to verbally abuse these people? Whether you understand it or not, Australians don't actually like it. But the interesting thing in asking this supplementary question is that after the Prime Minister abused Dr Vince FitzGerald he then, in effect, acknowledged the facts to be true when he said, `Australia's current account always puts some question into the exchange markets.' Of course, he then tried to rationalise that he was speaking in the longer term, which you have done today. Why always respond with personal abuse? Why not enter into the debate in a normal civilised way?
(Time expired)

—The Prime Minister has a colourful turn of phrase, as we all know, and employs a lot of colourful language very often to make points which need to be made. The fact that those opposite are so limp, lacklustre and lifeless that they can never make an effective point at all in public communication is their problem, not ours.

para.tab: What we are doing, through the Prime Minister in this instance, is making very clear that, whatever might be the situation so far as Australia's perfectly manageable level of foreign debt is concerned—which is, nonetheless, high—that bears no relationship whatsoever to housing mortgage interest rates, which are the concern of ordinary, average Australians. That is the point the Prime Minister was making.

Housing mortgage rates, variable mortgage interest rates, which do worry Australians, are not in any way linked to the level of foreign debt. What they are linked to is the level of inflation and inflationary expectations and the way in which monetary authorities in Australia manage short-term interest rates in response to that. That is the relevant economic relationship, not what you are trying to talk about here.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan. There is considerable reporting in the media today of a survey of the Committee of Economic Development of Australia, CEDA. This is on the barriers impeding Australia's exports to APEC members. According to the survey, Australian exporters face an extraordinary variety of tariff and non-tariff barriers to trade which cost hundreds of millions of dollars in lost export opportunities and, therefore, Australian jobs. Assuming the survey is reasonably accurate, in what ways is the Australian government tackling the barriers, particularly in the context of APEC.
—I call Senator McMullan.

—Thank you very much, and congratulations, Madam Deputy President. The findings of the CEDA survey are actually no big surprise. They indicate what I think most people already knew. What they actually do—why they are important, and why I welcome the report—is put very clearly, very starkly, the critical importance of APEC and of the goals we have set for APEC.

para.tab: It says that APEC is not some theoretical notion or, as some people seem to imply, something that is off the main game. It is a very bread-and-butter issue for ordinary Australians trying to get a job in a factory or an office, or make some money on a farm or from a mine. It is absolutely fundamental to our chances of effectively selling into the Asia-Pacific region that we maximise our chances of success under APEC.

It says three important things about our efforts to ensure that we are locked into the growth area in our region. Firstly, it says that the government has got it right in its determination to make APEC work, in initiating it, in seeking to set the pace on it, and in continuing to seek with others to drive the program of reform.

As I have said, the results do not come as a surprise. While they outline the fact that we should have no illusion about the size of the task before us, barriers like this are not insurmountable. We do not have to throw our hands up and say, `Look how hard it is', and walk away and hide. We did that for too long.

We saw similar reports on the size of the trade problem in agricultural subsidies during the Uruguay Round, but instead of, as in previous years, simply making speeches about it, we set out with a conscious strategy targeted to do something about it, particularly through the Cairns Group, and we made significant progress. Not enough to solve all our problems—we need to do more and we will do more—but a lot. We can do something similar through APEC. We cannot solve all our problems through APEC overnight but there is no better way to attack these regional trade barriers than APEC.

The second thing about the report is that it is proof that whatever inroads we can make into eliminating these trade barriers through APEC, Australia will win. The question in the period between now and Osaka is not whether Australia will benefit from the plans developed and approved at Osaka to implement the Bogor commitment, but how much we will win—not whether, but how much. The stakes are very high. It is very important that we keep the pressure on to maximise the benefits that flow to the whole region, and particularly, from our point of view, to Australia.

Thirdly, it shows that the APEC endeavour can touch upon Australians in very many walks of life. It illustrates the breadth and the depth of the issues involved in APEC. The government strategy, particularly through APEC in response to these barriers that Senator Collins has referred to in the CEDA report, is not just APEC. There is a multilateral strategy through continuing efforts in the WTO. There is the regional strategy through APEC; the subregional strategy through AFTA CER, which I will get a chance to talk about, I hope, later in the week; and the bilateral strategy through pushing in individual countries for them to open up their market.

I welcome the release of the report. It should increase community awareness about the important role of APEC in removing these trade barriers and in generating opportunities and wealth for Australians.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Madam Deputy President. I also congratulate you. My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Now that the ABC's pay television venture is close to being in a terminal condition, does the government accept the views expressed by the heads of Foxtel, Optus Vision and Channel 7 that a pay television monopoly is inevitable? If not, why not? What action does the government propose to take to protect the $12.5 million worth of taxpayers' funds already invested in the venture and the jobs of 110 employees who took very significant career risks to sign on in good faith? Why has the government spent the last 18 months ignoring all the signs of trouble? Is it because the Prime Minister thinks the current level of taxpayer support to the ABC is too high, as he implied last Friday, and he has been hoping that the deal would fall over of its own accord? It is bad enough to hate Vince FitzGerald. Why does the Prime Minister have to hate the ABC as well?

—This is unspeakably misleading. Everybody here, and the odd person who happens to be suffering to listen to this, should remember this: the ABC is involved in pay TV because of Senator Alston. Let us start there. He has claimed it. He said, `The role of the ABC has been one in which we have consistently argued from the word go that the ABC ought to be mandated a place in the sun.' This was his great claim—his great success—`We have insisted upon this.' Senator Bob Collins would not come forward with it, but Senator Alston came to the rescue and said, `We must have the ABC in this.'

—Madam Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. This can have nothing to do with relevance. If you want to have a debate about why it was that there was a Senate committee with a majority of Labor members on it that recommended in favour of the ABC's involvement in pay television and why, when this matter went through both the Senate and the House of Representatives, you supported it—in other words, you voted for it—let us have that debate afterwards. It has nothing to do with this question. It is utterly irrelevant. I am simply asking you a series of questions arising out of your inaction over the last 18 months. Let's hear the answers to those.
—Yes, let's hear the answers to those. I call Senator McMullan.

—I have to say it was directly relevant and quite vitally important. I am not arguing the fact that the ABC should not be involved or will not effectively continue to be involved; I am simply saying you were setting out consciously to create the wrong impression by those things which you said. You were deliberately setting out to create the wrong impression that somehow or other this was an initiative the government had taken which may now not succeed; whereas, in fact, you had required it and you had been advocating it.

para.tab: The government has, of course, seen some of the recent press announcements concerning BSkyB and Optus Vision and Foxtel and all these things. Even I have seen that on my occasional visits to Australia, so I am aware of it. The future directions for AIM, of course, are directly and primarily a matter for the ABC and for its board to consider. I do note that the Managing Director of the ABC, Mr Brian Johns, has announced that the ABC and its partners are considering other opportunities and structural arrangements for its subscription services.

I note the fact that Mr Johns said, `The ABC's aspirations for subscription broadcasting are built on the sound belief that the national broadcaster is in an excellent position to contribute to the delivery of additional quality Australian content.' He said, `These continue to be our aspirations, as we believe they are very much in the public interest.' I think that is an appropriate, balanced remark from the person who is directly responsible—that is, the management of the ABC.

The matters that Senator Alston referred to are for the AIM and ABC boards to discuss and provide advice on. I understand the ABC board is meeting—I do not think it is a special meeting; I think it is a normal meeting—on Wednesday, 27 September.

talk.start.para: —If it makes a difference.
—I am sorry; I do not think that meeting is especially to deal with just this. As far as I know, this is being dealt with in a routine way, but I am not aware of all the details about that.

para.tab: Instead of seeking to reflect upon the merits or otherwise of a proposal which you initiated, we ought to just calmly wait for those considerations. I think there is serious possibility the ABC can still do well in pay television. Let us just wait and see the outcome of this, instead of slashing your wrists in the enthusiastic hope that you might be able to find some problem on which you can proceed to comment.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I note that the New South Wales Labor government recently introduced drugs in sport legislation into the New South Wales parliament and, in doing so, the government has acted far more decisively on the important issue of drugs in sport than the previous coalition state government did. Can the minister inform the Senate how this bill from the New South Wales government is a further indication of a truly national policy on drugs in sport? What role has the Commonwealth taken in developing a national stance on drugs in sport?

—It certainly is the case that state governments have been cooperating extremely well with the Commonwealth in the field of strong action on stamping out drugs in sport. I acknowledge the commitment that the New South Wales sports minister, Gabrielle Harrison, has made in introducing new sports drug legislation into the New South Wales parliament.

para.tab: I think this legislation will complement the efforts of the internationally respected Australian Sports Drug Agency. ASDA will, in partnership with the New South Wales government, conduct an additional 300 drug tests on elite New South Wales athletes. The New South Wales legislation will reinforce the deterrence value of doping controls in the years leading up to the 2000 Sydney Olympics. I am pleased to say that this action by New South Wales has been the product of extensive cooperation between the federal government, the states and sporting organisations around the country.

In December last year I met with leaders of Australian sport and emphasised that we would begin a new consultative process and develop a national network with the states and sporting organisations. I wanted to forge a number of strategic partnerships that would result in achieving national goals. In less than a year there are already many fine examples of this having occurred—none more so than the progress that we have made with our national drugs in sport strategy. If we are to beat the drug cheats, it is essential that we all work cooperatively and with the same strategies.

While the internationally respected Australian Sports Drug Agency is our flagship, it is important that we do not fragment our national approach. It is for this reason that I am particularly pleased that a working party of officials from all state and territory governments, together with the Australian Sports Commission and ASDA, have developed and endorsed a national drugs in sport policy. More importantly, this policy has been developed with the active participation of non-government organisations, including the Australian Olympic Committee and the Confederation of Australian Sport.

I also note that state and territory governments are already implementing a broad range of anti-drug programs with the support and guidance of the Australian Sports Drug Agency. I recently announced in the chamber that the government's commitment to pursuing a drug free Sydney 2000 Olympic Games was absolute. I think it will be through the sort of strategic partnership I have just outlined that this significant goal will be able to be achieved.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. It follows on the same theme as Senator Alston's question. Does the government believe that Australians have a right to an independent Australian news service on pay TV and that the recent deal between the Murdoch and Packer consortia seriously jeopardises such an outcome by virtually guaranteeing that the ABC will now not have a role in news broadcasting on pay TV? Is the minister aware that the ABC's pay channel is the one pay licensee required to provide high Australian content? Will the government now consider expanding and bringing forward the review of Australian content on pay TV and requiring that it also covers news? Will the minister consider taking action to preserve diversity in pay TV news before the ABC is forced to abandon its pay TV news channel?

—Let me talk generally about the question of diversification of ownership, which seems to come to the core of the question at the end, and then refer to some of the specifics. There has been a lot of speculation about concentration of media ownership and loss of media diversity, triggered by concerns about what is happening with regard to pay television. There is little doubt that television in Australia is going through a dramatic period of change. What I think we have to recognise in it all—it was acknowledged indirectly in Senator Alston's question—is that a new industry is being established in Australia, a new pay television industry, which is creating quite a lot of opportunities and employment, and some risk. It is very hard to recall when a new industry was created where there was no risk for any of those who became involved in attempts to establish it.
—And lots and lots of money down the track—lots and lots of money.
—And lots of potential benefits also. That is the reason people are taking the risks. Otherwise they wouldn't be.
—That's right. Because they know.

—Because they know there is a chance of return. That is the nature of investment decisions. People see the potential for a return in the future and they are prepared to take a risk on losses in the short term to seek to gain their share of that profit. Some of them will win and some of them will lose. Those who win will probably win quite handsomely, but some will lose. That is the nature of investment and I do not see why anybody is getting too agitated about that.

para.tab: It is important to note that the arrangements for pay TV have actually resulted in a number of new players entering the field, as well as a rapid roll-out of broadband cable that is unparalleled in the rest of the world.

talk.start.para: —Talk about news. We asked you about news.
—She also asked me about diversity of ownership and it is an important part of the question.
—News.

—No, it was not just about diversity of news, if I recall it correctly, but I want to talk about news. It talks about restoring diversity of ownership in pay television. So listen to the question as well as the answer, senator; I am trying to answer it. I think that is the core of the question. I am not trying to avoid the news part of it, which I want to comment on specifically.

para.tab: We need to give people a bit of opportunity, a bit of time, to develop in these things. The minister has made it clear that he hopes the new channel 9 BSkyB news service is the first of many new offerings and that it is a little extreme to suggest that the emergence of this one service sounds the death knell for the ownership and control rules in the Broadcasting Services Act. I think that is not an unreasonable way of saying it. My expectation and my understanding of the minister's expectation is that the ABC will remain an important source of content for the new industries that are developing, including pay television.

The success of pay TV in Australia will depend on the service that is provided to the consumer. Given the preferences clearly shown by the Australian viewers—as evidenced by weekly television ratings, Australian viewers prefer Australian programs—I expect them to continue to do so. Therefore, I have no doubt that Australian programs will be significant in the make-up of all pay TV services. I do not think we should at this stage be sounding the death knell for ABC news services. Let us just allow the board and the ABC to give this reasonable and serious consideration, to respond and respond in an environment where we are not all seeking to write off the ABC.

talk.start.para: —You have got to have something to watch on free-to-air TV as well.

—Of course, there is no doubt that there will continue to be independent television provided to all Australians free to air through the ABC; there is no doubt there will continue to be independent news services available to all Australians free to air on the ABC.
(Time expired)

—Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer, and I will take up one point in it. He said that the ABC will remain an important source of content. Can he tell me how the ABC will remain an important source of content on pay TV news? Will they retain editorial independence, as they remain that important source of content? Also, at what time will the government decide that it is about time to do something about it?

—The government will have to be careful that it does not intrude too far, or everyone will assume therefore that it is trying to interfere in the ABC. So let us be a bit careful here. The situation is that we expect, and the minister expects, the ABC to continue to be able to be an effective contributor to pay TV, particularly on the content side. I certainly think the government will not be doing anything that will interfere with the editorial independence of the ABC's news services—I can assure you of that—and I think you can be assured that the board will not allow anything to take place that will interfere with the editorial independence of the ABC. For those two reasons, I think we can be confident of that, as we can be confident that all Australians will have access to free-to-air television ABC news of the highest quality and independence.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, why is the cost of production in abattoirs in Australia 113c per kilo finished weight, when the same costs in the USA are 41c per kilo finished weight and in New Zealand 72c per kilo finished weight? Is this cost of production the reason for the closure—temporarily, I hope—of the Murgon meatworks, the Coominya meatworks, Toowoomba Beef City, the Dinmore meatworks and the Biloela meatworks, resulting in the loss of nearly 2,000 jobs in Queensland alone? If the cost of production through the abattoirs is not the reason for these closures, temporarily or permanently, what is the reason? What does the government intend doing about what has been described as the worst crisis in the Queensland meat industry in 10 years?

—I would suggest to Senator Ian Macdonald that if he wants to know the answers to those questions then, instead of simply reading the printed question that is circulated at the start of question time every day to all of the opposition members, he actually read the Booz-Allen report from which those figures are drawn. It would be instructive reading for you, Senator Macdonald.

para.tab: The bottom line of the Booz-Allen report that produced those figures is that between 60 and 70 per cent—in fact, closer to 70 per cent—of cost disadvantage that is suffered by Australian beef producers is entirely out of the hands of processors, Senator Macdonald. It is, in fact, due to factors such as distance to market, for example, the types of cattle that are produced for particular markets. The Booz-Allen report, in fact, came down with the conclusion that about 30 per cent, Senator Macdonald, of that cost disadvantage was attributable to factors that Australian industry can do something about. About 70 per cent of it is not; it is simply factors in the industry itself.

So I suggest that you actually take the trouble to read the Booz-Allen report, Senator Macdonald, before you ask questions about it. But it is within the industry's ability to tackle about 30 per cent of those problems, and that is precisely the reason the government recently established an entirely new arrangement for putting the meat industry in that competitive position with the establishment of the Meat Industry Council, a meeting of which I attended—

talk.start.para: —Oh, right—another committee.
—You would not know the first thing about it, Senator Alston. You know as much about it as you did about putting the ABC into pay television—yet another brilliant Alston initiative!
—By another Senate committee.

—That is right. Divide Australia up between Optus and Telecom and tell them which area of Australia they can operate in—another brilliant Alston initiative! Over the past few days a number of meat establishments have closed for periods of between one week and several weeks. The industry itself cites market conditions as the reason for the closures, and that indeed has been the tenor of the statements that the industry has made.

para.tab: The price received for product in Japan has fallen due largely to the significant increase in competition from US suppliers. In fact, that has been a steadily growing increase in competition—six per cent up last year with an additional three per cent this year.

talk.start.para: —That is the whole point, isn't it—why they are so competitive?

—We are still trading about $3 billion worth of Australian beef in the world trade, so we are not doing too badly. So stop running the place down like you continually do. Those increases of six per cent last year and three per cent this year are on top of a base of about 11 million tonnes of annual production in the United States, as compared with our base of 1.7 million tonnes. The recent appreciation in the value of the dollar—about five per cent—has also impacted on the competitiveness of the Australian product in the international marketplace. Indeed, they are the two major reasons for the temporary difficulty that is being suffered. In closing, we will not be adopting the suggestion that has been made by the National Party of Queensland to re-regulate the Australian dollar.

—I must say that, after four minutes, we still have not got any answers to the question I asked in relation to what you are in fact doing. Why is it that in New Zealand—which I understand is the same distance from the markets as we are—the cost is 72c per kilo and in Australia it is 113c per kilo? After 13 years in office, hasn't your government got any solutions? Is it that you are afraid to stand up to the unions? Is it that you have no inclination to do anything about the on-costs that affect business in regional Australia and that you are simply bereft of ideas after 13 years in government?

—I point out that the person who asked this question—this pretend minister—is going to be, apparently, a senior minister in this alternative government for Australia. The distance from markets refers to the distance between Australian cattle producers and processors, which does put a huge freight burden on the whole cost of the production. I have to tell you, in terms of elementary geography, that New Zealand is this big and Australia is this big. There is actually a difference between Australia and New Zealand. I go back to the suggestion I made: before you ask questions relating to the Booz-Allen report, Senator Macdonald, I suggest you read it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. The minister would be aware of a report today that the government's child-care subsidies boost the take-home pay of working women. Can the minister please outline the details of those subsidies?

answer.speaker: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

talk.start.para:
—I thank Senator Neal for her question. The report analysing the benefits of the federal government's child-care subsidies for families has been released today by NATSEM, the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling. That paper titled,
How effective are child-care subsidies in reducing a barrier to work?
, will be presented at the 24th conference of economists at the University of Adelaide today. The key finding of the study is that the government's child-care subsidies—the child-care assistance and the child-care cash rebate—boost the take-home pay of working mothers by up to 60 per cent. The two payments, the child-care assistance and the child-care cash rebate, boosts the take-home payment of mothers by up to 60 per cent.
—You've already said that.

—Yes, I have said it. Indeed, I have said it again just to make sure that that very good news and that very good recommendation of our government's policies is appreciated. But, thank you, Senator—I will not say it a third time yet.

para.tab: The study says that the main reason many women with young children find it hard to return to work is the cost of child care. That is one of the main barriers for women returning to work, but that has been overcome by the child-care assistance and the child-care cash rebate. The report also highlights this government's commitment to helping families juggle balancing work and family commitments and responsibilities. Contrary to what we hear from those opposite, the report found that the child-care assistance and the child-care cash rebate were of more assistance to women on low incomes than to women on high incomes. The report says:

answer.para: The government's child-care subsidies have a dramatic equalising effect on mothers' incomes.
There you go, Senator; they do. That is measured by them—not me. The report continues:

Without the subsidies, some mothers in the study would have to spend 70 per cent of their take-home pay on child care. However, when the subsidies are included, this is reduced to less than 10 per cent in some cases.

The study shows that government policies particularly help low income women and that women working full-time who are on a low income and who are married with two children get a weekly subsidy of up to $106 per week. By contrast, women on a high income with two children in care get a subsidy of up to $56. Again, a low income married mother with one child in care has her income boosted by about 15 per cent with the government's child-care subsidies. It is important to remind everyone listening that last week in this House it was Senator Minchin who kept saying that the opposition, if and when they ever got into government, would income test—

talk.start.para: —When they get into government—get it right.

—If and when, Senator. You can say what you like, but we are fairly clear on this side. Senator Minchin was saying that the opposition would income test the child-care cash rebate. He would actually say to working women, `The wage justice, the tax justice that occurs for any other tax rebate for costs against earning an income is not for you.' It is a very important principle that we have fought for, Senator Minchin. We are pleased to know that, if you ever got into government, you would take it away. I suppose this is a piece of the hypothetical child-care policy from over there being dribbled out, as we are now told by your leader.

para.tab: Some 230,000 families are benefiting from these payments. It is the first time, as I have said, that the costs of child care have been recognised as a legitimate claim against earning an income. It is a very important and very significant payment. It assists families across a whole range of the income scale. But the most important thing about this document is that it highlights the benefits to working families of our child-care payments—both the child-care assistance and the child-care cash rebate. That is very good news for government. It is a very good reinforcement of the message that we have been sending out all along—working families benefit from our child-care policies.

termed it last week, will the minister give the government's reasons for not doing so?

I have just been travelling and I am not up to date with the precise terms of either the present proposed legislation or what it will include. —Thank you, Madam Deputy President. I extend my congratulations to you. My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. (Time expired)

—On the weekend the Attorney-General did refer to the fact that at the core of this government's policies and programs is a fundamental focus on the family. It has always been the case on our side that we recognise the family as a basic building block of our society. We recognise that recent press reports have been sensationalising divorce statistics. They have been misleading, but I think they have also struck a chord with people in our community. It is a chord that, regardless of what level the statistics indicate, national policy framers must take into account.

para.tab: Supporting and strengthening families is essential to our government's agenda. We should recognise, with this in mind, that the government released the agenda for families earlier this year. That agenda highlighted quite a number of major initiatives that we have put in place to assist families. You would appreciate probably more than most, Senator Harradine, that some 10 per cent of the federal budget is directly spent on financial support for families. That is a large amount of money, but it is money geared towards assisting families in need and is particularly geared towards easing the stress levels of families. As I said, 10 per cent of federal government expenditure is spent on direct financial support for families. In this context, in terms of broader policies, we should also recognise that our economic management direction is also fostered on creating the right environment for the creation and maintenance of families.

I could go through a number of initiatives, but let me point to one—I think you raised it indirectly, Senator Harradine—that is, initiatives within the law and justice area. For instance, the May justice statement provided major focus on support for families. Our initiatives were aimed at preventing legal problems and improving the options for resolving disputes where resort to the law is necessary. The justice statement itself lifted funding to a range of family relationship support services by some $12.3 million over four years. For instance, the number of places available in relationship preparation courses will be doubled to almost 45,000 by lifting total funding by $4 million over four years. Another $2.7 million will assist relationship and family service agencies to meet the problems facing non-English speaking background families. Funding will also be provided to improve access in remote areas and funding for family skills training services will be increased to $2.8 million over four years—a 50 per cent boost towards helping approximately 12,000 clients. As well as that, almost $3 million has been allocated to expand adolescent, mediation and family therapy centres in regional and rural Australia.

They are some of the initiatives that the government gave a commitment to in the May justice statement. That justice statement also had a commitment towards continuing to build an agenda in the legal area to minimise the trauma that families suffer through separation and also to continue to build within the legal system a more sensitive system for handling family problems.

Our position as a government is that yes, we do recognise that no matter what the statistics are, there needs to be a commitment by government to assist families in a preventative way. Much of our social justice agenda is geared towards that. Also, when people have to go to court, they are geared towards assessing them in that process as well.

talk.start.para: —I am sorry to have to ask this supplementary question. I was not being emotional about it. These are the figures by the ABS, not the press. It is an appalling situation. I am asking: what are you going to do about the fact that you only spend on average 10 bucks on marriage education per marriage? Why don't you take up the suggestion by Father Tony Kerin that, on notification of marriage by a couple, vouchers should be given to the couple for them to undergo marriage training? Why can't you give couples who are courting and contemplating marriage a voucher so that they can undertake marriage education, communication skills and so on? You are not dealing with that matter; in fact, you have put that aside. Where is your commitment to marriage?

—I did it about 18 months ago, actually. I signed up last year and I am quite happy about it, thank you very much. As I said, the stats, in a sense, are not the driving force here. The driving force of this government is to get the policies in place for people pre-marriage and if in fact they do have to hit the legal system. That is why there is a social justice program. That is why there are also major initiatives in rental assistance to assist families and people who are about to get married. You cannot see it in isolation. You just cannot see the government's response limited to a voucher system. If that is all you wanted, that would not cost much; it would be easy. The reality is that you have to attack this sort of issue at the core and across the spectrum. As I said, social justice is important. Continuing measures are important. The May justice statement to handle people going through the legal system is important.
—Do you speak for Lavarch on this?
—I am indeed.
—That will be of interest to his electorate.

question.block.title: Murdered Hostages: Freedom of Information Requests

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister confirm, firstly, that the families of murdered hostages Kellie Wilkinson and David Wilson made freedom of information requests of his department some five and three months ago respectively regarding those abductions and murders; secondly, that both families have made repeated requests to resolve the prolonged delays in accessing those documents; and, thirdly, that neither family has received access to a single document to date? Why is the government being so tardy as to at least appear to be obstructive? Can the minister assure the Wilkinson and Wilson families that they will be given full access to the requested files in sufficient time to prepare their submissions to the Senate inquiry?

—Of course they will be. Freedom of information requests are always difficult when there is a complex matter involving many months of government activity and many high officials, as was the case in this instance, and a number of issues going to inter-governmental relations, which was clearly of the essence in both these extremely tragic affairs.

para.tab: I did spend a lot of time with the key members of those families, particularly the parents—particularly the mothers in both cases—during that period. I know that, as far as the mothers are concerned, there is no great desire to further seek to make a public issue of the government's handling of this matter. But that does not in any way inhibit the government in its desire to be cooperative and to get on the public record anything that can appropriately be put on the public record and further helps to explain how these matters were handled.

We gave very full explanations of all the issues involved in the handling of these cases. I believe there is nothing further that can be revealed which would in any way change the characterisation of our handling of it. But, as I have indicated from the outset, we are perfectly happy for that Senate inquiry to go ahead. I will do what I can now to find out what the status of the consideration of those FOI requests is and make sure there is no inhibition on the capacity to place an appropriate submission before the committee. If that is the gist of what you are saying, it is a fair comment and we will do the best we can accordingly.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Minister, you have recently announced a number of measures to streamline immigration processes for visitors to Australia to make the whole system more convenient and efficient. The introduction of an electronic visa system means that processing times at Australian airports have been cut to an average of 54 seconds. Can the minister outline what further reforms are planned to minimise delays for overseas visitors on arrival?

—I thank Senator Denman for her continuing interest in this area. She is right; the government is keen to pursue an active agenda in this area to make entry into Australia much smoother and more efficient for those who want to visit this country—and some 3 million people in the last financial year did so.

para.tab: I announced just a few weeks ago—and senators will recall this—that, by the end of this year, visitors from around 16 countries will be able to have their visas issued by approved travel agents without having to visit Australian immigration posts. In this context, I explained the details of an agency arrangement for the Czech republic to the Czech ambassador last Thursday. I can announce that the arrangements are operating in Greece as from now. That is one area of reform that the government is very keen to move quickly on. It illustrates how keen we are to ensure that there is smooth and efficient entry into Australia by those wishing to come here.

We are also keen to pursue new technology. In that context, we are making optimum use of technology to streamline the process at airports once passengers have arrived. My colleague the minister for customs, Senator Chris Schacht, and I are today announcing a unique reform which began over the weekend and which will benefit not only overseas visitors but also Australians coming home. It is an initiative called advanced passenger clearance and has been developed jointly by my department, Qantas and the Australian Customs Service. This is a world first.

Advanced passenger clearance essentially means that incoming Qantas passengers will in future have their immigration and customs details cleared whilst they are still in the air. Initially, it will operate for Qantas flights from Los Angeles. The first flight to use the new process arrived in Sydney on Friday morning. We will be expanding the process in the next few months to cover all Qantas arrivals into Australia.

The process is such that, at the Qantas check-in at Los Angeles airport, the passengers are offered advanced passenger clearance with their seat allocation and boarding pass. The check-in agent enters a passport or visa number in the Qantas computer and sends it to Immigration in Canberra for clearance. The passenger is then issued with a new immigration arrival card, answers the three questions on it, signs it and simply swipes the card's magnetic strip through the entry point at Sydney airport to confirm arrival. I think Senator Denman referred in her question to the fact that at the moment it takes 54 seconds to process a person coming into Australia. This initiative obviously will cut the time even further, as Qantas passengers will go directly towards specially designated channels.

In announcing this initiative with my colleague Senator Schacht, I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate all agencies involved for their innovative approach to customer service. It means that those people coming into Australia will have the capacity to have their clearance approved while they are still in the air, which will make it a very quick process when they arrive at the airports here.

talk.start.para:
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. On 7 September in response to a letter from Senators Coulter, Spindler and me, you wrote that France now normally uses an all French route through the Caribbean to transport nuclear material to Mururoa. This week's
New Scientist
magazine quotes a
Le Monde
article which suggests that plutonium for the Mururoa tests is flown across the United States. Also, the
New Scientist
has been told by the US Department of State that between 15 and 18 French military aircraft have been allowed to fly through American airspace since May. What have you done to determine the true story? Is this an example of the US cooperating with the French as members of the nuclear club? Will you, as our letter originally asked, press the US to refuse French military passage over US airspace in order to delay the next planned French tests?

—We understand that, under US domestic law, France would be required to seek permission to transport through US airspace any nuclear device or hazardous material, including components made of fissile material. We have been advised by United States officials in Washington that France has not sought permission to transport fissile material or components through US controlled airspace. It does not become necessary for France to take the risk of being found to be breaching US law, because it does have alternative routes that are available—as I pointed out to Senator Bell and others who have written or spoken to me on this subject.

para.tab: In the earlier period of atmospheric tests, the US refused permission for French military flights on several occasions. The cargoes were then reportedly sent by sea. In the event of there being such a refusal now, it would be perfectly possible for the French to fly in the material through alternative, equally viable and efficient routes. This would be mainly through stopping over on French territory—such as Guadeloupe in the Caribbean. That was apparently not technically possible 20 odd years ago, but it is possible now. Under those circumstances, there is simply no reason to believe that the French are acting in the way that has been suggested by Senator Bell or in the press reports to which he referred. Accordingly, we do not see any foundation for being concerned about that.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I draw the minister's attention to the fact that, after many months of difficult negotiations following the first stage of implementation of the Declaration of Principles between Israel and the PLO, the two sides yesterday initialled an agreement on the extension of autonomy in the West Bank, due to be signed later this week. Given that many in Australia have followed the development of the peace process with interest and concern, I ask the minister: what is now the government's assessment of the prospects for a comprehensive settlement in the Middle East?

—I am sure all Australians would join with me in very warmly welcoming the agreement which has now been reached after many long days, weeks and, indeed months of negotiations between Israel and the PLO on the extension of Palestinian autonomy and in congratulating both sides on their commitment and perseverance over the last year and a half. It is an historic step forward for the peace process. It does pave the way for the holding of Palestinian elections and, indeed, the commencement on schedule next year, hopefully, of the final status talks, including on matters as sensitive as the future of Jerusalem.

para.tab: That agreement has been hard-won, even if Senator Hill is not showing any interest in it at the moment, and it should not be undermined by those seeking to score political points against the leadership of Israel and the leadership of the PLO. Even more, one can only hope desperately that it will not be undermined by the actions of extremists on both sides who fear the successful completion of the peace process. It has taken great courage, I believe, for the leaders of Israel and of the Palestinian Authority to show the restraint that they have in the face of such provocation to date. We can only hope that such restraint will be maintained.

There is no acceptable, practicable alternative to a negotiated settlement in the Middle East. A return to the past of failures to meet and confront these issues across the negotiating table would be a disaster for everyone concerned. We certainly hope that both parties will seek practical responses to Israel's security concerns that do not entail economic hardship to Palestinians.

I have to say that on the other track of the peace process, the Israel-Syria track, recent events have been less encouraging, although I am sure from my own recent visit to the region that there remains a strong commitment on both sides to achieving a settlement. Both sides are relying heavily on the United States to expedite the negotiations and it is clear that continuing United States engagement in the process is crucial.

There is, unfortunately, no great evident desire on either side to move that negotiation forward at this stage. That is worrying because the window of opportunity for getting results is becoming increasingly limited. As the United States is about to enter an election year, it becomes more and more difficult to get US policy makers focused on being decisive in their responses to issues of domestic political sensitivity. Similarly, the Israelis are going to be increasingly occupied with their own elections next year, with all the difficulty that follows so far as keeping a rather fragile coalition majority together, given the disposition to engage in electoral grandstanding related activity—not an unknown phenomenon in other parts of the world.

The coming months will be crucial for the Syria-Israel track. I do want to say on behalf of Australia that a failure to narrow the differences between the two sides in those remaining months of this year would, I think, be greeted with considerable pessimism around the region as an important opportunity lost.

The basic point remains one of very warmly welcoming and congratulating the agreement that has been reached just a few hours ago finally between Israel and Palestine on the second stage of the Palestinian track negotiations. That is a major step forward and one that across all sides of this parliament we ought to be very warmly congratulating indeed. On that basis, I ask that further questions be placed on the
Notice Paper
.

talk.start.para: —Last week Senator Parer asked me a question about agency arrangements out of Taiwan. I seek leave to incorporate a further answer on that.

para.tab: Leave granted.

answer.para: On 20 September, Senator Parer asked me questions relating to a fee of $50 being charged in relation to tourists visiting in Australia from Taiwan. I said I would make inquiries and I now provide the following information:

Australia does not recognise Taiwan and does not have official representation there. Taiwan residents may apply for visas through the Australian commerce and industry office (ACIO) in Taipei. Decisions to issue visas are made by authorised delegates in Hong Kong and ACIO evidences the visa issue in Taipei.

ACIO is a legal entity under contract between Austrade and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI), the peak body representing state-based chambers. A supplementary contract between my department and the ACCI provides for a visa facilitation service (VFS) within ACIO.

The $50 fee is not as Senator Parer seems to think a charge for a visitor visa. It is a charge for a commercial service provided by ACIO. The arrangement saves Taiwan residents the cost of travelling to Hong Kong to apply there, but that option remains open to them.

The arrangement has been in place since July 1992. Without it, Australia would not have benefited from the boom in tourism from Taiwan which has seen visas issued rise from 40,156 in 1991-92 to 134,750 in 1994-95. The figure for 1995-96 is expected to go above 150,000.

Other countries charge a range of statutory or other fees associated with visa issue to residents of Taiwan. For example, the American institute provides a similar type of service and charges NT750 (about $US30 or $A40) and a further $US20 for machine readable visas. ACIO is in the middle of the `market'.

So the ACIO fee is not a statutory charge as Senator Parer seems to think but a commercial fee for a particular service comparable with the fees travel and other agents already charge for similar services around the world.

Given that residents would have to otherwise access an overseas diplomatic mission, the technical infrastructure involved and other ACIO overheads this charge is a moderate one and is subject to periodic review.
There is no statutory fee for a short term visitor visa from Taiwan or anywhere else.

—Senator Ellison asked me a question about proposed native title amendments in question time. I give him a response now. As to the substantive content of those proposed amendments this time round, they are spelt out in the press release of the Attorney-General dated 19 September. It might help the
Hansard
