answer.para: NEWS RELEASE
ATTORNEY-GENERAL
THE HON. MICHAEL LAVARCH MP
19 September, 1995
COMMENT SOUGHT ON NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENTS

A Commonwealth officials' paper outlining proposed Government amendments to the Native Title Act 1993 (NTA) resulting from the High Court decision in the Brandy case has been released for public comment.
The paper also proposes typographical and technical amendments identified as necessary after 20 months' experience with the NTA processes.
The amendments were foreshadowed by the Prime Minister in his 1 September 1995 media release which stressed that there would be no compromise on the fundamental principles of the NTA.

The recognition and protection of native tide in the Act, including provisions dealing with future acts, strikes a balance between the protection of native title and general land management and resource development needs.
Many of the proposals are similar to those in a discussion paper of 14 March 1995 by the President of the National Native Tide Tribunal, Justice Robert French, who has welcomed the proposals.

Under the new system, applications under the NTA for determinations of native title or for compensation, will be commenced in the Federal Court to conform with the High Court's Brandy ruling that only courts can make binding determinations.
The NNTT will continue to perform notification and mediation functions but the Federal Court will hear and determine applications.

In practice this will not mean any change in direction for the NNTT whose operations to date have been largely confined to registration, mediation and those of an arbitral body under the right to negotiate process.

The major difference between the Government's proposed amendments and Justice French's suggested scheme is the application of a registration test before claimants will be entitled to the right to negotiate over certain future acts involving the claimed land.

The registration test will be similar to the existing test for acceptance applied by the NNTT in that the Registrar will register a claim unless she is of the opinion that, on the face of it, the claim cannot be made out.

However the amendments will make it clear—as the Government always intended—that the prima facie test is to be applied before registration, rather than in the process of accepting the claim for determination.
This will address the comments of Justice O'Loughlin in the Miriuwung Gajerrong case that registration takes place on lodgement of the claim and the claim attracts the right to negotiate from then.

The Government believes that the registration test is essential to maintain the balance of interests in the NTA. Unregistered claims will still be able to proceed in the Federal Court but any unmeritorious cases will be subject to the Court's normal processes for dealing with baseless or vexatious claims.

The proposed amendments will not affect the jurisdiction of recognised State/Territory bodies to deal with native title matters under the relevant State or Territory legislation and specific amendments will ensure minimal disruption to those bodies.

The paper has been sent to a range of interested parties including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander representative bodies, the ATSIC Board and ATSIC Regional Councils, industry bodies and State and Territory officials for comment by 19 October.
The Government intends to introduce amendments into the Parliament before the end of the current sittings.

talk.start.para: —On the particular question that Senator Ellison went on to ask about the pastoral lease issue, the government accepts that there is a degree of uncertainty about the impact of pastoral leases on native title. Its view, and that of the states and territories, is well known—that, based on the majority reasoning in Mabo No. 2, native title has been extinguished. But the matter is one that must be resolved in the courts. For the Commonwealth to legislate on the position would not only be unfair but would also expose us to a possible liability to provide `just terms' compensation as required by the constitution.

para.tab: The issue is before the courts now in a number of cases, including Wik and Waanyi. The Commonwealth has used its best endeavours to ensure that the issue is resolved as soon as possible. We are certainly conscious of the need to get it resolved as fast as possible. In any event, pastoralists can be reassured that their leases are valid and can be renewed without negotiation even if native title proves to have survived, which is contrary to our belief.

talk.start.para: —I also take this opportunity to respond to a question asked of me by Senator Panizza on 29 June about the legal costs of Mr Graeme Campbell in relation to defamation action which has been brought against him. I give Senator Panizza the following reply to the question he asked me on 29 June.

para.tab: I am informed that the libel case referred to was a case brought by the Western Australia Director of Public Prosecutions against the member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Campbell, rising out of comments allegedly made by Mr Campbell about an investigation by the Western Australia police into a matter concerning a member of the director's family. I understand the police investigation related to a state matter and did not relate to any federal matters.

It is clear from what I have just said that Mr Campbell's case is quite different from Dr Lawrence's case, which involves an attack on Dr Lawrence in her capacity as a federal government minister. It does not appear that the allegations, the subject of the defamation claim against Mr Campbell, were made by him in the performance of his federal electorate duties on behalf of his constituents. In all the circumstances, there appears to be insufficient federal connection to warrant consideration of Commonwealth funding of Mr Campbell's defence. By way of completeness, I note that Mr Campbell has not applied for Commonwealth funding on this matter.

speech.speaker: MacGibbon D.J.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Ian Macdonald this day, relating to the closure of meatworks.

speech.para: At the outset I declare that I have a financial interest in the beef industry and I have a knowledge that far exceeds anything that Senator Collins will ever acquire about the cattle industry. I have never heard so many misleading statements as I have heard this afternoon in response to that question.

para.tab: The facts of the matter, Senator Collins, are that American beef is about 60 per cent more expensive off the hoof than Australian beef, yet it can be landed for sale in this country at about 40c a kilo cheaper. Do not tell me that is because the American abattoirs are out on the ranches. It has nothing to do with it at all.

The heart of the cattle export industry in Australia is in central Queensland and that is now in a crisis—a crisis. The industry is just on the brink of survival. We have had a drought of major proportions for four years, running into the fifth year. No-one down here has any knowledge of the drought situation at all. It is really acute in relation to the cattle industry.

Abattoirs are not petrol stations or corner stores or supermarkets. They are a vital part of the cattle industry. They are the price setters. A producer of cattle who wants to sell his beasts really has to take what the abattoirs offer him.

Furthermore, the abattoirs negotiate the export sales contracts. It is not the cattle producer, it is not some grand governmental authority—least of all, your department, Senator Collins—that negotiates the sales; it is the individual abattoir that negotiates the sales. There are three critical points in relation to that.

The first is that we probably have half the number of abattoirs that we had 20 years ago, so the competition is not there. Secondly, we have quite antique union relationships within the abattoirs because of the meat workers and their various unions. The third crucial point is overseas ownership, which is now very considerable in the industry.

The first thing I want to talk about is the lack of competition that comes from the great reduction in the number of abattoirs. Because there are so few, you have to sell to the nearest abattoir. Therefore, they are the real price setters. There is no way you can negotiate with them for another few cents a pound on the beef.

They have become extremely tough in recent years, particularly with the classification of carcases and the fat layers. For 12 or 13 millimetres it is a certain price; for fat layers beyond that, if you are producing fat cattle for the Jap ox market, or something like that, the price drops dramatically. But the arbiter of the fat level is the abattoir. It is not possible for the producer to go in there or sell beforehand and know what the fat level is on their stock.

The second thing is this antique relationship that the unions have in their industrial relations with the abattoirs. The fact of the matter, Senator Collins, is that the productivity—the throughput, the number of kills per hour in our abattoirs—is very significantly less than in other efficient abattoirs around the world. That is because of all the things we have inherited and which, in 13 years, you have not lifted a finger to correct. You have given in, time and time again, to whatever demands the unions make.

I recognise the difficulty of dealing with the meat workers. They would cut your throat in a flash and pretend they have just slipped on a wet floor. But they need to be taken on and, until they are taken on, the cattle industry has no future in Australia.

Thirdly, there is this matter of overseas ownership. You have a company like Conagra, which bought Australian Meat Holdings from its Australian owners. Conagra would have hundreds of millions of dollars tied up in the Australian beef industry but it has billions tied up in the American industry. It is faced with overproduction in the United States, a glut on the market there. It wants to corner the Japanese and Korean markets and it is quite prepared to close down, as it has in the last few weeks, the holdings it has in Australia.

I come back to the central point: we are in a crisis in this industry, which is not a small industry. The cattle market is the fourth largest Australian export industry, and it is basically situated in the central part of Queensland. I can tell you that it is in crisis today and that the government is not doing anything about it. It is not using the powers that it should have to preserve this vital Australian export asset. Given the mess that we are in with increased mortgage rates and interest rates through the community because of the huge overseas debt that you people have built up, you have a moral compulsion to do something about this.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —I, too, would like to take part in this debate. I also declare that I have an interest in the cattle industry, in the form of a shareholding in the Kilcoy abattoirs.

para.tab: I join this debate because I also recognise the crisis situation all over Queensland, particularly in its central areas. It is a crisis that has to be faced. There are 2,000 people out of work, and four or five abattoirs that have been closed down, as enunciated by Senator Ian MacDonald. The situation is getting worse. It is a question not only of the abattoirs closing down and of the lack of competition that the previous speaker, Senator MacGibbon, mentioned; it is also a crisis of drought, compounded by high interest rates and now, the coup de grace, the abattoirs closing.

We have heard many people announce the problems that have been caused by bankruptcies in rural Australia. This has been not only in the wheat industry but also in the cattle industry and the wool industry. It has almost reached a stage of monumental proportion in rural Australia, where it has been said that up to one in three people are facing some type of financial hardship.

The cattle industry just cannot continue to go on with the prospects with the way that the tally is counted in the abattoirs at the moment. When people reach their tally, they go home at 11 o'clock or 12 o'clock. Then the huge amount of investment in the abattoirs is left there, not producing. This may have been all right in the days when we had forward contracts, but your own initiatives have brought us into a world market—we are trading in a global village. Time after time, Senator McMullan gets up and tells us that, and no-one on this side of the house would argue against that. But if you want to allow us to trade in a global village, if you want us to take part in a world market, and if you want to reduce the tariffs to nothing, if you want to do all these things that this side of parliament has not argued with, then you must bring us in with competitive abattoirs and an industrial relations system that works.

I listened very carefully to you, Senator Collins, today when you spoke about the difference between New Zealand and other countries, and watched the movement you made with your hands. That might have made good television; it might even have impressed the press gallery. But it was absolutely wrong. You know as well as I know that there is a very considerable difference between the cost of processing a beast in New Zealand and in the USA. I do not want to get to the case, as in some countries, where labour is down to $4 an hour and we absolutely—

talk.start.para: —What?
—I was going to use an unparliamentary term, but I will not use that term—`disadvantage the working class'. There has to be some movement upward in the abattoirs that we can process at a reasonable—
—Productivity.

—Yes, where we can lift our productivity in a reasonable way so that we can absolutely compete with processing in foreign abattoirs. We understand the constraints that you have in the union movement, but there has to be a reasonable movement forward. You have not addressed that problem. Consequently, we have seen 2,000 meatworkers, the people who would support your cause, out of work.
—Not for that reason alone, Ron.
—It is exactly for that reason.
—It is not for that reason only. Nothing to do with the exchange rate? Nothing to do with the marketplace?

—Of course the exchange rate and the glut have compounded the issue and have brought it to a head, but that has been boiling in the pot, bubbling along for the last four or five years. You know as well as I do that if you want Australia to be competitive, to trade in a competitive market, then your government has to be able to go to the meatworkers and say, `Listen, boys. The game is over. We can no longer have this tally system where you are out of the abattoirs at 12 o'clock in the day when you have done your tally.'
(Time expired)

—I was interested to listen to some of the comments that have been made in regard to this matter. I would like to indicate that recently, on one occasion with the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee, I visited a meatworks in Victoria. Admittedly, they do kill for local consumption, but they were quite proud of the fact that they had developed a method of management and a process of consultation with members of the meatworkers union which had been preceded by discussions with the officials of the meatworkers union, including Wally Curran, about these changes that were to take place.

para.tab: Those meatworks indicated to me that they had got a very good response from Wally Curran, the Victorian secretary, and that the people in that particular meatworks had cooperated quite well. They pointed out that they now were in a position to carry out much of the inspection work themselves and that they had been assisted by AQIS by way of AQIS putting in place a process where AQIS could have an overall auditing role but the inspection within the meatworks was carried out by people who were qualified in that area and working for the company. They also talked about this cooperation.

In other areas where we had a number of public hearings on the role of AQIS it was pointed out to us that there were some problems regarding cooperation in relation to awards under which AQIS inspectors worked and meatworkers worked and that this process did add to costs. But I cannot recall one occasion where the accusation was made that the meatworkers were not conforming to what were reasonable circumstances. Because a number of meatworks have laid off people overnight, it has been suggested that all of sudden the burden has become so great that they had to lay off people. Those on the other side know that that is not the case.

A lot has been said about the tally system. When there are any obstacles to what the opposition or some people in business see as the most fluent of operations that will give the best economic return, because of certain old ideas that have been perpetuated for some years, the union is always to blame. Let it be known very clearly that meatworkers have historically worked ordinary hours—going way back to the days when they worked 60 hours, as everyone else did. It was the employers who brought in the tally system to encourage workers to get in there, to do the tallying, to shorten the number of hours they would have normally done and to get out of the place, and that would guarantee the employers that over a certain number of hours or less they would get a certain tally. The employers brought in that, and now they are complaining about that as a concept.

I do not say for one moment that changes should not be made in relation to this by way of discussion and cooperation, because anybody in the meatworks and that industry knows that quite a large volume of meat has got to go to export and that we have to compete against other people. But the people who suggest that, by doing the sorts of things that we may be able to do to increase efficiency and a more cooperative approach, we can surmount obstacles of cheap meat below what reasonably should be sold and competing unfairly by way of bounties or other assistance are smoking opium, because we cannot defeat that.

I suggest that, if criticism is going to be made, let us level it at everybody in the industry because all of them have to carry some of the blame. Let us look to the future and rationally try to work out the best way to go forward in the interests of everybody in the industry and in the community.

talk.start.para: —Today in question time I raised a very serious matter of concern to parliamentarians in Queensland, and I guess the problems are the same everywhere throughout Australia. It is not only the beef producers, the meatworkers and the people who rely on them who are in crisis. It is the small towns, the communities, in regional Australia that I have a very great concern for.

para.tab: After 13 years in power, this government, a Labor Party government, has absolutely no solutions whatsoever to the problem. I asked Senator Collins to explain to me why it is that the abattoir costs per kilo finished weight are 41c in the United States, 72c in New Zealand, 105c in Argentina and 113c in Australia. There has to be some reason for that. Perhaps Senator Burns could have explained it to me. He did not, but perhaps he could have.

Senator Collins talked about the Booz-Allen and Hamilton report and told the Senate that the costs of processing the meat had something to do with transportation. Senator Collins knew that was an untruth and knew that he was misleading the Senate when he said that. It is typical of Senator Collins. He has been a failure as opposition leader in the Northern Territory parliament and a failure in every ministry he has taken here. His only approach when he is cornered is to get up and abuse the questioner. You wait: as soon as I sit down, he will get up again and he will abuse me. He will spend four minutes out of his time calling me names. They do not worry me. Names from Senator Collins do not worry me. But you watch: every time he gets the opportunity, he takes part in a bit of name calling, a bit of personal attack. He will not address the question before us.

Senator Collins was trying to tell the Senate that these different costs related to transportation. As he would know if he read this Booz Allen and Hamilton report—I suspect he has not—the costs of delivering to the market are listed on page 42. It shows that the cost of processing in Australia is 112.7c per kilo. It will also show that transportation is an extra 37.1c per kilo. It will show that in the United States the price is 41.2c per kilo for processing and the costs of transportation are an additional figure. In New Zealand, 71.7c per kilo is the cost of meat processing. Transportation in New Zealand is 28.4c additional. This is the sort of minister we have on the government side. Government ministers will get up and say anything at question time when they have an audience, knowing that what they are saying is incorrect. That deserves the censure of the Senate.

I am not concerned in these point taking exercises. What I want to know is what this government is going to do for the people of regional Australia, for these meatworkers, for these small communities and towns that rely upon it. Sure, you cannot correct everything. There are some things beyond our capabilities as a nation. But, by the same token, there are a number of things that can be addressed in relation to costs of production.

I do not want to attack the unionists, as Senator Burns mentioned. A lot of them I know are decent, hardworking people. But the system is wrong. There is no encouragement for productivity. The unionists and the meatworkers—I guess they have to be unionists in that industry—can be encouraged to have a greater input to increase their productivity, and share some of the rewards. The rewards should not all go to Conagra or anyone else; they should go to everybody. It is within this government's power to do that. But after 13 years of ministers like Senator Collins and others, they have done absolutely nothing.

In my lifetime, I can remember a lot of communities where meatworks have shut down completely and the town has closed. Here is a government, a supposedly Labor government, that has done absolutely nothing about it. They can do something about the charges, they can do something about the costs and they can do something about the costs of doing business in rural areas. That is what this government should be doing—not abusing those who raise the question.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This is a very interesting debate. A lot of very good things come out of debates like this where there are exchanges across the chamber.
—Name one.

—I will tell you what has come out of this. We have now discovered your policy for looking to the rural industry in Australia, specifically the meat industry. You have gone through and shown that there are problems in it. The one solution that has come from the other side is that there should be a bearing down on the conditions available to workers. Senator Boswell, whom all on this side respect, said, `We are not going to pay them as low as $4 an hour. We would not pay them that little.' But that was the region he was thinking in.

para.tab: Senator Boswell was saying that, to cure the problem in the Australian meat industry, this government should be thinking of forcing workers to accept something in the region of $4.00 an hour.

Senator Panizza interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Senator Panizza interjects, and the effect of his interjection is, `Yes, that's all right, suppress the conditions of the workers.'
—I did not say that at all.
—Sorry, what did you say?
—I said, are you saying that the US conditions are less than ours in Australia?
—Senator Panizza does not want to suppress the conditions of the workers in Australia, but he points out, as an opposition party member, that conditions in America are less.
—No, I didn't' say that. I'm asking you whether you think that.
—I would have thought that the fair inference to take from that, Senator Panizza, is that you think the conditions of the workers in Australia should be—
—I didn't. I'm asking you!
—That is all right; that is a policy.
—He wants $3.00 an hour for juniors; he supported that.
—Senator Burns points that out—and Senator Burns has been through these struggles again and again. So has Senator Murphy, who also wants to say a few words.

para.tab: But this is very interesting. I think we should have more of these debates where the solution to problems on the farms in regional areas of Australia is to reduce the conditions of workers. Well, that is all right. But I would suggest that if the opposition were to say that, for heaven's sake, they should not come in here and say that they are on the side of the bluecollar workers of this country. Say what you mean; say, `Yes, we are going to overcome all the adverse effects on this industry, including those of drought, by reducing the wages and conditions of workers.' That is a policy you have put forward, and we now know what we are debating.

talk.start.para: —After having listened to Senator Cooney's comments, I wish to make a few of my own on the same subject. This is one of the few occasions of which I am aware when Senator Cooney has been so glib in his presentation before this chamber. He has misquoted my colleague Senator Boswell, deliberately or otherwise, and in no way has he faced up to the real and serious issues affecting this most important $6 billion industry with its uncompetitiveness in our international markets, which we are now debating. Senator Cooney, if you are going to take up the brief of defending Senator Collins and Senator Burns in this chamber, you should have started long ago; even had you done so, you still would never be out of this chamber—in particular, with the brief of Senator Collins with his long list of blunders in other ministeries, such as his promises about waterfront conditions and pay TV.

para.tab: The real issue before us is the uncompetitiveness of this particular industry; it is highly uncompetitive. Those on the other side of the chamber have approached this issue with a heartlessness being exhibited towards farmers. If this Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) has ever had a serious obligation toward his ministry, it is now, due to the drought and the low commodity prices that farmers have borne for the last four to five years. Farmers now simply cannot take this final straw—that is, the uncompetitiveness of the processing component of the beef industry. In fact, it is the whole monumental cost structure that drags down our competitiveness internationally and, indeed, illustrates the fundamental malaise within our economy.

As was quoted by other speakers, our farmers are the most efficient beef farmers in the world. As just one measuring stick, in the past 20 years farm productivity in labour has increased by so much that it is now some 50 per cent greater than the average OECD farm productivity figures. Yet in the last 20 years the terms of trade have decreased on an OECD scale—and that has far outweighed any increase. Farmers are playing their particular part. But once the product leaves the farmgate that is when, layer upon layer, the cost structure is laid on. That occurred last year until we reached the absurd point of having one of the major American chain stores, Sizzler, importing or attempting to import—

talk.start.para: —They did not import.

—They didn't in the end, but they attempted to import American beef into this country. So it is a fact that we have the absurd situation where American beef can be imported into this country and sold domestically cheaper than we can do it ourselves in this country. The facts are there, Senator Collins. The farmer in America receives some 60 per cent more off the hoof to buy American beef, yet they can deliver it to this country some 40c to 50c cheaper a kilo than we can deliver in our own country. That is an absurd situation. It costs something like 41c a kilo to process meat in the United States, 72c in New Zealand and $1.13 a kilo in Australia. Can you see how uncompetitive we are?

para.tab: It is true that the union movement must take on the burden for the unproductiveness of this particular industry and, if nothing else, for the waterfront. The uncompetitiveness of the waterfront has certainly been borne out by one of the government's own reports by the Bureau of Industry Economics in August 1995 showing just how uncompetitive our waterfront has become. It relates directly back to the union movement, and so does the processing industry.

Senator Burns quotes Wally Curran as a reformer. For the last 20 years or more Wally Curran has shut down abattoirs in Victoria and has been the reason for the shutdown of abattoirs in Victoria. I am not even sure whether there is an abattoir in Victoria any more; there would be only one or two. They have all shifted to other states. They have gone to Queensland and they have been pursued vigorously in Queensland.
(Time expired)

talker.name: Senator BOB COLLINS
talker.role: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: —In the short time remaining I would like to address some of the issues that have been raised; although it is difficult, considering the mishmash of positions taken by opposition speakers on this matter, to really focus on—
—More mish than mash.

—There is certainly as much mish as mash anyway. Senator MacGibbon complained about the extent to which Conagra has invested in the Australian beef industry and suggested, by necessary implication, that the government should have a direct role somehow in setting up additional meatworks around Australia. That was an interesting contribution from Senator MacGibbon.

para.tab: The principal point at issue is the very serious problem that is currently being experienced by beef producers and the towns that rely on their product in Queensland. I hope, along with the rest of the government, that that is short-lived. But it is foolish indeed to attribute the entire problem to industrial relations, as opposition speakers have done. It just indicates their profound ignorance of the problem.

The principal reasons are, as I said, the increased and quite serious competition from the United States into that market at the moment and the increase in the Australian dollar—and, I might add, the increasing costs of cattle for processing which has resulted from the need to feed grain to a lot of these cattle. Senator Boswell was honest enough to concede that a lot of this problem is in fact related to the drought.

As I said accurately, despite Senator Macdonald's assertions, the Booz Allen report, and he quoted from those figures, did point out that a great percentage of the competitive problems that are suffered by Australian beef producers—about 70 per cent—are not addressable by processors. One of those problems, as I correctly said, was transport—that is, the distance from the cattle supply to the processor. If Senator Macdonald bothers to read the report, he will in fact discover that that is so. I hope, along with all other senators, that the problems being suffered in North Queensland are short-lived.
(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)
—The Deputy President has received a letter from Senator Short proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:
The government's desperation in attempting to cover up its economic mismanagement by its denial of the obvious impact of Australia's massive foreign debt on domestic interest rates.

proctext.para: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.tab:
More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places
—

talk.start.para: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

speech.speaker: Short Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —This government really is desperate about the next election. How else do we explain its constant resort to the lie as the norm of political conduct when it comes to speaking about the economy? How else do we explain the tirade of defamatory vitriol, personal abuse and denigration that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) threw at the government's national savings adviser last Friday because of Dr FitzGerald's temerity in stating the blindingly obvious, namely, `There is a risk premium in our whole interest rate structure relating to the high level of foreign debt'?

para.tab: How else do we account for the evidence of the Carmen syndrome—that is, `I forget' or `I can't recall'—in the Prime Minister's recent statements denying a link between Australia's massive debt burden of $187,000 million, which is equivalent to $10,000 for every man and woman in Australia, and our interest rate structure, including mortgage interest rates? How could it be that the Prime Minister forgot last Friday that just a few years ago, at the height of the interest rate increases that we had in 1989 due to his own policies, the then Treasurer, now Prime Minister Keating, justified using high interest rates because they had the benefit of sharing the pain of attacking Australia's trade and debt problems, which spending cuts did not? Let me quote briefly from what the Prime Minister said at that time:
Monetary policy gives you a reduction (in living standards) across the board so the yuppies are paying, too!
Their disposable incomes are reduced by the interest costs of their investment, their mortgages or what have you.

speech.para: And here comes the rub. He continued:

para.tab: That's why there has to be a national effort, a fair and equitable spreading of the burden in reducing the current account deficit and sharing the burden on living standards.

speech.para: In other words, the Prime Minister—the then Treasurer in 1989—drew, quite correctly, in the clearest possible terms, the link between the current account deficit, foreign debt and the interest rate structure in Australia.

para.tab: How else, other than desperation at the present situation, can you explain the fact that virtually no respectable economist in Australia agrees with Treasurer Willis and his representative in this chamber, Senator Cook, who echoed the same words as Mr Willis last week, both of whom claim there is, to quote Treasurer Willis, `not one skerrick of truth' and that it `is completely and utterly untrue that foreign debt means higher rates of interest for Australians'? That is what the Treasurer said last week.

The government is panicking. That is good for us, of course, but it is not good for Australia or for Australians, because what it means is that the electorate is being fed—and will continue to be fed until the next election—a diet of deliberate untruths about the state of our economy and about the government's role in this. That is why I have brought forward this matter of public importance for debate today, namely:

speech.para: The government's desperation in attempting to cover up its economic mismanagement by its denial of the obvious impact of Australia's massive foreign debt on domestic interest rates.

Before looking at the real facts, though, let me also draw attention to the divisions within the government's most senior ranks on this matter. On the one hand, Treasurer Willis and Senator Cook, as I said, have asserted there was no link between our foreign debt and domestic interest rates. On the other hand, the then Treasurer, now Prime Minister, asserted quite the opposite a few years ago. Even in the last few days the Prime Minister seems to be much more equivocal than the Treasurer, because it was only last Wednesday that the Prime Minister said:
We must work to deal with the problem—
that is, of the current account deficit and foreign debt—
so we're not paying too high a premium on world interest rate markets.
A clear allusion there, I would have thought, to the link that he sees, quite rightly, between the debt level and our interest rate structure.

para.tab: Where does the Prime Minister really stand on this issue? It is yet another sign of a divided, disparate, desperate, incompetent, tired government which is in office well past its use-by date. Let me look at some of the facts, as distinct from the economic illiteracy being peddled by the government. In this context, by the way, I note that I am not surprised that Senator Wheelwright, who participated in a similar type of debate last week, does not seem to be included in Labor's batting team for this one. Unless things have changed, given his appalling performance last week, I was not at all surprised to see him dropped and Senator Burns substituted for him. It looks like Senator Burns might have got hurt at training last night and they have brought him back from the reserves. I welcome that very much indeed, Senator Wheelwright.

Let us have a look at a few of the facts and some of the things that real experts have said about this situation. Just a few months ago, in June in fact, the OECD released its report on Australia. It said in that report that `the widening current external deficit', which leads to higher foreign debt, exerts `significant upward pressures on Australia's real long-term interest rates'. The OECD said that. Normally the OECD does not put out reports on any particular country without getting the broad imprimatur of the country's own economic advisers. Whether that was the case or not, I do not know in this instance. It would be surprising if it was not, but certainly that is what the OECD said.

It would not surprise me if government advisers had given that imprimatur to the report because only a month earlier, the budget papers brought down in May that were circulated with the authority of the Treasurer, Mr Willis, said:

speech.para: . . . a high level of foreign borrowing relative to GDP can impose costs on an economy by making it more vulnerable to external shocks and by raising interest rate premia on borrowings.

That also was not an unusual statement. It seems to me to be blindingly obvious that that would be the case and I think the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser, at the time of the Reserve Bank annual report and in other speeches surrounding that occasion made precisely the same point.

para.tab:
Inevitably, higher interest rates on foreign borrowings will flow through to the home mortgage market and the business lending market as banks hold a large portion of Australia's foreign debt. It is no coincidence at all that Australia has the highest current account deficit in the OECD, the 47th worst ratio of net foreign debt to exports out of 51 countries rated by Standard and Poor's, and the highest bank prime interest rates among the developed economies surveyed by the
Economist
—much higher, as we all know, than the interest rates in most of our important regional trading partners.

The simple fact is that Labor is desperately trying to escape culpability for Australia's record $187,000 million of foreign debt. In so doing, it is recklessly and wantonly throwing truth on this matter out of the window. The reality of the situation is that Labor is to blame on this matter. There is a direct connection between Labor's budget deficits and Australia's foreign debt. Every respectable economist in Australia knows that. Every member of the government, if they are honest and prepared to admit it, knows that. Certainly every Australian who has suffered under the bludgeoning of interest rate policy, of falling living standards and of massive economic incompetence throughout this government's term of office knows that all too well. The result is that we have now a situation where we have a foreign debt that is incredibly high by any standards. It is eight times higher than it was when this government came to office and is a major cause of the fundamental problems underlying our economy in the long term.
(Time expired)

talker.name: Senator McMULLAN
talker.role: Minister for Trade)

talk.start.para: —This matter of public importance purports to assert that the government is seeking to cover up the economic situation in Australia today and the economic record of the government. Why would any government want to cover up the fact that it has just concluded a record equalling 16 quarters of continuous economic growth—that is, four years of continued, consistent economic growth—with respected economic commentators, such as Don Stammer from Bain & Co., saying that it is likely to continue for years to come?

para.tab: Why would we want to cover up the fact that economic growth has been averaging four per cent or more over the last three years and is consistently amongst the highest in the OECD, or that employment has grown by 670,000 in just 2 1/2 years? Why would we not want everybody to know that? The opposition is desperately trying to divert attention from these things.

Why would we be concerned to prevent the Australian people from knowing that we have had an increase in labour productivity of 2.5 per cent a year? We have had all this growth while we have had an underlying inflation rate of 2.5 per cent. Why would we not want people to know of the significant improvement in Australia's external competitiveness over the last five years—or over the last decade if you want to measure it over a longer period? Why would we not want people to know that exports have grown by more than 50 per cent—or in real terms by five percentage points of GDP—in the last five years?

When you look at it on balance, there are a lot of things we want the people of Australia to know. What we want is a real choice for the Australian people—a choice between the government's plans and the opposition's plans to deal with the reality of Australia's economic circumstance. What are the competing policies going to be on important issues such as the current account deficit, growth and inflation? If the Australian people knew that, it would allow them to make a judgment.

That is a fundamental issue for all Australians to be concerned about, and it is the issue we should be addressing here. I waited for 10 minutes to hear the slightest glimmer—or perhaps I should say the smallest dribble—from Senator Short about what the opposition's policy to deal with this might be, and I did not hear a word. He did not mention one word about what their policy to deal with this might be. That is a conscious policy of the opposition—the only policy they have is not to let anybody know what their intentions are. It is the only policy that has been made clear up until now.

The opposition have set out to be deliberately misleading about the connection between debt and mortgages. It is true that it is arguable, and there is evidence to suggest linkages between a country's level of overseas debt and its ratings by the international ratings agencies, which might affect interest rates so you have to borrow long-term overseas, although it is not a very direct link. The level of external debt relative to GDP for both New Zealand and Canada is higher than for Australia, but they both have the same rating as us. So it is not a direct relationship. Those countries, which are sometimes used as comparisons with us when it suits the opposition—and they were not mentioned in this debate—have the same rating as us.

The effect is not direct but, when you try to lead with that and follow through to say that this is part of what determines the variable mortgage interest rates that ordinary Australians are borrowing on their homes, you are stretching a very long bow—like the long bow that Senator Short deliberately put in. The opposition is misleading the Australian people with their truck they are taking around—their debt truck they imported to build up our debt.

We have a situation where the opposition tries to assert that, because this debt was overwhelmingly caused by the borrowings of the private sector, we all have a share in it. If that logic follows, it means that somehow or other all Australians have a share in the assets Australia's private sector has built up overseas—so we are all little shareholders in Escondida, the big copper mine in Chile that BHP owns. If we are all partly responsible for the overseas debt of the Australian private sector, it would be equally logical to say that we are all participants in its assets. It is not an argument you ever hear the opposition putting, because there is a significant increase in the assets of Australian companies overseas.

But let us get down to the serious questions about interest rates. Senator Evans in his answer to a question today made clear the situation that was reported only in part—in fact, it was sufficiently reported only in part by Senator Short to be almost deliberately misleading—about what the
Economist
has said about short-term interest rates. Senator Short slipped away from the fact that what the
Economist
magazine said about borrowing costs and real interest rates was that Australia's real interest rates are significantly below the halfway point in the 15 countries it listed for whom it has done an assessment of real interest rates.

All the countries below us on that list have a much lower rate of growth than us. We could perhaps have lower interest rates if we slashed our rate of growth and stopped creating so many jobs. That is not a trade-off that, I think, Australians would advocate, but it is a policy that the opposition are entitled to put forward in a democracy. It is perfectly legitimate. If they want to put that to the Australian people, let us hear them do so.

Australia has been a country with debt since 1788. We have always drawn on overseas capital. The key thing is: can we afford to pay the money back? Our debt servicing ratio—that is, the amount of our exports of goods and services we have to use to fund our debt—has fallen dramatically in recent years. It has fallen to make it clearly a very manageable proposition. It has fallen from 20 per cent to about 11 per cent, and that is a significant improvement caused by a number of factors, including the increase in our exports. We are getting the rate down to manageable proportions, to proportions comparable with those of other economies with which we tend to compare ourselves.

Can we do better? Yes. Do we need to do better? Yes. Is it improving? Clearly, yes, it is. That brings us to the key point. In a democracy approaching an election, is looking back at the past the basis upon which the Australian public can make an informed choice? They want to know what the competing proposals are for the future and what the proposals are to deal with the problem of the current account deficit.

Our strategy has been outlined by me, of course, and more significantly by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and other senior ministers in the government on a number of occasions. It is clearly on the record: to deal with savings through reducing public sector outlays and through superannuation, to deal with efficiency, to deal with industry policy and to deal with, in my own area, the question of trade, the improvement of exports and import competition, opening up new markets and making ourselves more effective in the region. It is a long complicated argument, but in essence those are the four elements of the strategy.

Where is the opposition's strategy to deal with this issue? We did not hear a word of it from Senator Short. You have not heard a word of it from Mr Howard—and you will not, because they do not want the Australian people to have an informed choice because they fear what that informed choice will be. Let us assume that the question of debt is as serious as Senator Short says it is. I think the action is clearly, deliberately misrepresentative.

talk.start.para: —Don't you think it is serious?

—I do not think it is as serious as you have said it is. Whatever you think, when we come to the election it will be the same. Whether they are elected or we are elected, the debt will be the same. The question is: what is the strategy for the next three years? How are we going to deal with that issue? How are we going to get our current account deficit down without driving the economy into the ground and having zero growth?

para.tab:
Anybody can solve the current account deficit by driving the economy into the ground. What we want to do is have a managed strategy to bring the current account deficit down, create jobs and have growth with low inflation—have a strategy in place to do those things. We have set our strategy out. The Australian people might choose an alternative strategy, but they deserve to be offered one.
(Time expired)

talker.name: Senator KERNOT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: —We have heard from the government and the opposition so far, and I think we do need to get a couple of things straight. I think most people would agree that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was wrong to deny categorically that there is any link between interest rates and foreign debt. Of course the two are related—he has said so himself in his more salient moments in 1986, 1989 and 1993.
—Salient or sane?

—Salient. But also I think it is wrong for Mr Howard and the coalition to claim that Australia is going down the proverbial plughole bowed down with foreign debt. The extremes on both sides are misleading.

para.tab: But let us go to that prominent consumer of Australian orange juice, Dr Vince Fitzgerald. He concedes that Australia's foreign debt is high, but Australia after all has been in debt to foreigners for all of its 207 years of white settlement. Dr Fitzgerald goes on to describe our $180 billion net foreign debt as `not unmanageable'. In fact, last year it declined as a percentage of GDP. The proportion of our export income needed to service the debt is lower now than it was five years ago.

But if Australia continues to run a high current account deficit, our foreign debt, in our view, will inevitably rise. The key variable driving this is not so much the cyclical trade balance, but the underlying income deficit; that is, the interest we are paying on our foreign debt and the profits we have to repatriate to foreign investors. That is the reason we think our current account deficit will not be brought under control even as our trade performance improves. It is this income deficit—the interest and profit payments—that ensures that our foreign debt will probably continue to progressively rise over time.

We are being asked in this matter of public importance: is there a direct link between this and interest rates? The Australian Democrats think the news is mixed, but at this point in time mostly negative. As a capital importing country, we need to be able to continue to attract both lenders and investors. The surest way to attract lenders is by offering high interest rates.

As Dr Fitzgerald points out, interest rates on Australian bonds are about two per cent higher than on US bonds, and much of this difference is probably because of the risk premium associated with our interest rates. It is true that this feeds into interest rates on housing, mostly through the fixed term mortgages, which tend to be funded by the banks through longer term bonds.

talk.start.para: —What about the variable mortgage rates, which most Australians pay?

—Yes, that is relevant too, and I am going to come to that in a minute. So our high current account is feeding into these interest rates indirectly. Interest rates, however, on bonds peaked in January and have been falling for most of the year. Interest rates on fixed term mortgages have also been falling over the course of the year. So the news for most of this year has actually been `good', relatively speaking, and has meant lower interest rates rather than higher ones.

para.tab: But I want to add to the debate that the net foreign debt figures tell only half the story. Our foreign debt has stabilised since 1989 largely because of the dramatic increase in foreign equity liabilities. This government has promoted a massive debt for equity swap. Over the past decade the level of foreign investment in Australia has risen from 16 per cent of GDP to over 36 per cent—that is in one decade—and it is still rising. Foreign equity investments are more expensive to service than foreign debt. I have been saying that here for six years, and I think we are going to see some of the predictions we have been making come to reality.

According to the ABS, Australia's net foreign debt liabilities stand at about 16 per cent of GDP, but net foreign debt liabilities stand at about 39.8 per cent. Senator McMullan said that it is getting easier to manage. But if you look at the statistics for servicing the debt, you will see that for every dollar we pay overseas in interest on the debt we are now paying 80c in profits to foreigners. That is a very close gap, I would argue. That means that foreign investment is more than twice as expensive as foreign debt and, unlike debt which is eventually paid out, ownerships and profits stream overseas. This will be eating away at our current account deficit—if not forever—for a long, long time.

The opposition is telling only half the story, in our view, because the servicing of the foreign debt is only about half of the income drain through the current account deficit. The opposition does not want to talk about the other side. I suspect to admit that a laissez-faire approach to foreign investment, which is what we have seen so far from the opposition, is adding to our current account problems would obviously raise questions about why coalition governments have sold off Victorian power stations, the Bank of Western Australia, the Adelaide water supply, Melbourne freeways—all of these things—to foreign interests. It is to put a question mark over the short-termism of the opposition's proposal to sell 49 per cent of Telstra offshore.

Australia does have a chronic national savings problem. That much we know. We have been living with a national savings problem for 207 years by importing money, and that is not new. We do need to reduce public sector indebtedness but not in a climate of crisis. We do not believe we are in a climate of crisis except with respect to the escalating amount of foreign investment in this country and what that means for Australian ownership in the long term.

We do need a debate about the best means of reducing public sector indebtedness—who should pay, where costs should be cut, what taxes might need to rise to pay for these things. So far we have not heard the coalition's contribution to this debate. Where will it spend? Where will it tax? These matters are not on the table. The Australian electorate deserves better than unfounded prime ministerial outbursts of illogic and coalition mutterings of gloom and doom uncluttered by suggestions of how to fix it.

talk.start.para: —This debate is indeed a matter of public interest. It is a matter of public importance because there is not a household in this nation that does not pay the price of the foreign debt which this Labor government has inflicted upon this country. There is not a business in this nation that does not pay the price for foreign debt.

para.tab: As honourable senators on the other side disagree, I need only draw to their attention the fact that every dollar that we pay in interest on our foreign debt is money that leaves our economy. It is money that is not spent at home. It is money that is not being spent in the towns and communities of regional Australia. It is money that is not creating jobs in the powerhouse of this nation. It is the reason why the standard of living of ordinary Australians is lower than it needs to be. The Labor Party is in the process of bankrupting this nation. They are the facts and they are very simple.

If we have the enormous foreign debt that we have at the moment, and if we continue to accumulate it at the rate at which it has been accumulated under this Labor government, this nation cannot survive as a prosperous nation in our region. Twenty-five years ago all that most Australians knew about Asians was what they saw on `Paul Hogan goes to Hong Kong'. Paul Hogan and Strop were sitting on the back of a rickshaw and a little Chinese man was running along in front pulling the rickshaw.

If you go to South-East Asia, you do not find any rickshaws any more. You do not even find any trishaws. The only place you will find trishaws in South-East Asia is in Cairns. It is the Asian tourists who are sitting on the back and it is the Australian kids who are sitting up the front pedalling and pulling them along. That is a sign of the decline of this nation's economic prosperity, and it is directly attributable to the failed economic policies of the people who sit opposite.

It is true, it is incontrovertible, that we, as borrowers of money from banks, be it as people who have mortgages, overdrafts or credit cards, pay more than we need to pay because of the policies of the government. There are three reasons why that is so. The first reason why we pay more is that our foreign lenders ask for what is called a risk premium. In other words, they sit there, look at the economy, look at the current account deficit, which is the amount of money we bleed overseas every year, look at our foreign debt and say, `How likely are these people going to be able to repay next year, or five or 10 years down the track?' The higher you get in debt, the higher the current account deficit, the higher the risk premium.

As Senator Kernot pointed out, the difference between the bond rate applying in the United States and the bond rate applying here is two per cent. Not all of that is risk premium, but you have to ask yourself why it is that it costs us more to borrow here than it costs the United States. It costs more in part because the people who lend us money have less confidence in this country than they have in our competitors. The signals that this government sends overseas damage our economy and make us all pay more for the amount that we borrow from banks.

Banks, after all, merely borrow money from offshore to lend to people in Australia. If a bank has to pay more to borrow overseas, it has to recoup that price. The interest rate that the bank pays is the price of money. To make a profit a bank has to charge a higher price than it itself pays for money. In other words, if banks have to pay more when they go offshore to borrow, we as the people who borrow from banks pay more in turn.

There is a reason why banks have to go offshore to get the money to lend to the Australian population. The reason is that the savings base of this country has been destroyed. The savings base of this country has been annihilated under the mob that sits opposite. When they came to power savings constituted 15 per cent or $1 in $6 of our post-tax income. This year's budget papers showed that savings under Labor are now three per cent or $1 in every $33 of after-tax income.

If there is not a big enough pool of money here at home to finance the requirements of Australian borrowers, then where are our banks going to get the money? Of course they are going to go offshore. Of course they are going to borrow overseas and of course our foreign debt goes up. All Australians are part of the reason for the foreign debt—partly because we borrow from our banks and partly because the government has destroyed the capacity of ordinary Australians to put money in their savings accounts. It is the government's economic policy that has made this happen and it is the government that must be condemned.

Finally, that little pool of funds that does exist is being raped and pillaged by this government, which itself is borrowing $200 billion. Sure, it is not borrowing from overseas; it just happens to borrow the tiny little pool of money that sits around floating in the Australian domestic economy. If the government has its hand in the till, it is obvious there is no room for any of us. It is obvious that, if we want to borrow money to finance business or houses or whatever, the banks that lend the money to us have to go offshore.

Last week the Senate was treated to a foretaste of this debate as a result of a contribution by a Lord Lucan look-alike over there who has promptly done a Lord Lucan and disappeared from the chamber. He has disappeared from the debate. Quite frankly, I do not blame him. He made a fool of himself and he made a fool of this government. The truth is that this nation deserves better than it gets under Labor. This nation deserves a chance to save. This economy deserves a chance to grow instead of being constrained by debt, as it is under the people who sit opposite.

To use an old bush saying, this mob over there could not be trusted to run a choko vine over a chook yard, let alone run the economy of this country. What I say is: it is about time the economic illiterates on the other side sat down. It is about time they accepted the fact that they are culpable for this mess. It is about time Australia was given a chance under a coalition government to grow, to prosper and to, once again, become a successful nation, not just in the region but the world at large.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate on a matter of public importance. There has been a lot of rhetoric about foreign debt and interest rates but we have not had too many facts or figures about what our level of debt is, what it has been over the last few years and how that relates to the interest rates that we have had over the last few years.

para.tab: I will later seek leave to table a certain document—which I was not able to pass to Senator O'Chee because he was speaking—setting out the ratio of net foreign liabilities to our gross domestic product. The jargon becomes a bit wearing at times but this document relates to the ratio of our net foreign debt since June 1987 through to June of this year, quarter by quarter, and compares that with the interest rates quarter by quarter.

Without going into all of the statistics in significant detail, the document shows that our net foreign debt from June of 1987 to June 1995 has increased from 32 per cent to 39.8 per cent. So the net foreign debt over that period has increased. But what has happened to interest rates over that same period?

The opposition argue that the debt has increased, and that is true, but they also argue that that is what has driven up interest rates. In fact, in June 1987, interest rates were 15.5 per cent. Today they are 10.5 per cent; they have come down by a half. Net foreign debt has increased but interest rates have come down by a half during that period. Surely that proves that the relationship the opposition are trying to show between debt and interest rates is a false one; it is a false argument. The opposition are simply wrong on that issue.

Interest rates relate to a number of economic issues, fundamental to which is inflation. Interest rates represent the cost of lending money by the various financial institutions to us who borrow money. I am a borrower, not a lender, I have to say. Interest rates represent a return on money and they closely follow the inflation rate.

talk.start.para: —Haven't you got a bank account?
—Yes, I do.
—Well, you're a lender; you lend to the bank.
—I have a debt and two mortgages.
—That's his private business.

—That is right, and it is irrelevant to the issue before us. I would like to remind the opposition that they have no policies on how to deal with this issue of debt. If they have them, they are keeping them hidden until they launch them during the election campaign. It is the old story: if you tell a lie that is big enough, you can get away with it. We are continuing to get that desperate approach from the opposition.

para.tab: I ask: what is the foreign debt? The federal government directly contributes to just four per cent of the foreign debt. State governments contribute 27 per cent, while 60 per cent of the debt is from the private sector. In other words, when companies want to expand, they borrow money, overseas as well as on the domestic market.

In a capitalist, free enterprise system, those companies go out with asset backing and their profits—or maybe their losses, although they would have trouble borrowing a lot of money if they had significant losses over a long period—and they borrow money. There is nothing wrong with that as long as their asset backing and the strength of the commercial viability of their businesses back up that borrowing. The government does not control that. That is the private sector's business, it is not the Commonwealth government's business.

As I said earlier, the federal government is directly responsible for just four per cent, or $4 out of every $100, of Australia's debt. Private business, with its own asset backing and its own business strength, is responsible for 60 per cent of that debt.

The other important point about debt is whether it is sustainable. Most of us borrow money at some time or another. We have to be able to sustain that debt through our income level. We also have to have asset backing on that debt. The critical point is that while our debt has gone up, the economy has also grown. In fact, the economy has grown at a faster rate than the debt of the country. The critical question is: can we support the debt levels that we have today? The answer is: we can. But John Howard, the recycled opposition leader, has no policies until election time, particularly on this critical issue.

The best way of understanding the size of the foreign debt is to compare it to the size of the economy. Since September 1993, the size of foreign debt relative to the size of the economy has decreased. In other words, the economy has increased faster than the debt. We are in a better position today to finance foreign debt than at any other time in our recent past.

Debt is not a bad thing as long as you can support the debt, as long as you can repay it, so long as the borrowings are going into the economy and producing productive investment, producing jobs. Look at our record on that score over the last few years: 16 quarters of economic growth. We have greater economic growth than most comparable countries. Senator O'Chee is grand on rhetoric in debate but there was not too much fact or substance. Even though our debt has increased, it is sustainable, as the facts show. We have had consistent economic growth—

talk.start.para: —What about imports?

—Imports are not necessarily a bad thing provided we are exporting as well, and we are. I know the position of the Greens. If they had their way, they would cut the Australian economy off from the world and would not allow imports in. But if you want to export, you have to allow imports. Theirs is just not a sustainable position.

para.tab: I do not like using economic jargon but, using the terminology, the debt service ratio peaked in June 1990. Five years ago was the worst point for us in respect of debt. In June of 1990, the debt service ratio was 20.6 per cent. Since then it has declined substantially—because, as the economy has grown, debt has grown—but the economy has grown faster and our debt service ratio now stands at 11.4 per cent. So our ability to repay the debt has improved significantly in recent years.

There is still more to be done—we do not deny that there is a problem—but the important thing is the size of the problem and how we deal with it. The opposition say that there is a problem when you connect interest rates to debt. That is palpably not true, as the figures I have referred to show. When you ask the opposition what their solution to the problem is, they say, `Wait till election time and we might show you something.'

One of the critical issues is exports. I do not have time to go into that in detail today. The other is savings, so that we do not have to borrow so much from overseas. Generally, Australians are not good savers. Part of tackling that problem is national superannuation. Most comparable countries have national superannuation and we have also put it in place. What does the opposition have? It is all very well to complain about a non-existent problem but they have non-existent policies. I would like to finish by tabling the document to which I referred.
