talk.start.para:
—This debate simply revolves around credibility. Who do you believe? Do you believe Mr Keating, who has failed to live up to almost every promise he has made? Do you believe Mr Willis, who just does not know, and this raggle-taggle collection of fibbers on the other side, who certainly won the last election by telling straightforward untruths about what they were not going to do? Do you believe the experts, including Mr Keating's former adviser on this very matter, Dr FitzGerald, or do you believe the other experts who have come into this debate, such as Mr Alan Wood? Do you believe the Treasury itself and what it has in its own
Economic Roundup
, or the Reserve Bank? Who do you believe?

para.tab: The people who have demonstrated their words cannot be taken seriously, who have demonstrated their words are absolutely worthless, are saying not just that there is very little relationship, but that there is no relationship whatsoever between the balance of payments disaster and interest rates. That is just a disgrace. It is self-evidently wrong, and is yet the latest attempt by this government in its sea of dishonesty to try to obscure the simple facts which exist.

We have already heard from Dr FitzGerald, who was a former deputy secretary of the finance department and who has a distinguished Public Service career, and whom Mr Keating has personally abused because he does not kowtow to Mr Keating or pull his forelock—probably because Mr Keating's forelock is fast disappearing. Dr FitzGerald has accused the government of being the major source of our debt and national savings problem—and that, of course, is exactly right. As the latest
Economic Roundup
says:

speech.para: Net foreign debt as a proportion of GDP—
and this might interest Senator Sherry, who obviously did not know—
increased from less than 10 per cent in the latter part of the 1970s—
that is when John Howard was the Treasurer—
to a peak of 43 per cent in September 1993 before declining to 37 per cent at December 1994.

At the same time, Australian investment abroad has also gone up, but overseas borrowings were used to fund most of Australian equity investment abroad. So there is no doubt that foreign debt has created a major problem for Australia—a factor which influences interest rates. It is not the only determining factor—we have never said so—but it influences interest rates and is a factor in what is happening in the market. This is what the Treasury says in its latest winter 1995
Economic Roundup
:
. . . a high level of foreign borrowing relative to GDP can impose costs on an economy by making it more vulnerable to external shocks and by raising interest rate premia on borrowings.

That is exactly what the Treasury says; it is not what the Treasurer (Mr Willis) says. It was, in fact, what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said before he suddenly realised that what he said was not politically useful and so pretended he had never said it. This is what the Treasury says and what we say:
Many factors can influence the international financial markets' assessment of the overall sustainability of a country's external liabilities or current account deficit.

Foreigners are lending us money every month to the tune of up to $3 billion for one simple reason: we are not exporting enough—or else we are importing too much—to pay our bills, including our massive interest rate on the huge amounts of money we keep borrowing every month just to pay the bill.

para.tab: It is absolute nonsense for the government to run around saying, `Oh, but that money is borrowed by the BHPs and so on of this world.' The fact is that the great bulk of this money is transferred in the foreign exchange markets, particularly to financial intermediaries. Who borrows from financial intermediaries in terms of short-term government securities? The government itself. It is hidden. So people like Senator Sherry, who know nothing about economics and marketplaces, do not realise, as Dr FitzGerald does, that this hidden foreign investment in the government is of massive proportions.

It is in the
Australian
today, if Senator Sherry has the capacity to read it—sorry, to understand it. I presume he can read it, but he has to have the capacity to understand it. Dr FitzGerald says this:

speech.para: Because the Commonwealth has recently been issuing its debt securities domestically, it may seem to be responsible for only a minor part of the debt. Roughly half the debt that is counted as private includes amounts raised by banks to be on-lent to others.
He makes this conclusion:
Yet it makes no material difference whether the government issues debt securities directly to foreigners or receives funds from them indirectly through a bank.

Let that be some sort of major lesson in reality to the people who keep talking about this alleged four per cent government foreign debt. That is nonsense. Apart from anything else, the total government foreign debt is something like $110 billion out of $180 billion total net debt, and I compare it to net debt because the government does not have much of a net position.

para.tab: So here we have the government, a massive borrower, involved very heavily in having an interest rate policy which has failed. We have this extraordinary situation, despite what Senator Sherry has said, where you have had these increases in the last 12 months: bank housing rates up by 1.75 per cent; bank prime rate up 1.75 per cent; and overnight cash rate up 2.75 per cent. What happened to the balance of payments? Over the latest year, it is up from $17 billion to $27 billion—all obviously just a terrible coincidence, according to Senator Sherry.

Sure, there are other factors that influence rates and, sure, there are times when short-term rates move in different directions to long-term rates, but that is because of people's expectations about the future interest rate movements, particularly our balance of payments problem and what is going to happen to it, interest rates in general and inflation.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —One would think that the opposition had found a new element in the economy—risk premiums and interest rates. It has been with us for over 200 years. The Australian community has always been an importer of capital, since the days in 1788 when the First Fleet sailed into Botany Bay. They were financed by imported capital. True, there were times when for a short period our current account was in surplus—that is, merchandise trade balance—when the wool boom was on in the 1950s and possibly for a very short time in the 1970s.

para.tab: The net flow of capital has been with us for more than 200 years. Invisibles have always been a drain on the current account—that is, transport costs from overseas and insurance. This net inflow occurred even though in the past we have had high trade barriers, tariffs, and prohibition on imports—sugar for instance. This occurred when the colonies were governed by conservative politicians carrying out the United Kingdom generated laws and regulations and, later, locally generated and enforced laws and regulations.

Since federation, as the opposition so often have pointed out, for most of our parliamentary history, conservative governments of their ilk have been in power. During those years, it was a case of so many lost opportunities. Since 1983, this Labor government has challenged the contemporary thinking of the Australian economy in the areas of industrial relations; legislation about business practices; management practices; the reduction of tariffs and, in some cases, the removal; and the lifting of the embargo on sugar imports. All of these actions and others carried with them the likelihood of current account problems.

Is the opposition suggesting that this should not have been done? Do you suggest that we should not have done those things? What would they have done? I certainly have not heard a description of what they would have done. I have not even heard what they would do now, even though they are so critical. What would the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) have done? Would he have kept the high tariffs in place? Would he now repudiate the wage and incomes accord, which is recognised to have helped keep wages stable and inflation low? To create a balance in the current account, would he reintroduce a regulated Australian dollar, establish new tariffs, increase the ones that we have now and take other steps to restrict capital flowing to Australia? What make us a country that is unattractive for capital to be invested, to prevent Australians from purchasing imports, capital goods, merchandise and services? If the Leader of the Opposition took such steps, he would be a mean-spirited hypocrite, as would those who would support him in such a proposition.

If this is not the intention of those on the other side of the chamber, what are their intentions? We on this side have opened up the Australian economy. We have joined the world economy; we have sown the seeds of a bountiful harvest for the years ahead. I ask the opposition: what have you got to offer?

talk.start.para: —One of the small advantages of being a minor party is you often get to have the last word in a matter of public importance. I want to put on record some basic points that have seldom been mentioned in this debate. Yes, debt levels are rising and this is a problem. Australia's debt is not the same as government deficit. The twin deficit theory was debunked in the late 1980s. The majority of national debt, as has been mentioned, is private sector generated. Senator Sherry mentioned a figure of around 60 per cent, and that has been the case for some time, but deregulation of the financial sector in Australia has made it very difficult for government to have much impact on this.

para.tab: We deregulated our financial sector in the 1980s as a precursor to preparing for the Uruguay Round of GATT. When did we ever assess what the impact of various levels of financial deregulation would be? What we have to ask now is: who is running the financial markets, who is running Australia's financial sector, and what level of control over such things as interest rates does the international money market have? When we answer these questions I think we then begin to see that as a precursor to the Uruguay Round of GATT we have now linked up to a new, very substantially changed trade regime which, despite any changes that may have occurred anyway, has pushed us to change our domestic economy vastly and made us vastly more vulnerable to international money markets and international resource markets, which can change.

People are speculating on resources as never before, and there is this huge link-up to casino capitalism in Australia and elsewhere. I point out to those people who think that compulsory superannuation is the trick that it also links us to the new international casino capitalism. Those seem to be the kinds of questions that are not being asked: how vulnerable have we become, and how have we never sat back and worked out at what level Australia still has some say?

Today the government seems to have been giving us arguments that we can use our exports to trade ourselves out of trouble. But we can look at that only if we forget about the fact that we quite clearly, over more than one year, have been running balance of trade deficits. The situation is getting worse—about $2 billion a month, which is far more than the government ever said we were likely to make in five years time as a result of us getting into this new international trade regime under the Uruguay Round of GATT.

How the heck do we trade ourselves out of a growing current account deficit when our level of trade on imports is greater and growing in relation to our exports? Just how much beef can we produce? Just how many woodchips can we make out of our precious old-growth forests? Just how can we trade ourselves out of this situation in the way we are when we are not seeing the connections between our financial sectors, our trade and our lack of industry policy? When we have higher interest rates, it makes it more attractive to borrow overseas and more attractive for overseas investors to lend here. Higher interest rates and low wages mean less disposable household and small business incomes.

debate.sub1.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee: Joint

speech.speaker: West Sen S.M.

talk.start.para: —I present the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the visit of the defence subcommittee to Exercise Kangaroo 95 between 8 and 11 August 1995 and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

para.tab: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

para.tab: That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.para:
On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the report that is entitled
Report on the visit of the defence sub-committee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to Exercise Kangaroo 95, 8—11 August 1995
. At the invitation of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), the defence subcommittee attended Exercise Kangaroo 95 between the dates I have just given.

para.tab: Kangaroo 95 was the major Australian Defence Force combined and joint exercise for 1995. The exercise concept involved the further testing of Australia's strategy of defence in depth by exercising elements of the Australian Defence Force in northern Australia in a short warning conflict scenario. It was designed to emphasise the joint nature of operations at the operational and tactical levels of war and to further develop the procedures required for civil-military cooperation during short warning conflict in the defence of Australia.

The enemy forces in the exercise were drawn from the fictitious island nation of Orangeland. Under the exercise scenario, Orangeland mounted `Operation Trojan Horse' against Australia in order to obtain their rightful share of the region's non-renewable energy resources. This was a high profile, special operations group operation under the command of Headquarters 2nd Division, supplemented by elements from the Royal Australian Navy, army and Royal Australian Air Force. At the height of the operation, the effective strength of the Orangeland forces was approximately 1,625.

Kangaroo 95 ran for over seven months, from mid-January to the end of August 1995, and was perhaps the longest and most complex exercise ever undertaken by the Australian Defence Force. The area of operations spanned a land area from Derby in the west to Cairns in the east, traversing three state/territory jurisdictions and encompassing large areas of international and territorial waters.

Defence elements of seven nations were involved in Kangaroo 95 in varying degrees, with foreign contingents being from the United States, United Kingdom, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore and Papua New Guinea. Some 18,000 navy, army and air force personnel were involved with around 16 ships and 110 aircraft. Direct expenditure is expected to be in the order of some $64 million.

The subcommittee's visit commenced at HMAS Cairns with a briefing on the operations of the base, despite it being outside the area of operations. The subcommittee was flown by a RAAF HS748B to Weipa where 2 Royal Australian Regiment, 51 Far North Queensland Regiment, 10 Joint Force Support Unit and the Navy Mine Clearance Unit were deployed. We visited the Comalco bauxite mine, a key defence priority in the Weipa area, and observed amphibious operations on board HMAS Tobruk. I would have to say that trying to maintain defence and protection for the Comalco mine at Weipa is a monumental task and it was very interesting to see the large area that has to be covered.

The subcommittee then flew to Darwin for a briefing on the objectives and overall progress of the exercise, followed by a visit to headquarters northern command, the joint headquarters of the Australian Defence Force in the area of operations. At the invitation of the Honourable Mr Gary Punch MP, Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, we also attended the Official Opening of the Defence Force Careers Reference Centre in Darwin. The final leg of our visit was to the Orangeland headquarters in Nabarlek.

The visit, though brief, impressed upon the subcommittee the significant impact that a well-armed and organised aggressor could inflict in northern Australia, as well as some of the fundamental difficulties faced by the Australian Defence Force in operating in the north. These difficulties range from severe climatic conditions to the sheer enormity of northern Australia and the wide variety of terrain in which the Australian Defence Force must operate. Members certainly appreciated the difficulties encountered in moving troops and supplies in such conditions.

The subcommittee met a diverse cross-section of uniformed personnel from the three services on its visit to Kangaroo 95. The subcommittee was able to hear of some personnel problems in the Australian Defence Force, including problems caused by repeated separation within service families. In particular, the subcommittee was advised that stress and family-related problems exist in the 51 Far North Queensland Regiment due to insufficient manning levels in the regiment's Q stores. The subcommittee recommends that the effectiveness of present arrangements be investigated to determine whether additional Australian Regular Army personnel should be recruited to support the 51 FNQR Q stores.

The subcommittee was told that the presence of service personnel in northern Queensland had resulted in a number of marijuana finds. While this is to be commended, the subcommittee was concerned about the lack of an Australian Federal Police presence north of Cairns. Currently, the 51 Far North Queensland Regiment conducts significant surveillance work on behalf of Commonwealth agencies such as the Australian Federal Police, AQIS, Customs and Immigration. The location of some of these Commonwealth agencies in the far north Queensland area would not only assist 51 FNQR's operations but would also enhance the level of protection and service in this remote area. Consequently, the subcommittee recommends that an Australian Federal Police presence be established on Thursday Island.

The opportunity to observe amphibious operations on board HMAS
Tobruk
was an important aspect of the subcommittee's visit. The subcommittee had some concerns about the impact of the decision to proceed with the paying off of HMAS
Tobruk
on the amphibious capability of the Royal Australian Navy. HMAS
Tobruk
is to be replaced by two training helicopter support ships, HMAS
Kanimbla
and HMAS
Manoora
, which were acquired from the United States Navy. Both of these replacement vessels are about 10 years older than HMAS
Tobruk
. The subcommittee is more inclined to the view that HMAS
Tobruk
should be retained.

Exercise Kangaroo 95 provided the Australian Defence Force with the opportunity to test command and control structures in joint operations in northern Australia. The subcommittee was told that the strategic planning for Kangaroo 95 identified the need for a lead joint commander. This resulted in the appointment of the air commander as the lead joint commander prior to the start of the exercise. In this capacity, the air commander was responsible to HQADF for achieving the exercise objectives.

Commander northern command, the joint commander of specified navy, army and air force units in the area of operations, reported to the lead joint commander in the event that he wished to utilise units outside of his direct control. However, the commander flotillas, commander of the Amphibious Task Group in the area of operations, did not report to the commander northern command but to the maritime commander who in turn reported directly to the lead joint commander. The subcommittee considers this command and control structure to be particularly unwieldy. Its inadequacies were demonstrated by the inability of the Australian Defence Force to co-ordinate reaction to exercise events in the Torres Strait. This points to the advantage of a single command and control structure incorporating one joint commander in the area of operations.

The subcommittee's visit to Kangaroo 95 also highlighted the lack of air mobility in the army, especially given the recent grounding of the Nomad aircraft and problems with the Black Hawk helicopters. The lack of airborne and early warning control aircraft was also a concern as some penetrations of Australia's airspace by Orangeland forces went undetected.

The subcommittee was impressed by the Australian Defence Force's high level of awareness of the environment and the hazardous tropical conditions of the area of operations. Examples included the presence of non-camouflaged portaloos, the issue of bush hats to subcommittee members, the advice received to drink water at regular intervals and the precautions taken to ensure that water was carried at all times. Moreover, an environmental awareness and health handbook had been prepared which recognised that the unique environment, fragile infrastructure and sensitive heritage areas of northern Australia require careful protection in both the defence and environmental contexts.

The subcommittee was informed that all landholders, including indigenous landowners, in the area of operations had been consulted by the ADF. This resulted in some areas being declared off limits to the exercise due to tribal, environmental or other concerns. Overall, the general response to the exercise from landholders and the northern Australia community was very positive.

Another pleasing aspect of the subcommittee's visit was the strong integration of women into the Australian Defence Force and the demonstrable recognition of the positive role they played in the exercise. Indeed, throughout the visit we were highly impressed by the professionalism, dedication and enthusiasm of the members of the Australian Defence Force, including members of the Reserves, for the tasks and responsibilities which were entrusted to them. The subcommittee looks forward to a full briefing on the outcomes of Kangaroo 95 and the report of the Australian Defence Force on its own debriefing on the exercise.

Before I conclude, I say that there is a dissenting report from one senator. We find that to be most regrettable. This report is a report of our visit, the commentary, the information provided to us and what we observed while we were there. To comment on protests and other things that may have taken place before and after our arrival and about which we were given no information I think is a little bit beyond the realms of what this committee report was supposed to encompass.

In conclusion, I publicly express our appreciation for the opportunity to attend Exercise Kangaroo 95 and for the efforts of those who contributed to the success of our visit. I commend the report to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —I also take this opportunity to refer to the visit of the defence subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to Exercise Kangaroo 95 this year in August. Whilst I am not a member of that committee, nor part of that particular delegation, I am certainly aware that a number of my opposition colleagues actually participated in that particular exercise. They were: the Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair, Senator David Brownhill, Mr David Hawker, Mr Noel Hicks, and Mr Lou Lieberman.

para.tab: I had the good fortune to follow very much in the footsteps of this particular visit with my opposition colleague the member for Groom, Mr Bill Taylor, and staff members from the office of the Leader of the Opposition and the office of the shadow minister for defence, Senator Jocelyn Newman.

I certainly commend this report. It certainly picks up those issues that relate to the Northern Territory aspect with which I am familiar and which my own visit to Kangaroo 95 highlighted. Mr Taylor and I certainly appreciated the generosity of the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, and also the members of the defence force who not only entertained us and extended considerable hospitality but also gave us very comprehensive and detailed briefings.

In fact, our particular visit, which dovetailed, as I mentioned before, with many of these other issues, involved particular briefings at exercise control in Darwin and also at Tindal with the 322 air base wing. That also occurred at Nabarlek in the field with the Orange forces—if you like, the enemy—where we were certainly briefed by General McGrath and his officers, and then back in Darwin where we visited the new Robertson Barracks, where there was a command post exercise being conducted with Singaporean and Malaysian troops. We were also given a Norcom briefing and an intelligence briefing in Darwin.

Our visit extended over some four days and was very comprehensive. I know that my colleague Mr Taylor, because of knowledge he gained as a former senior naval officer, had a number of criticisms with regard to the area. He certainly made those comments well known and they are borne out in this particular report.

From my own point of view, being a senator for the Northern Territory, I can certainly comment on the validity and the value of exercise Kangaroo 95 for this particular year. As Senator West has mentioned, over 17,000 troops participated in the exercise. That participation included not only the efforts of Australian nationals but also the cooperative efforts, in various aspects of the exercise, of troops from the United States, Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore. All participation was invaluable, and I am sure that all participants learned very special lessons from that particular exercise.

In the conduct of an exercise such as this there is a commercial advantage to regions like the Northern Territory and North Queensland; I think from memory the cost of putting it on exceeded some $65 million. The value that then has to be measured to the Australian Defence forces is one that is naturally vitally important.

It is important that on this occasion we had the participation of troops from Indonesia, Singapore and Malaysia. It is only by developing these very special relationships of good neighbourliness with our near neighbours that we are able to secure the future not only in the immediate term but also for the long term. I look forward to seeing the final reports of this particular exercise—and I am sure that there will be many lessons learned from it.

From my own point of view, I was certainly vastly impressed with the use of modern technology by the military in this particular exercise. More particularly, I was fascinated at the use of computer equipment and communications equipment which was far beyond the scope of anything previously appreciated by me as existing and being available to Australia; I am certain that in the development of those areas this technology is important.

Similarly, by staging an exercise such as this in northern Australia, there are important implications for the fields of development of both education and health services. The conduct of an exercise such as this in tropical north Australia poses many problems for Defence, and I am sure that there will be many lessons learned from that aspect of the exercise. The area of education, of course, has wider implications for people who live in northern Australia.

As a result of what I saw on this exercise, I have proposed that there ought to be a much closer working relationship between the Australian Defence Force Academy here in Canberra and the various tertiary courses that are available through the military—whether they be in military studies; intelligence areas; health related fields, particularly tropical medicine; or in the provision of tertiary studies to so many of the members of the Australian Defence forces who will be located in northern Australia.

I am very pleased that already the comments I made at the time of the exercise have met with a warm response from senior Defence officers who have been to see me. I have been consulted by the Australian Defence Force Academy, and the Northern Territory University has expressed quite considerable interest in the various opportunities that arise in this area.

I can certainly see the immediate results of exercise Kangaroo 95—as they existed within the community with regard to the improvement of relationships between the Defence Force and the wider Australian community on the ground; the involvement of so many Aboriginal participants, not only in the military but also in cooperative arrangements with this particular exercise; and those opportunities that I have mentioned which will now naturally flow to defence, health, education and other government agencies.

talk.start.para: —I was a member of the committee group that travelled to northern Australia to witness Kangaroo 95, or aspects of it. At this stage I would express my thanks to Lieutenant Colonel Mark Lippeatt who was our escorting officer. If not for the work of Mark Lippeatt, we may well have missed most of Kangaroo 95 inasmuch as when we went to Cairns we found that the exercise was not there.

para.tab: Originally, we were to go to Thursday Island but, due to an aircraft accident and the fact that the war games had moved on from that point, we were to move to Weipa instead. But there had been no arrangement for us to be briefed on the overall arrangement involved with Kangaroo 95. That would have meant we would have gone all the way to Darwin—that is, the last one-third of our observation of Kangaroo 95—without understanding what it was we were looking at in terms of the rationale of how it was organised. That was unfortunate and, as I say, thanks go to Mark Lippeatt for his efforts there in perhaps turning around an otherwise pointless two-thirds of our trip.

It has been mentioned that there is a dissenting report—and the dissenting report is mine. Members of the committee would be, and could be, in little doubt that I have a different viewpoint to theirs in relation to Australia's military involvement with some overseas forces that have been involved with human rights abuses in their own countries. I believe that just about every other speaker in the House of Representatives has taken the opportunity to have a go at me in relation to writing the dissenting report. Senator West has mentioned that she believes we should have put in the report only what we observed. I am just wondering how much it takes before people really do see; what does it take?

Clearly, in surveys over half the Australian population has indicated that they are concerned about Indonesia's occupation of East Timor, and Australia's part in recognising Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor and largely ignoring the human rights abuses that are occurring there. That huge level of public concern, of course, is impacted by such things as the inviting of an elite force from Indonesia—a force which has been known to be involved with East Timorese human rights abuses—to be part of a major Australian Defence military exercise. What does it take for a Defence subcommittee to see that actions by Australian Defence upset a number of people in the Australian public?

It has been mentioned that there were demonstrations in Darwin—and, yes, none of the other committee members attended those demonstrations. I was invited to attend the demonstrations by the organisers, but it has been suggested by some members of the committee that I may have been the cause of them. Oh, to have that much power!

The level of community concern exists. There is a large population—or relatively large, for its number—of East Timorese in Darwin. We are talking about people who have witnessed members of their families disappearing, being taken away or killed in front of their eyes. To suggest that I or any other individual would be responsible for that level of concern and outrage at Australia's military involvement in terms of the Kangaroo 95 exercise is bizarre. To suggest that those pieces of information given to us by the Australian military during those exercises are the only ones relevant to be mentioned in a report of Kangaroo 95 is also bizarre.

I wonder how many members of the defence committee have ever spoken or accepted invitations to speak with representatives of the peace, social justice and aid groups who are concerned about exercises like Kangaroo 95? If the message is, `They did not hear about it, therefore it does not exist,' then perhaps the aid groups, social justice groups, human rights groups, peace groups and community groups in and around Darwin should make sure that they put their information and their concerns to committees like the defence committee. They should not just assume they are going to ignore it. They should make sure those members of the committee receive information about the concerns because then they will have no excuse whatsoever to say that those levels of concerns do not exist.

We can have 10,000 people in the streets in Western Australia protesting about woodchips and there will still be people who say, `This is just a minority.' The number of people protesting in the streets or asked what they think about a particular issue does not necessarily relate to the level of concern; yet we appear to be blinkered on this. If I am a member of a committee and I have a differing viewpoint from the majority of the committee, does that mean my views are not relevant and should not be mentioned in the report? I believe I am representing a substantial number of people in the community—people who otherwise, in a committee such as the defence committee, would not get a voice.

Of those people, nearly everybody mentioned the fact that they knew I was involved in a demonstration outside Larrakeyah Barracks. That is true. But the fact that they knew I was involved in a demonstration with those groups of people who invited me to participate indicates that they did hear about the level of community concern. The fact that they complained that I went along to the demonstration obviously is proof that they did know there was community support; yet, even though it was mentioned in the local newspaper—and the national media, as far as I could see—they chose to close their eyes to that, to pretend that did not exist and to mention only those levels of community participation and support for the exercise that they were advised to by the military.

Obviously during such an observation of a military exercise we do not have a number of people from a number of different community sectors invited to the exercise to give their opinions about how they feel about that. It is not like a normal hearing.

What we do know from the EPAC survey earlier this year before the budget is that a number of people in Australia are suggesting that the level of expenditure on defence could be cut relative to areas they think are more important, such as the environment. That is what the community says on a number of issues. Is the amount of money we spend on an exercise like Kangaroo 95 justified? On what basis is it justified? Those are the kinds of questions asked by the majority of the community.

The fact they are not highly advised on the details of military exercises and so on would indicate that it is often quite difficult to get information about that. I know, because I am on the defence committee and I cannot get as much information about much of what Defence is spending than most people in the defence industry. That is the reality in Australia.

Those levels of community concern exist. They are concerned about what we are spending, how we are spending it and how defence policy interacts and does not interact with other areas such as foreign affairs and human rights. I do not believe you have a leg to stand on if you say, `If I mention human rights abuses, it has nothing to do with defence.' If defence policies are seen or perceived to be giving the wrong signal in terms of human rights, then there is a link with defence and therefore we have the right—in fact, I feel obliged—to mention those issues when it comes to talking about such things as Australia's organisation of a major military exercise like Kangaroo 95.

talk.start.para: —I have been inspired to rise and to speak in this debate and certainly to support Senator Margetts, at least from one point of view—that is, to uphold the right of Senator Margetts to make a dissenting report. In fact I thank her for doing so because I believe that is a very important role, particularly in debates about defence. It is so difficult in this nation to really get any alternative opinions on this area of our life. The problem is the government and the major opposition are so often totally in agreement about their support for the defence forces that they cannot see there is a large body of opinion in this nation which has another point of view. I support Senator Margetts in her remarks and I certainly support her right to make a dissenting report.

para.tab: It is important to underline the total confusion of the military, the government and the opposition in understanding the dissent to the direction that our military forces so often take. I remember that in Kangaroo 89 I was part of a protest. I was spat at by military people and I was attacked by them. Interestingly enough, a number of them said things like, `Kangaroo 89 ensures your right to disagree, but if we had our way we'd stop your protest.' That is the kind of confusion people have when others want to dissent about such operations.

I also support Senator Margetts in her comments about the involvement of the Indonesian military. I believe that to have been an appalling decision and I reject as rubbish—I hate to say this about my friend Senator Tambling—his comment that this enhances good neighbourliness. I believe Australians are appalled at the proposition that the Australian army should train Indonesian soldiers to murder and oppress their own people. I congratulate Gary Gibson, who is in the House of Representatives, for moving a private member's bill to prevent Australian involvement with military forces of nations whose own forces are involved in human rights abuses against their own citizens.

Let me underline that by saying that defence forces around the world overwhelmingly are being used these days not against external threats but against their own citizens. In nation after nation that is what is happening. I have just been speaking with some people from Guatemala whose experience is exactly that. The terrible situation in that country has been reinforced by the role of the military of that country. In nation after nation the situation is that defence forces are not used to defend countries against external threat but used to oppress their own people. It is about time we recognised that.

speech.para: This bill amends the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989 to provide an appropriation of $83,636,000 for the 1996 calendar year.

The act appropriates funding for the Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program through which the Commonwealth provides supplementary funding to State and Territory Governments, non-government school systems and education institutions, and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education consultative bodies to advance the education of indigenous people.
Funding under the act is appropriated on a triennial calendar year basis, with the current triennium due to finish at the end of 1995.

The Government intends to make major changes to the Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program from January 1997, with a new funding triennium to commence at that time. Those changes will provide for a more equitable basis for the distribution of funds on a per capita basis and new accountability arrangements that focus on achieving improved educational outcomes for indigenous people.
To allow time to implement these substantial changes, 1996 will be used as a transitional period. Funding at existing levels is therefore required for the 1996 calendar year.

This bill is an important element of the government's long-term strategy to improve education opportunities and outcomes for Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders. It is therefore timely to review that strategy.

In 1989, under Commonwealth leadership, the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy was agreed by all governments. It provides a shared framework to the year 2001 for collaborative strategies to achieve equity of educational opportunity and outcomes for indigenous people.

Many factors contribute to educational disadvantage for indigenous people. Education systems may not adequately accommodate students' cultural backgrounds. People in remote communities can have limited access to quality educational facilities and teachers. Many indigenous children have special learning needs because English is not their first language. Poverty limits the ability of many indigenous people to participate in education.

In late 1993 the Commonwealth appointed an independent Reference Group to examine the effectiveness of strategies developed in the first triennium of the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy. This National Review of Education for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples reported in late 1994 that there had been broadly based improvements in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education since the policy was implemented. For example, between 1989 and 1993 the percentage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students staying on to Year 12 of school increased from 14% to about 33%. During the same period, the number of indigenous people attending university doubled.

However, the National Review also found that, despite these encouraging improvements, indigenous people remain the most educationally disadvantaged group in Australia. From preschool to higher education, Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders participate and attain significantly less in education than the rest of the community. For example, at primary school level, three times as many indigenous students have literacy and numeracy problems as do other primary students. Although the proportion of indigenous students studying to Year 12 has, as I have indicated, increased significantly in recent years, it is still less than half the rate for Australian students as a whole.
Such continuing disadvantage is unacceptable and requires action from all governments. This government has taken the lead to accelerate efforts to achieve educational equity for indigenous people.

Sponsored by the Commonwealth, the Ministerial Council on Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (MCEETYA) agreed in November 1994 to establish a taskforce to develop a national strategy to improve indigenous education outcomes. This taskforce will make its final report to State, Territory and Commonwealth Ministers later this year on the proposed strategy, which will include action on those National Review recommendations that are directed to State and Territory governments.

I am pleased to report that at the May 1995 MCEETYA meeting, State and Territory Ministers reaffirmed their commitment to the goals of the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy, and acknowledged the need for more effort to achieve equity in educational outcomes for indigenous Australians by the turn of the century.

My colleague, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Simon Crean has already arranged bilateral discussions with each State and Territory to translate this acknowledgment of need into increased practical effort. Once specific financial arrangements have been agreed, the Commonwealth will formally respond to the National Review.

The Commonwealth has already foreshadowed, in the recent Budget, its willingness to increase substantially its funding support over the next four years, as part of our response to the National Review, contingent upon States and Territories also increasing their effort.
That extra Commonwealth funding would be directed to priority areas across the range of programs through which this government fulfils its commitments to indigenous education.

ABSTUDY provides means-tested income support and other financial assistance to enable students to complete secondary education and progress to tertiary education. In 1994, Commonwealth funding of $114 million assisted some 44,000 students.

The Aboriginal Education Direct Assistance Program provides tutorial and vocational guidance support for, and encourages parental involvement in, students' education. Indigenous students needing special assistance can be individually tutored or attend centres that provide assistance in completing homework assignments. School-based parent committees are supported to participate in educational decision-making and to undertake activities that encourage indigenous students to engage in schooling. The program also funds activities to help indigenous students make informed choices about future education and career options. Over $49 million has been appropriated for this program in 1995/96.

Support funding for Higher Education institutions contributes to strategies to increase indigenous people's tertiary education participation and attainment. Over $14.5 million was provided for this purpose in 1994.

The Aboriginal Education Strategic Initiatives Program (AESIP), which is funded by this act, assists education providers to meet the specific needs of indigenous students at the institutional level. It supports initiatives such as the development of culturally appropriate curricula and the employment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education workers who provide a supportive role model for indigenous students and act as a link between the family, the community and the school. Over $83 million is provided by the Commonwealth for this program each year.

As I indicated at the outset of this speech, this bill provides for the continued operation of AESIP during the 1996 transitional year. Further legislation will be introduced next year to implement the changes to the program for the 1997-1999 triennium that are being developed as part of the Commonwealth's response to the National Review.

This bill also transfers $0.54 million per year from 1 July 1995 from this appropriation to the Department of Communications and the Arts to part-fund the establishment of the National Institute of Indigenous Performing Arts Training. This honours a commitment in the 1994
Creative Nation
Statement to the preservation and promotion of indigenous cultures. As funding for the new Institute is being provided from July 1995, the AESIP appropriation for 1995 is reduced by $0.27 million.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

speech.para: The purpose of this bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 (the act) to implement decisions made by the government in respect of higher education and to make minor policy and technical changes.

The bill's provisions amend section 17 of the act to adjust funding for operating grants to reflect the major research facilities program and to provide supplementation for 1994, 1995 and 1996 price movements. Supplementation for price movements is also provided for superannuation expenses, teaching hospitals and special capital projects.

The various provisions of the bill should be seen in the context of the government's overall policy directions for higher education. In particular, as confirmed in the recent budget, the government remains committed to a large, accessible, diverse and innovative system of publicly funded higher education. This bill underpins that objective by, for example, providing new and additional support for innovations in open learning and educational technology, enhancing the opportunities for universities to offer student places funded jointly with industry, and improving the detailed operations of the higher education contribution scheme.

The bill makes substantial improvements to the open learning initiative. The two main elements of the open learning initiative are the Open Learning Agency of Australia (OLAA), an independent open learning organisation, and the development of an open learning electronic support service (Open Net). In addition to rolling over unused funding from 1994-95 to 1995-96, the amendment to the act will provide for the extension of the open learning initiative.

Open Net provides teaching and learning assistance to enrolled students of OLAA, allowing students to communicate with tutors and other students by e-mail and through bulletin boards, to transfer assignments and access electronic library services and other national and international information resources through the internet.

Given the immense benefit that open net can offer to a range of students, the act will be amended to extend open net services to additional nominated client groups, potentially including other higher education, TAFE and school students.
The official launch of open net in may was an important step in realising the potential benefits of new technologies for australian higher education.

Open Net is the first step in the establishment of the recently announced Education Network Australia (EDNA) which in itself is part of a broader national strategy to enable Australia to adopt new information and communications services and technologies—the so called information superhighway. Key objectives of EDNA are to maximise the use of new communications technologies, to improve the quality of learning in the education and training sectors and to maximise industry development of opportunities for Australians. The initiative has the potential to make a major contribution to equity in educational opportunity across the country. The expansion of the coverage of open net is an important step in this process.

The role that new technology is playing in the education and training sector is evident in another aspect of the bill. The bill provides the statutory framework and funding arrangements for the Co-operative Multi-media Centres (CMC) program announced by the prime minister in his cultural policy statement creative nation. This statement addressed the challenge of creating "a dynamic Australian multi-media industry providing australian content for australian and international consumers". The CMC initiative was announced to address the identified need to build a critical pool of talent with multi-media skills.

The objective of the program is to support the development of a competitive, internationally successful, Australian multi-media industry. It is intended to bring together a wide range of people, organisations and resources in order to meet the challenge of the multi-media industry's skill requirements. The CMCs will catalyse the development of collaborative links between the education and training sectors and the industrial and creative communities. They will support multi-media skill formation while also bringing other benefits to those involved in producing and distributing multi-media.

To foster developments in multi-media, the government will seed the development of up to six CMCs over the next two years and will provide funding for the centres of up to $56.5 million over nine years. The CMCs will be collaborative enterprises between education and training centres, private industry organisations and the arts/cultural communities. The CMCs will also encourage co-operation in many areas including research and development, product distribution, management of intellectual property and sharing of access to equipment and facilities.

An important aspect of the government's higher education policy is to encourage productive interactions between higher education institutions and industry across all fields. To this end the joint commonwealth/industry funded additional places scheme was established in the 1991 budget as a partnership between the government and industry. The objectives of the scheme are to provide additional places in higher education institutions and to encourage linkages with industry.

Under existing program arrangements the commonwealth contributes 60 per cent of the cost of a place and industry the remaining 40 per cent. Approximately 20 per cent of the cost is returned to the commonwealth by way of HECS. In 1994 the program generated an additional uptake of 868 new places; 74 per cent of places under this scheme were filled by students selected by their employers.

The government is keen to build on this success and is revising the program's guidelines to introduce greater flexibility for institutions and industry partners. Part of these changes is to enhance the choices available in relation to hecs charges for students in joint commonwealth/industry funded places.
At present all places under the scheme are HECS liable. Section 35 of the act is amended by this bill to allow a HECS exemption for students occupying places under the scheme.

Under the new arrangements institutions would have the discretion to deem students HECS exempt where employers wish to pay 60 per cent of the cost of a place—that is, including the equivalent of the students' HECS charge. The commonwealth's contribution will remain at 60 per cent. In such cases the commonwealth would require institutions to remit the equivalent of the HECS charge. This will not result in an increase in the cost to the commonwealth and industry will contribute a greater proportion of the cost of the HECS exempt places. As a consequence there will be no net loss of commonwealth revenue.
This amendment to the scheme will provide greater flexibility to institutions in providing courses at times and under arrangements that are more suited to the needs of industry.
In other minor changes, section 3 of the act is amended to rectify an anomaly by removing the reference to TAFE in the definition of a "course of study".

The bill amends the act to extend the capacity of the secretary to remit a student's HECS debt to cover the period after an appeal has been lodged with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), where additional information has been provided by the applicant. This will provide a more timely service that benefits both the government and the student, by reducing the need for AAT hearings.

Finally, the bill make a number of minor amendments including an amendment to section 110 of the act to remove references to obsolete provisions. The bill also makes a minor amendment to section 43 to provide that applications for tax file numbers must be lodged directly with the Australian Taxation Office and can no longer be lodged at institutions. As the commissioner of taxation has responsibility for issuing tax file numbers for administrative reasons it is appropriate for applications for tax file numbers to be made directly to that office.

This bill reflects this government's commitment to an internationally recognised, high quality, higher education system which is striving for excellence and innovation in teaching and research—a system which is accessible to all Australians.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

speech.speaker: Woodley Sen J.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is debating the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill 1995. The provisions of this bill mirror changes made to the Social Security Act by the Social Security (Non-Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 and the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995. In the speeches I gave during the debate on those two bills a couple of weeks ago, I clearly stated the position of the Australian Democrats on the provisions contained in this bill. So I do not intend to take up the time of the Senate going over those provisions again.

para.tab: The first comment I would make on this legislation, however, is that this is the first amendment bill we have seen to the recently renamed Student and Youth Assistance Act. As I have said, the amendments in this bill are identical to amendments contained within the social security bills we dealt with in the last sitting week. The reason for that is that, against the wishes of the Australian Democrats, the youth training allowance was established under DEET legislation rather than simply being incorporated into the Social Security Act.

I noticed in the House of Representatives debate that the shadow minister for employment and training, Dr Kemp, complained of the added complexity of having to deal with amendments to two separate acts. Of course, I fully agree with him, but I cannot let the shadow minister's comments pass without noting that, at the same time the youth training allowance was introduced, the Democrats pointed out to both the government and the opposition that, by having the YTA set up under DEET legislation, we were introducing unnecessary complexity into the system. It is added complexity for us as legislators; it is added complexity for the many community legal and welfare rights centres trying to advise their clients; and it is added complexity for the millions of people whose payments are governed by these acts.

As Dr Kemp quite rightly pointed out in the House of Representatives debate, the only reason the youth training allowance was established under employment, education and training legislation was as a result of a power struggle between DEET and DSS. What he failed to mention was that the opposition allowed this to happen. I can only reiterate the Democrats' belief that the youth training allowance should be incorporated into the Social Security Act.

I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment in the committee stage. That amendment is identical to an amendment that I moved last year to a student assistance bill. The aim of that amendment is to exempt the value of farm assets from the Austudy assets test.
What the amendment will actually do is simply increase the current 50 per cent discount allowed for farm assets to 100 per cent.

Since moving my amendment last year, the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee has completed its inquiry into the impact of the Austudy assets test on farming families and has presented its final report to the Senate. That inquiry was held over eight months and received high quality submissions from hundreds of concerned groups and individuals.

Evidence given to the inquiry by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy showed that, as a result of the assets test, around 5,400 students from farming families are being denied access to Austudy. The fact that the assets test was discriminatory to farming families was noted by the committee which, in its conclusions, said:

speech.para: The Committee . . . considers that the assets test applied to farming families in order to determine eligibility for AUSTUDY, is an inappropriate policy instrument that does not take into account the nature of farm assets and their relationship with income. In essence, the current assets test does not acknowledge that some farmers are assets rich but income poor and that farm assets cannot readily be liquidated without diminishing the viability of the farming unit.

They are very wise comments by that committee. They are to be commended for the decision that they made which was recorded in that report. At the end of that eight-month inquiry, the majority recommendation of the committee was that farm assets should be excluded from the Austudy assets test. This is precisely what my amendment will achieve, and I will be calling on all senators to support this amendment.

speech.speaker: Tierney Sen J.W.

talk.start.para: —I rise in this debate to speak in support of the coalition's amendments which have been circulated. The Student and Youth Assistance (Youth Training Allowance) Bill proposes to change the youth training allowance provision in the Student Youth Assistance Act 1973. This allowance provides income support for young unemployed people under 18 years. The effect of this bill is to replace the jobsearch allowance administered by the Department of Social Security with the youth training allowance to be administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. The payment agency for the youth training allowance will remain as the Department of Social Security.

para.tab: We believe that this bill makes some cumbersome amendments in this area of administration. We should remember that this bill and the original act provide only a form of training allowance. They certainly do not make provision for real jobs for our youth. I have a real concern that another major portfolio area—DEET—has been brought into this process of administering these benefits. It seems to be more empire building on DEET's part. It increases the complexity of the youth training allowance and makes it harder for younger disadvantaged people to access benefits and training.

There has been no convincing justification in the debate on this bill to date to support bringing DEET into the delivery of this scheme. Over the years DEET has become a huge bureaucratic monster. It has 16,000 staff, administering volumes of complex regulations. Clients, employees and DEET staff are confused. We believe that this bill will only add to the complexity of the whole process.

In the hearings we had earlier this year on Austudy—we made recommendations of 22 changes—we did not in that whole process of receiving evidence about DEET's administration of that program gain a lot of confidence that would indicate that on this occasion what has been proposed here will actually improve the situation. We believe that the government has failed to perform and deliver effective training as promised by Labor through these programs. The scheme has not delivered its job creation targets because the training is really not relevant to available employment needs.

Dr David Kemp, who is our shadow minister, has exposed the government's fraud of concealing the real story on employment numbers. Youth unemployment in this country is running at nearly 30 per cent. In many regional areas the unemployment figure is an appalling 50 per cent, and that is certainly the case in my own area in the Hunter and to the north on the far north coast. Many of these 15- to 18-year-olds are long-term unemployed. Labor have deliberately reclassified and hidden 70,000 of the 140,000 people on the long-term lists. They put long-term unemployed, including our youth, into 13-week training programs. These labour market programs still leave three out of five people out of work when the program is completed.

The inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training into long-term unemployment heard evidence from young people that many of the training courses are irrelevant to their needs. Courses are often set up with a minimum of 20 participants and our youth are herded into them, irrespective of their interests or employment goals. It is little wonder that kids complain that only two or three of their number on the course were even interested in that particular area. They say that they are sick and tired of having to sit around and do courses to meet the targets of DEET officials. As clients, it seems that their real needs are secondary. At the end of these 13-week courses the majority not only do not get a job but they also lose their long-term unemployment status and they go back to the start of the queue again. In that process, they lose a lot of the assistance that people who have been classified for a longer period of time as long-term unemployed actually get. We feel that in many ways what has been set up under Working Nation with that sort of outcome is very much a retrograde step.

The traineeship targets for Working Nation for 1994-95 will not even reach half the government's targets. Of 26,500 placements, only 9,000 had been achieved in 1994-95. The amendments and the continual changes to Working Nation and the youth training allowance, in particular, prove that the whole policy has been done on the run. The scheme has been painfully slow being cranked up to provide assistance to young people. Labor's dishonest rhetoric always says that the targets will be met next year. The reality is that the targets are not met and the numbers of training opportunities for the young have been reduced. So much for the so-called world-class labour market intervention programs of this Labor government, as claimed by the chair of the ALP caucus economics committee, Wayne Swan, the member for Lilley, when he opened the unemployment conference in Brisbane earlier this year.

The number of young people moving into traineeships in 1994-95—the first year of Working Nation—will be lower than the year before Working Nation came into being. The ALP propaganda machine has spent millions reassuring the nation that youth traineeships are mounting and the process is speeding up. This line is totally without credibility. The machinery for operating the traineeship scheme has collapsed and the result is that the CES has botched the job of providing the promised effective training schemes. We believe that the logic of handing over the administration of the youth training allowance to DEET proposed by this bill is flawed and inappropriate. DEET and the CES have already dropped the ball on traineeships. The intent of the bill is to extend DEET's responsibilities. It will in no way guarantee an improvement in the job prospects for young people receiving the youth training allowance.

The failure of this government's approach to training has been identified for some time now. In June of this year Dr Vince Fitzgerald of the Allen Consulting Group wrote a report for ANTA. The report was highly critical of this government's approach to training. Minister Crean was so embarrassed that he hid the report until September for three months. The details of the report demolished the ALP's training credentials. Fitzgerald wrote:

speech.para: The current approach to training reform will not, without change, bring about the desired outcomes . . .

Nothing has changed. Our youth are churned through training schemes, whether they meet their needs or the needs of employers. Fitzgerald was saying that we must change our training ways away from government regulated courses. He argued that we should move to a more industry based model. This is the way forward in Europe and it certainly should be the way forward in Australia. Yet we persist with training people to go to the back of the unemployment queue, as I indicated earlier. Training schemes must be more tightly linked to industry and small business job opportunities. The coalition wants to be constructive in developing sensible and effective training for young people.

para.tab: What future is this legislation offering? It is all about administrative change to the bureaucracy. It does not improve the nature of the training. We want training schemes to do this and to deliver real skills that will be provided for real jobs. We have a number of initial programs at work, more or less as pilot schemes, that do provide the way forward for the future. I refer particularly in my own area to the Hunter Valley Training Co. It is a fine model that has been emulated by a number of other areas and does provide this real link between real work and training. The TRAC scheme in the retail area, which was initially started in the Hunter, is another example. These are all models for the future.

I support the coalition's amendments to this bill. These amendments have three important aims: firstly, they focus the government back to delivery of effective training programs; secondly, we want the government to clamp down on the expansion of this bureaucracy by DEET; and, thirdly, the amendments assure our young people that the coalition wants to see Labor's failed programs redesigned to give proper emphasis to industry based skills training.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para: —I rise to make my contribution to this debate on the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill 1995. It makes various amendments to the Student and Youth Assistance Act to mirror amendments made to the Social Security Act 1991 resulting from the government's Working Nation initiatives. These include provisions dealing with the liquid assets waiting period, periodic compensation payments, lump sum compensation, debt recovery, disclosure of information, reviewability of ministerial decisions, deferment periods and waiting periods, payment of the youth training allowance to full-time students and loan fringe benefits.

para.tab: The coalition opposes the provisions regarding disclosure of information and reviewability of ministerial decisions and supports the government's amendments to remove schedule 6, with the exception of item 7, and schedules 7 and 8. As part of Working Nation's youth initiative, the government introduced the Student Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill to implement the jobsearch allowance for under-18-year-olds. The youth training allowance is closely aligned to Austudy and is subject to means testing with parental income and assets tests being taken into account.

For some time I have been raising in the parliament the issue of access to Austudy for rural students. On a number of occasions the coalition has moved amendments relating to the health card. On occasions our amendments have had the support of the Democrats and no doubt they will support these amendments again. The issue came up some time ago when the government brought down the budget. Inadvertently, by mistake or by some reason or another, they did promise in their budget papers that the siblings or brothers and sisters of the breadwinner of any family who was eligible for health care cards would receive Austudy.

When this commitment was made we raised the issue in the Senate, only to find that the government had made a mistake. They built up expectations among young rural people who were looking forward to having a tertiary education and who were being tricked out of Austudy by the $750,000 assets test. In rural communities at the moment there are many students whose parents would have assets totalling $750,000. Those parents would be receiving negative incomes because of the drought or, in the past, because of low commodity prices for wool. I would expect, now that most of the abattoirs have closed in Queensland, that there will be a cattle crunch which will deprive a lot of rural students of access to Austudy.

I understand that the coalition will be moving an amendment relating to the health care card issue, just as they have moved amendments previously when this legislation has been considered. I am hopeful that the government will support the amendment. I say `hope' rather than `expect' because the government has made a commitment. There is no doubt it has made a commitment. It acknowledges it has made a commitment to rural students, yet it has backed away not once, not twice, but on at least three or four occasions.

I acknowledge that when the government introduced the drought relief package, that package made Austudy available to those people who were able to access that drought relief package. But there are many others who are not in receipt of the drought relief package—not so many in Queensland, but there are some in New South Wales and Victoria who are still subject to drought conditions and who are still unable to send their children to acquire a tertiary education.

One of the reasons why I am fighting so hard for this amendment is that it is very difficult now for the smaller properties to survive. Whereas 6,000 sheep used to be the number from which a person could get a decent living, now it is probably 12,000. Wheat farms have to get bigger. In real terms, that means a lot of farmers' children have to leave the property because they can no longer obtain a living from the land. More and more children of farmers will have to leave the land and the only opportunity available to them is to obtain a tertiary education. Unfortunately, because of circumstances far beyond their control, their parents are not able to offer them access to Austudy.

The real point is that they can no longer obtain a living from the family farm. The family farm is flat out trying to provide a living for the parents. In the old days, it was always the great wish of farmers to pass on the property or access another property for their children, just as their fathers gave them a property. Unfortunately, that is not the case now. Many families of farming parents have to move off the property. If they are not able to get a living from the family property, there is nowhere else for them to go except to obtain a tertiary education. They are now going to be deprived of that, unless our proposed amendment is carried.
