speech.para: This amendment is designed to exempt the value of the family farm from the Austudy assets test. This is the same amendment I moved last year; indeed, the Democrats have been moving similar amendments for over four years now.

para.tab: In response to one of my amendments last year, a Senate inquiry was established to look into and report on the impact of the Social Security and Austudy assets test on farming families. I certainly would like to recognise the involvement of my colleague Meg Lees in getting that reference up, as well as the involvement of Senator Patterson. So we had this inquiry. I was a member of the committee of inquiry. It was held over eight months. It received more than 250 submissions and the overwhelming majority of those were highly critical of the assets test as it applied to farming families.

The committee presented its report relating to the Austudy assets test to the Senate in March this year. The inquiry found that around 5,400 students from farming families are being denied Austudy because of the assets test. The inquiry also found general agreement that retention and participation rates of rural students are much lower than in the rest of the community. The committee pointed out that it is in the national interest that farming families have access to educational opportunities in order for this productive sector to remain competitive and technologically innovative.
The major recommendation—let me underline this—supported by the Democrats, the Greens, Senator Harradine, the National Party and the Liberal Party, was:

speech.para: The committee recommends that farm assets be excluded from the Austudy assets test.

A very, very important recommendation. Children from farming families deserve and have a right to receive the same level of government encouragement and support to continue their studies that city kids enjoy.

para.tab: The average value of a broadacre farm is around $900,000. In each of the past three years, however, Australian broadacre farmers have reported average losses of around $17,000, $6,000 and, for 1994-95, $13,500. Yet the majority of these farmers are ineligible to receive Austudy to assist in their children's education.

The amendment will address this inequity. The amendment reflects the policy of the National Farmers Federation, the Victorian Farmers Federation, the majority of the 250 groups and individuals who gave evidence to the Senate inquiry and, I am sure, reflects the wishes of every farming family in Australia. Therefore, I commend the amendment to the Senate.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I want to briefly respond to the amendment moved by Senator Woodley. This is, as he said, a debate that we have had on a number of occasions in recent years. Addressing the particular problems of rural people and ensuring they have fair access to education is an issue of concern certainly to the coalition parties in this place.

para.tab: It is our observation—and I am speaking generally—that rural children are at a disadvantage in terms of education. It is not surprising that the schools that offer the greater choice and greater depth and most of Australia's universities are located in either major cities or capital cities—most in fact are in capital cities. This creates problems when trying to ensure that a fair opportunity for education is given to children who live in regional or rural Australia.

There are a lot of different ways to address that problem and ensure that there is equity across the Australian community—but that is, in broad terms, a debate beyond the one we are having today. It is certainly a debate that the coalition does not shy away from, and it is one that we will be addressing as a major part of our rural and educational policies at the next election.

I also have to acknowledge that in recent years there has been another problem facing rural children—that is, rural families have suffered from the devastating effects of this prolonged drought which is affecting a great deal of Australia. I have witnessed the consequences of that suffering as I have visited those universities that do exist in regional Australia. The students have told me of the problems they have had when they have been unable to continue courses in universities, firstly, because of their responsibility to their family and because they have tried to keep the family income going and, secondly, simply because of the costs associated with getting to university and undertaking study.

We have a general problem in this country—because of our geography and demographics, our country students are disadvantaged. In recent times, we have had a more particular problem, because so many of our rural families have suffered the detrimental consequences of the drought. This has added to the difficulties that those families have had in providing the sort of education they want for their children. As national legislators, we acknowledge that this is something we must address.

I also accept that there seems to be a trend that people in rural Australia have lower incomes. Others in this chamber from the Liberal Party and the National Party are probably better able to speak about the effects of commodity markets and consequences of low prices. I can certainly speak about all the unnecessary on-costs that farmers have to bear as a result of this incompetent Labor government. It has been the case that incomes of rural people in this country overall seem to be very low, and that has made the education of rural children even more difficult.

This gets us to the issue of Austudy. I think Senator Woodley will acknowledge that this is an issue that has been raised under the framework of this bill simply because it is convenient to do so—we have performed similarly with other student assistance bills in the past. Senator Woodley believes that, if we remove the asset study altogether for rural families, we can solve the problem of students missing out on Austudy because of the asset value of farms.

We have addressed this in the past. We have addressed it in the committee to which Senator Woodley referred. We have a lot of sympathy with what he seeks to do, but we still have some reservations as to whether his solution is, in fact, the best solution in all the circumstances.

We have a responsibility to be fair to communities living within rural Australia, whether they live in the towns or whether they earn their income from primary production. Senator Woodley's amendment, as I understand it, is limited to those who earn their income from primary production. I simply remind him that many small businesses in towns have been grossly reduced in value as a result of the drought and also because of the general difficulties in rural Australia. Some businesses have had their income reduced but would still have a value. Sometimes you wonder about the methods of calculating these values. Nevertheless, there are families who have missed out on Austudy because of the assets test applied to their business. We certainly hesitate before endorsing an amendment that would, in effect, divide rural Australia in this way.

We also have some reservations about further dividing Australia between rural and non-rural. The whole issue of assets tests on Austudy is a difficult one. We understand the motivation for that test. Public funding is always tight, and at the moment it is particularly tight. But the future of this country very much depends upon the quality of education that can be given to all Australians, which includes those families suffering from low income who may miss out on that opportunity because they cannot be supported through Austudy as a result of the assets test.

We have tried in the past to look for what we think is a fairer approach. The fairer approach we have endorsed in the past is to work off the health card system to which, as honourable senators know, there is not an assets test applied, only an income test. Certainly, in circumstances out of the ordinary where someone's income drops, such as in the case of a drought, the value of the supporting asset may remain up because people invest for the long term in the hope that the drought will eventually pass. Because of the low income during that period, we believe—and certainly know in many cases as a fact—that they have been able to access a health card.

It seems to us to be a fairer solution that, if those who are entitled to a health card as a result of their falling income were given the right to take Austudy without being subject to an assets test, that would achieve many of the objectives that Senator Woodley seeks without, it seems to us, creating further inequities within the community. In other words, it would not be discriminatory in the way that Senator Woodley's solution might be argued to be.

We do not say for a moment that this is a cut and dried issue. As I said at the outset, I think we all recognise a responsibility to these particular families in Australia who may be in need but who, nevertheless, fail the assets test. We also recognise our direct responsibility, our primary responsibility, to their children. But in our efforts to find the best solution in these circumstances, we believed in the past that the health card option better achieved that outcome, and that is still our opinion today.

So we will not support Senator Woodley's amendment. We will put the alternative of the health card amendment, which we have put previously in this place. We hope that, when we reach that stage of the debate, the Australian Democrats will recognise the merit of our proposal and will support us. In that way, we can offer some benefit to rural families that fall within the difficulties I have outlined.

para.tab: But the main hurt that they have had to sustain is the 25 per cent interest rates that have eaten the equity out of their properties. Another point I want to make is that in the second reading debate, before Senator Hill came in, I was challenged by the ministerial secretary, Senator Sherry. para.tab: I have sympathy with Senator Woodley's amendment but it does leave problems. As the letters have come in, I have rung them back and said there are problems with that amendment. What are you going to do about the machinery dealer, the haberdashery store, the grocery story, or the hardware store which gives extended credit to the farmers?

You are going to divide the community. I put that to rural organisations. They said, `As far as we are concerned, a health care card will get us out of trouble, and we would be grateful for that amendment to be carried.'

The argument that Senator Woodley and I are engaged in at the moment is not going to carry a lot of weight. I will put money on it now that the health care card amendment will be carried, as it has been carried on the last four occasions. The government takes the bill back to the lower house and rejects the amendmentm, and then it comes up here again.

talk.start.para: —Nobbled.

—They nobble the amendment. Senator Sherry is the secretary to the primary industries minister. He should be using some of his weight to have an amendment to the government legislation carried. We have been toing and froing on this one for the last 12 months. Every time a bill mentions Austudy we go through this exercise.

para.tab: Senator Woodley and this side of the chamber support amendments that give rural students access to Austudy for many valid reasons. I alluded to them in my speech on the second reading. Farmers at the moment cannot afford to pass on a property as their parents passed the property on to them and their parents before them passed the property on to them. It has always been a tradition in the farming communities. If your parents gave you a property, it is incumbent upon you to give your sons, in particular, and daughters a property.

Unfortunately, the living areas of properties have to be extended. No longer does a small family farm provide an income. So these students and rural families have to leave the property. They have to seek employment in the cities or in other regional towns. The only way they are going to get employment is if they have the same choice as other low income families.

What you are doing by not passing either of these amendments, Senator Sherry, is consigning those kids to second-rate jobs. Every child in Australia has the right to an education, but you are denying that right to rural families. The assets test is tripping up some of these families. As Senator Woodley said, a property worth $750,000 is not a huge property. I believe he used the figure of $900,000. I would have thought that was roughly accurate.

talk.start.para: —A figure provided for us.

—Senator Woodley says it is a figure provided for us, so it would be accurate. The health care card does not rely on an assets test. It relies on an income test. Senator Woodley, there are advantages in what you say. There are also advantages in the health care card because it allows other people to access Austudy. It will pick up many of the small businesses that are also suffering in regional and rural Australia.

para.tab: You can argue that yours is better, we can argue that ours is as good as yours, but we will not get anywhere. Hopefully, our amendment will be carried. If the government does support it—and I say that with hope rather than expectation—then we will be able to give some of these cash-strapped rural families access to tertiary education.

speech.speaker: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

talk.start.para: —I would also like to join this debate for a short time. It is very hard to add any better words or emotion than those of Senator Boswell, who has fought very hard for this issue every time it has come before the Senate.

para.tab: There is no doubt it is the fate of many a parliamentary secretary to be left holding the fort at this very late hour and to be asked to be across all sorts of issues from one ministry to another. We have a perfect example of a parliamentary secretary who simply is not across this issue. Senator Sherry has done his best throughout the last parliamentary session to get across every single ministry that he can, but he has fallen short here. Surely Senator Boswell has shown this evening that Senator Sherry was not across this particular subject at all.

There was a commitment by the government in the budgetary papers of 1993 unbeknownst to Senator Sherry—an ironclad commitment. Senator Boswell tabled that ironclad commitment. We await Senator Sherry's response with baited breath. In knowing Senator Sherry, as we do, he is far more reasonable than the other senators. He is a man who is priming himself on this very portfolio of primary industry.

talk.start.para: —They'll never forgive him if he lets them down this time.

—It is a test of Senator Sherry's moral fortitude, and also as a representative of the rural communities, to admit he is wrong. As you know, Senator Boswell, many a time he has been sent out into the rural communities, such as the citrus industry, to compile a report. On the face of it, the report on the citrus industry was a fair and just report but what happened when it landed in cabinet?
—It gets sat on—by a very large weight.

—Absolutely sat on, as Senator O'Chee says. It is embarrassing but I think Senator Sherry will get his chance in shadow ministry, when the time comes, to take up this particular portfolio. We do not expect Senator Sherry to be over all the backflips that the government has done since 1993, and he has certainly missed this one; but the coalition's amendment seeks no more than to reinstate the government's original statement in the budget papers.

para.tab: We seek an alternative to the Democrats, to apply the income test according to the health care card as the threshold. As pointed out by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, this is not only going to benefit farmers—I appeal to the Democrats—but also many of those in the small towns such as the small businesses which are equally as worthy.

It is our aim to keep the whole community together. We not only represent the farmers; we represent all the rural sector and all those small towns which interconnect with the farmers. It is vital that all rural people have access to education, otherwise they are just going to pack up and leave these small towns. They will take their children with them. We have already seen an exodus in the last 10 years from many of these small towns. In particular, in my state of Victoria, in the Mallee, towns have actually vanished. We have to make a decision sooner or later whether or not we want these small towns, whether or not we want people to live in our country regions. If they are not given some incentive, if they are not given a fair go, they really will pack up and leave for the sake of their children, for the sake of their children's education.

I appeal to the Australian Democrats: if we do not support the opposition's amendment today, we are going to hurt many of the farming families in the small towns, denying them access to Austudy. The report said that there were over 5,400 families suffering under the assets test. This amendment will benefit many thousands of those farmers. Senator Woodley, if you do not support it, you will perpetuate the existing problem of the asset rich and income poor farmer.

As I said, there is no greater concern to farming families and families in small towns than education for their children.
Throughout all the hardships—drought, low commodity prices, the internationalisation of our economy, and all the doubts and anxieties running through the economy at the moment, be it in the country or the city—there is only one wish for the families out there, and that is that they can at least achieve, as a priority, the education of their children.

They will put up with more hardship than anyone else, they will have more grit in their lives than any metropolitan family, if they can just achieve that priority. It is a worthy priority, an admirable priority, and an understandable priority, to be able to educate their children. This is the right of all families in this country. To have a law that disadvantages those in rural areas is a disgrace on the part of this government.

I would like to read from the report—an admirable report, chaired by the Deputy Leader of the National Party in the Senate, Senator Brownhill. I have one particular quote—it is rather lengthy but it sums up the situation—from a witness who appeared before the committee, Mr Robert Charlton of Milawa in Victoria. He said:

speech.para: Many farming families battle financially to break even yet are excluded from receiving the assistance of Austudy on the grounds that they own too much. While I recognise that the assets limit is set higher for primary producers than for others the assets test does not realistically reflect the amount of capital tied up in a farming family and should be abolished. The relief brought to rural families via access to Austudy would be enormous. It could possibly secure the education of children living on country properties and, in many cases, may prove to be the difference between a family staying on the farm or being forced off through financial difficulties.

talk.start.para: —I ask Senator Sherry if he can clarify the criteria for determining whether people qualify for health care cards in relation to assets?
—The health care card issue is the subject of the next amendment. Whilst we are getting that material for you, can we leave it to that amendment?
—There are two amendments, both dealing with the same issues. It is important to clarify the differences between the two amendments. That is why I am asking the question now.
—I will be dealing with that.
—Fine; that is great.

—Having listened to Senator McGauran and Senator Boswell, I must say that if it had been an evangelical appeal they were making, I would have had to put up my hand. They were very convincing. No-one doubts Senator Boswell's commitment to the bush—I want to say that—but I need to say to the members of the National Party of Australia in this chamber that this is one issue on which the National Party should not allow the Liberal Party to lead it by the nose. It is time for the National Party to separate itself and to stand up for the bush.

para.tab: Senator Boswell said that the government will reject the health care card. I agree with him. My advice to the National Party is: do not proceed with it. Take the advice that we are offering and do not desert Senator Boswell, your own deputy leader, who was convinced by the inquiry we had and who was able, very tellingly, to change his mind and, as chairman of the committee, urged the exact amendment that I am now moving as a first step in dealing with the issue—which people in this chamber are very passionate about, I do not deny. I am appealing to the National Party because I am not sure I could convince the Liberal Party.

I now turn to some of the issues that were raised. Senator Lees, who has a lot of experience in this area, will speak a little about some of them but let me make a quick comment on the issue of discrimination against, for example, small businesses in rural communities.

In the committee of inquiry we were very aware of this issue—it was raised on many occasions—and we recommended that we have an inquiry into the larger problem of other businesses in rural communities. The Australian Democrats are ready to support immediately such an inquiry. I would support the bringing forward of terms of reference for that inquiry, and perhaps Senator Hill would be the appropriate person to initiate it, having raised that issue himself. I am sure he is fair dinkum about it and I look forward to the terms of reference that he will bring into the chamber so that we can deal with that issue. But that is only a first step in addressing the needs of people who are most obviously being disadvantaged.

Let me quickly speak about the issue of the health care card because we have looked at this very carefully. There will be a significant number who would not benefit from the health care card amendment but would be greatly assisted by a 100 per cent discount of farm assets under the Austudy assets test. That is because the Austudy income test is far more generous than that which applies to the health care card.

The income test limits on the health care card allow a family with one child to earn up to about $19,400 a year, while a family with two children can earn up to about $21,200. However, these are sudden death thresholds, meaning that if the family earns $1 over the threshold, it receives no health care benefits at all.

The threshold for full rate Austudy is $21,300, but the payment has a gradual withdrawal rate of $1 for every $4 of income over the threshold. Further, the Austudy income test is based on what is known as adjusted family income, which allows additional concessions for other dependent children. So a farm family which, were it not for the assets test, would qualify for a part rate Austudy payment, will benefit from the 100 per cent discount amendment but will gain nothing from the health care card amendment.

Let me give you an example. A farm family with two children on an income of $25,000 would not qualify for a health care card and would probably be excluded from Austudy. If the 100 per cent discount amendment were accepted, this same family would qualify for a part payment of Austudy of around $100 per fortnight if the student child were living at home, or $190 per fortnight if the student child were away from home. In summary, all farm families with incomes between $21,000 and around $45,000 would benefit from the 100 per cent amendment by receiving a part rate payment of Austudy.

Let's not forget that the only reason these people are not currently getting Austudy is because of their farm assets. Most city families with incomes between $21,000 and $45,000 per year are already receiving part Austudy payments for their kids. So while the health care card amendment is certainly a valuable one, I believe, as a priority, the chamber should be supporting the 100 per cent discount amendment.

In conclusion, I would simply point out once again that the inquiry of the rural and regional affairs committee took over eight months and received submissions from over 250 people. The conclusion that committee came to was that the family farm should be exempted from the assets test. In the light of that, it seems strange that the opposition are so keen to pursue an amendment that is so clearly a second-best option.

talk.start.para: —Just for the record, the Greens (WA) will be supporting Senator Woodley's amendment No. 1.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: —I thank senators for their contributions. Firstly, there is Senator McGauran's challenge, and I thank him for what I think was a backhanded compliment on the way through. Likewise, I issue a challenge to you under the same terms that Senator Woodley has issued it. If you know that your amendment is not going to be supported by the Democrats—
—The amendment is going to be supported.

—Why aren't you going to support him on the allowance?

—I will get to that in a moment. The problem is that the National Party has been done by the Liberal Party. You have been done in the shadow cabinet; you have been done in the party room. Here is another case of the National Party being overridden, ground into the dust, by the Liberal Party.
—Ha, ha!

—You can laugh, Senator Boswell, but why aren't you supporting Senator Woodley's amendment? You boast about the freedom to vote with your conscience—and it has happened here; I will acknowledge that, Senator Boswell. I can recall that there have been occasions such as the Mabo legislation—I do not know what you did on the tobacco legislation—when you have crossed the floor.

—Mr Acting Chairman, I rise on a point of order. This is a debate concerning the merits or otherwise of a particular clause. I suggest that you draw the parliamentary secretary back to that clause and the detail which you would expect to be addressed in a committee stage debate.
—May I just make a comment?

para.tab:
The ACTING CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)
—Are you speaking to the point of order, Senator Sherry?

talk.start.para: —Yes, I am. I am sure you allowed other speakers such as Senator McGauran to range much further and wider than I have. We have had speakers on the next amendment. I think I have a right—indeed, a duty—to respond to the issues specifically raised, which certainly were not ruled out of order when others were speaking.

—In relation to the point of order, I think that there has been a wide-ranging discussion from members of the opposition and from the Australian Democrats. I think that Senator Sherry is responding to some of that, but I am sure that very shortly he will be talking about the amendment that is before the chamber.

—Yes, in fact, I am just about to pass on to that. So the challenge lies with the National Party. It will be interesting to see what they do when confronted with this situation of the Liberal Party overriding them on yet another issue.

para.tab: In respect of the challenge to me personally, the facts of life are that I am a member of the party caucus. I participate in the debates, and I accept the decision of the party caucus and the cabinet process. Be that as it may, like other senators in this chamber—Senator Hill, Senator Boswell, Senator Woodley and a number of others who have expressed a view in this chamber—I tour rural areas very extensively. I am aware of some of the very difficult circumstances that exist in the rural sector.

Before I get to Senator Woodley's amendment, Senator Boswell and Senator McGauran have raised what they argue is a specific commitment promise given by the government in the budget papers of 1993. Senator Boswell has tabled a document which is not the budget papers—I point out to the chamber—which is not legislation and which is not a government statement. It is a document issued by DEET called the
1993-94 Student assistance budget kit
.

The background to this document—contrary to the assertion that there was any commitment given in the budget papers, which is the budget that is handed down by the Treasurer and the associated papers by the various ministers—is that there was no commitment to remove the assets test or to base it on the health care card. What we then had was a kit put out shortly thereafter—I do not know the precise date—which was incorrect. It certainly does refer to assets tests—`without parental income and assets test'. It does refer to that. That was an error. It was corrected straightaway. I do not know whether it was corrected on the same day, but it was certainly very shortly thereafter once the government had it drawn to its attention. It was corrected shortly thereafter because the kit that was issued was incorrect.

There was no government undertaking. There is no government budget paper, no government legislation, no government press release or no government campaign material that gave the promise that Senator Boswell refers to. There was no government undertaking that the assets test would be waived for health care card holders. There was an error, and it was corrected at the time by Minister Free. The document that Senator Boswell refers to, and that I was very happy for him to table, clearly indicates what I have said. So there is no need for me to fall on my sword or my pen. I think that the facts are very clear on this matter.

The government will not be accepting Senator Woodley's manedment. The Austudy assets test is there to ensure that assistance is targeted to those in greatest need. The assets test was introduced following community concern that income alone was not an adequate measure of the financial circumstances of families and their ability to contribute to their children's education. The assets test already provides a wide range of concessions which ensure it operates to target Austudy assistance fairly, most significantly.

The value of assets is calculated based on current market value and net of debt. These are important concessions where the value of the family farm or other business is genuinely affected by market downturns, drought or high debt burdens. Recognising the special circumstances of assets that are tied up in a family business, a 50 per cent discount applies to the value of all family businesses which the parent is wholly or substantially engaged in operating, including family operated farms.

Under special concessions for drought affected families, families in exceptional circumstance drought affected areas who are getting a Commonwealth drought relief payment through the Department of Social Security can get Austudy exempt from income or assets tests. Families in exceptional circumstance drought affected areas who do not get or choose not to apply for the drought relief payment can still get a 100 per cent discount on on-farm assets. So we have heard about and seen the difficult circumstances in the drought areas of Australia and that change has been provided.

Minister Free in the House on 22 June this year drew attention to recent Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics figures, indicating that average farm values for most types of farms were within the limits allowed under the Austudy assets test. Senator Woodley's amendment seeks to apply a 100 per cent discount on farm primary production assets, which I notice is one of the reasons given by Senator Hill for not supporting this amendment. He has argued that it would discriminate against people who live in rural and regional Australia and who do not have on-farm production assets.

talk.start.para: —That is a good argument too.

—Yes, but you could then extend that logic further and say why discriminate at all against people who have assets in urban areas who may run similar types of businesses, other than farms, to people in regional Australia. I think you also base your argument on an inconsistent argument that would discriminate against people in urban areas who are earning similar incomes with similar or the same assets and businesses. Given the concessions to the assets test already in place, the benefits of this could flow to only farming families who are not in exceptional circumstance drought affected areas, particularly those with on-farm assets worth more than $750,000 clear of debt.

para.tab: Also, Senator Woodley's amendment is limited to only on-farm assets, so families whose assets are tied up in a family business other than a farm—as I have already mentioned, Senator Hill has already dealt with this issue—would be treated differently. This includes shopkeepers and local business people. Why should we treat shopkeepers and local business people in rural and regional areas any differently from the small business people—those who you, Senator Boswell, talk in here about—who are in suburban Australia? They may be going through difficult circumstances. Why should we treat them any differently?

talk.start.para: —That is what the health care card will do.

—We will get to the health care card when we get to that amendment, Senator—just wait. I am dealing with the amendment before the Senate—not the amendment that you know nothing about and we have not yet got to. The cost of a 100 per cent discount on on-farm assets for Austudy is estimated at $14.8 million. Let us hear from the opposition about where they would get the revenue from. They are always talking about balanced budgets; they are always talking about lowering taxation. Where would you get the revenue from? Let us hear from you about that. Senator Woodley's amendment would insert—I apologise to the opposition: we are dealing with the Democrats' amendment. Let us hear from the Democrats about the revenue issue and let us hear from the opposition about the revenue issue on the next amendment.

para.tab: Senator Woodley's amendment would insert a new section 8 into the bill which provides that, not later than the commencement of the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill 1995, regulations must be made in relation to the matters set out in the new section 8. The bill, if passed, would commence on royal assent. Schedule 1, where this amendment is intended to be inserted, will be taken to have commenced on 20 March 1995.

This means Senator Woodley's amendment would be taken to have commenced from this date once the bill has received royal assent. However, regulations implementing the substantive provisions of this amendment would need to be made prior to the royal assent of the bill. It is inappropriate to hold up royal assent for this bill whilst regulations are made. This bill is about keeping the youth training allowance in line with legislative change that the Department of Social Security is making to other Commonwealth income support payments.

Senator Hill is saying—we have already touched on this to some degree in this debate—to you, Senator Woodley, that he agrees with you but he is not going to support your amendment because the opposition are approaching the issue from a different tack. The opposition might reconsider their position when they disclose their currently secret policies, if they have them, some time up to the election. In the meantime, they are not going to support your amendment. The challenge is for you to support their amendment, and that seems to be the thrust of the opposition's position in addition to the arguments they have put forward. We will wait to see, I suppose, as we get closer to the election, how they intend to deal with this issue.

In respect of the question from Senator Margetts about the health care card—more information will be provided when we get to the next amendment—clients who qualify for health care cards free of assets testing qualify in the following circumstances, and I have six categories listed here: firstly, clients who receive mobility allowance but are not in receipt of any other DSS income support payment; secondly, with parents receiving child disability allowance prior to 31 December 1992 the card is issued in the name of the child; thirdly, health care cards issued under the disadvantaged persons health care scheme; fourthly, student parents receiving postgraduate awards on 31 December 1993 whose award continued into the 1994 calendar year; fifthly, blind pensioners receiving pensioner concession cards; and, sixthly, ex-pensioners and sole parent pensioners receive a card for six months after the payment is cancelled, and disability support pensioners receive a pensioner concession card for 12 months after payments are cancelled.

That then leads me to what the definition is of mobility allowance and child disability allowance. I can obtain that information for Senator Margetts, but I cannot give that to her this evening. That leads me to a series of further questions about qualification for the health care cards. No doubt we are not going to finish this this evening, so—

talk.start.para: —So you still have not answered the question.

—I accept that I have not provided all of that information. We will get additional information for you. It is fairly obvious now that we are not going to finish this this evening. When we get to the next amendment on the health care card, or before then, depending on when this debate concludes this evening, we will try to get additional information for you, Senator.

talker.name: Senator LEES
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: —I would just like to make some comments on some of what Senator Sherry said. To begin with, Senator Sherry commented that when the assets test was introduced people generally accepted the basic principle that income was not the only thing we should be worried about. I suggest to you, Senator, that nobody foresaw what was going to come of the next few years for rural Australia. No-one foresaw what was going to happen to commodity prices, to interest rates, to our climate.

para.tab: I think what we are facing goes a lot further than just an occasional drought. What we are now facing could well mean that many farming areas have to totally readjust to make some sense of the long-term change I suspect we are facing. So suggesting that a decision was made a number of years ago and therefore we have to hang on to it regardless of existing circumstances is simply, shall we say, stretching the point to its limit and beyond. If the government is so inflexible, maybe it is time that it should not be governing at all.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) talked about drought relief. Looking at my home state in particular, we are not eligible for that. Senator Hill will support me in saying that, despite year after year of problem after problem, mice plagues do not come into the government's calculations when determining drought. Rain at the wrong time of the year which totally ruins harvests does not qualify us for drought. Forget about the fact that our farmers have had year after year with either low incomes, no incomes or negative incomes, not one farmer is able to take any benefit from the support the government is giving. I am very pleased to say the government is giving it to other states, but no farmers in my home state are able to access Austudy through that special drought relief provision.

Looking at comments particularly from Senator Hill, I suggest that now is the time to move without any further putting aside of this or looking for alternatives. In particular, Senator, you made comments about how you do understand and you do agree that we should do something. I suspect—Senator Bell is going to comment on this in a moment—you are not going to push or pursue even your second best option when the government comes back and says, `Sorry, we don't like the look of that.' I really hope I am wrong on this. I hope that, if after all of this we do end up supporting the second best option, we will really see a push this time.

We are in a situation where students in most states are now going into their final term of 1995. Saying again that we are going to defer this, we are going to perhaps wait till after the election or we are going to hear more about what the Liberal Party is going to do is simply not good enough. Four years have gone by now and a decision has not been made. So we are calling on you in the first instance to support the best option, which is ours.

Yes, it is only one step in the right direction. We still need to deal with other businesses, both in rural areas and city areas, as to how we will come to terms with difficulties they have of education in the next generation. But we have the opportunity now to, I believe, spend money very wisely on the education of rural children. I hope that, when we get to your amendment tonight or perhaps tomorrow and we do eventually agree in this place to support the second best option, we really will see it pursued this time.

talk.start.para: —Having been blessed earlier on in the debate with the perspicacity of Senator Boswell and Senator McGauran, I was not going to make a comment—that was until I heard the contribution from Senator Sherry. What an extraordinary contribution that was. It was absolutely extraordinary. I started to take the view that maybe Senator Sherry is in need of Austudy so that he can go back and get some remedial comprehension lessons.

para.tab: All of Senator Sherry's attack on the amendment was in fact argument in favour of the coalition's position. Senator Sherry repeatedly challenged across the chamber: what were we going to do in relation to people in small business who might have low incomes. Senator Sherry said, `What about small business proprietors in the cities who might be suffering from low income?' Senator Sherry did not accept and should have accepted the interjection from my colleague Senator Ferguson, who is very learned in these matters, who said, `That is what the health care card amendment covers.'

As Senator Sherry is a man who speaks his mind and has obviously spoken his mind, all I can assume is that he is going to vote against the Democrat amendment and then is going to cross the floor and vote with the coalition. Every argument he put up was an argument in favour of the coalition's amendment. It is as simple as that.

I am a generous man. I am even going to make the offer that between now and the second division I will go and get a pair of running shoes so that Senator Sherry can put them on and become more comfortable when he walks across the floor. Unless he does that, I suggest that Senator Sherry should stop making such inane contributions to this debate, should maybe look at the issue before he speaks and should recognise the fact that the coalition's position, which is a unanimous position of both the National and Liberal parties, a position about which we are very happy, is the best position and Senator Sherry ought to be backing it.

talk.start.para: —What worries me about this debate is that it is probably the sixth or seventh time it has come around and we have heard a different version of the arguments from the coalition. At various times we have heard contributions from Senator Gibson, Senator Tierney, Senator Crane, Senator Hill and Senator Teague. I would like to know where Senator Teague is now. The last time Senator Teague moved the amendment that I understand the coalition is about to move, the Democrats actually supported that to find that it came back to this chamber and the coalition ran away from it.

para.tab: I think Senator Woodley can be forgiven for having to come up with a different amendment, knowing that the one the coalition is purporting to promote was not worth the support of the coalition the second time around. I think Australia's rural communities deserve treatment a little bit more honest and a little bit more straightforward than this. They are interested in finding out just what it is this parliament is able to support.

I am at a loss as to what it is the parliament will support. I have heard the government's arguments in various shapes and forms over the years. I have not been impressed by any of the arguments against this fairly simple measure of ensuring that Australia's rural communities have access to what they should be entitled to—a fair system for being able to further the tertiary education of the young people who live in Australia's rural areas. Time and time again we have been knocked back on this by the government. What was it, Senator O'Chee? Perspicacity? A term which was—

talk.start.para: —Very apt.

—No, Senator O'Chee. I think our attempting to embellish this debate with sophistry and what are essentially just a bunch of clever dick words, rather than getting down, voting for and actually achieving something for the benefit of Australia's rural community, is really not what we are about. What we are about is trying to be simple about it and getting on and recognising the simple core of the matter. I recognise that in Senator Woodley's amendment. I have seen it before. I think we would do well to spend less time messing about with fine, flowery words and to actually get on and solve the problem. The problem has been before us for several years and it does not need any more clever words.

—I rise to reply very quickly to two challenges which were put to the Democrats. First of all, Senator Ferguson said, `Why is the health care card amendment a second-best amendment?' I do not want to canvass the explanation I gave before because we had the figures, which clearly show that this is so. My explanation in
Hansard
will explain it to you, Senator Ferguson.

para.tab: Senator Sherry challenged the Democrats about cost. During the hearings we were told that the cost of our amendment would be somewhere between $10 million and $15 million. In a previous debate tonight we saw that Kangaroo 95 cost in the vicinity of $64 million. Some of that money, of course, was used to teach Indonesians to kill their own citizens. I would suggest to you that Australians would much rather see $10 million or $15 million spent on what they would regard not as a cost but as an investment in the future of children of the farming families of Australia.

talk.start.para: —I was not going to be drawn into the debate, but a couple of things Senator Woodley and Senator Lees have said have forced me to. It has been very interesting to hear Senator Woodley, Senator Lees and Senator Bell get up and speak and purport to know exactly what people who live in rural communities require to further the education of their children. I happen to live in one of those communities and have first-hand knowledge of neighbours who started off getting support and then there was some alleged mistake made. They started getting support because they were in receipt of a health care card and then, all of a sudden, this was cut off because it was decided that it was a mistake in the first place and it had never been intended that health care card holders should be able to receive support through Austudy for their children's education.

para.tab: I do not agree with Senator Lees or Senator Woodley when they talk about a second-best option. The one thing people who are actually living in rural communities are most concerned about—I can say this with first-hand knowledge, because I still do—is that there is no discrimination, amongst the people who receive support, from people within rural communities. Coming from a farming family myself, the thing that concerns me is: if this is offered only to children of farming families, what happens to the children of the families they live with in those rural areas who run the local machinery dealership, as was mentioned by, I think, Senator Hill, and the people who are running all the other small businesses within those rural communities who are suffering just as much as people who are under the direct effects of the drought by way of their personal income through primary production?

The reason we have decided that we do not want to use just the farm assets test—it would be very easy for the Liberal and National parties to say that we will just support the farming family—is that there are more than farming families that need support. To discriminate amongst people who live in one small community is only going to cause divisions that are not warranted and are certainly not in the best interests of the children we are trying to help.

talk.start.para: —But we supported that amendment before.

—Okay. You supported that amendment before. You said that you brought the same amendment up three or four times. What I am saying to you, Senator Bell, is that the only fair way to do it is to have something that covers more than just farming families. As a former farmer myself, I know that within rural communities everybody suffers equally. It is not just those people who happen to be involved in primary production.

para.tab: The unanimous decision by the two parties in the coalition is that we should look at supporting people other than just those that are working on farms. I may have something to say when our amendment comes up regarding the health care card, which we think is a far better option because it does cover all of those people.

I think I heard Senator Sherry saying, `What about small businesses in urban areas that are suffering because of a downturn in the economy?' The health care card option covers a far greater range of people and it does the thing we want to do; that is, provide equality of opportunity for all those young people who are looking to further their education in the way that suits them and their families best. For that reason, I do not support Senator Woodley's motion that only farming families should be considered and the farm assets should be considered. We should be looking at the broader rural communities and also at people who live in smaller urban areas who are suffering the same sorts of downturns. That is why the health care card is not the second-best option. It is the best option.

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

talk.start.para: —I will reply very briefly. Senator Lees in her contribution raised the issue of drought assistance and RAS. She also raised a series of circumstances that, she argues, in South Australia have precluded or excluded rural families from receiving drought assistance.

para.tab: Drought assistance is what it says: drought assistance. Certainly, we are all concerned about the impact of low commodity prices and their fluctuations on rural families. But that is not what the drought assistance package is for. It is not for mouse plagues—and we can regret that—but, primarily, it is based on rain criteria. If you want to argue that there should be a change on the basis of low commodity prices, then do it—but do not do it on the basis of drought. Low commodity prices certainly affect rural incomes, but drought policy is drought policy; that is, lack of rainfall. That is the policy we have applied consistently throughout Australia.

The only other comment I would make is to Senator O'Chee. Primarily, the comments I have made are on this amendment. There are other comments that will be made opposing your amendment that has been moved. As for your remarks about running shoes and some of your other silly comments, they belong to grade 6 debating, which we have all left far behind us, Senator O'Chee.

talker.name: Senator BOSWELL
talker.role: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

talk.start.para:
—I would just put on the record a comment of disagreement with Senator Bell. Senator Bell made the accusation that the coalition has walked away from this amendment on four or five occasions. I have challenged Senator Bell to show us in the
Hansard
where we have done that—that is, where a division has been called and he voted one way and we voted the other way.

para.tab: The truth of the matter is that our No. 1 amendment—the fall-back amendment, as you have called it—has gone down and been rejected by the lower house. The amendment has then come back to the Senate and the Senate has not opposed it but let it go through. However, at no stage have you ever picked that amendment up and divided on it.

I suspect the reason for that is this: these bills that we have both attempted to tag amendments on have benefits to a number of other areas. The fact of the matter is that every time a bill able to carry an Austudy amendment is picked up by either the Democrats or the coalition, our amendments are tagged onto it. That particular bill to which the amendments are tagged on has benefits to other people. As I say, I suspect that this is what has happened. If we reject the bill and do not accept the government's final position, then we exclude a number of people from benefits that they otherwise would have obtained.

But do not come in here and say that we have walked away from the amendment. You can only state that if you have pushed us to the amendment, you have called a division and we have voted against it—and that has not been the case at all.

talker.name: Senator HILL
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition)

talk.start.para: —I do not want to unduly delay this debate, but the Australian Democrats continuously amaze me. They do not seem to appreciate that in this debate both of us—the Democrats and the coalition—are trying to offer relief to farmers and their children and it is the government who is opposing us. It is opposing our proposal, and it is opposing the Democrats' proposal.

para.tab: Yet when you listen to the Australian Democrats, all they want to do is attack us, the coalition. The enemy in this instance is the Labor Party. It is very difficult for the Democrats to appreciate that. Both of us—both the Democrats and the coalition—are bringing forward today proposals to offer relief to farmers, and both our proposals will be opposed by the Labor Party. We have, as has been said, put this amendment time after time, and on no occasion has it been accepted by the Labor Party.

talk.start.para: —We are consistent.

—The Labor Party is consistent: it is not going to give relief to farmers and their children on this Austudy issue. It would be much better, I would suggest, if the Australian Democrats came in here and, for a change, gave the Labor Party a serve. Senator Lees almost got to that stage today.
—She did. She gave us a serve.

—She might have given you a gentle touch-up but that, I have to concede, for the Australian Democrats was a major move in the right direction. Senator Woodley will not do it. Why won't he get up and condemn the Labor Party? Why won't he say that, although it might be the preference of the Democrats to have their amendment over our amendment, if the Labor Party does not pick up either of our two amendments, the Democrats will put out press releases attacking the Labor Party? para.tab: In this debate we are interested in the interests of these rural families who are suffering as a result of government legislation. That should be all that we are interested in. It is what we all should be concerned about.

We come to the Senate today with a solution. Perhaps it is not perfect; we accept that it is not perfect. But it will offer relief to some farming families who at the moment deserve but are not getting that relief. So why don't we stand together and condemn the Labor Party? They do not deserve support in this issue, nor do they deserve to have the option they have at the moment—that of seeking publicly to play us off against each other. I know it is difficult for the Democrats to criticise the ALP, but perhaps on this occasion they just might do so a little.
