speech.speaker: Panizza Sen J.H.

talk.start.para: —Last Tuesday, 19 September 1995, Senator Chris Evans had something to say about the workplace agreements by the government of Western Australia. He reckons that he was looking into those agreements, which is basically the state government making enterprise agreements with its workers. He said:

speech.para: . . . I came across some quite concerning information with implications for this parliament and for the federal government.
They are his words. He said:

para.tab: It seems that as part of that approach the Western Australian government has come up with a concept called `flexible remuneration packaging'. At first sight that would not seem to be a particularly big deal. Many employers offer salary packaging; there is nothing intrinsically wrong with that provided appropriate taxation is paid.

speech.para: He went on to say:

para.tab: Those employees are allowed to sacrifice up to 30 per cent of their salary package. They can take their salary in other than cash benefits up to a maximum of 30 per cent.

speech.para: Then he went on to say:

para.tab: So how is it that this inducement can be offered and a supposed advantage flow to employees without any cost to that state government, the employer of these people? Simply put, it is because of tax evasion. The state government is encouraging the avoidance of payment of tax by its employees. It has erected a tax avoidance scam. The scheme induces employees out of their award system into the workplace agreement on the basis of helping them to avoid paying the appropriate tax on their incomes.

speech.para: He said that senators would be interested and I interjected by asking him how it would be done, but he did not say anything. He said that it is quite blatant tax avoidance. He said:

para.tab: The state government are encouraging the avoidance of the payment of tax by their employees.

speech.para: He finished by saying:

para.tab: It really is a very scandalous situation that we have a state government encouraging tax evasion. I know the federal coalition opposes the fringe benefits tax . . .

speech.para: He uses all those sidelines which are not correct. I told him that at the time. Incidentally, I advised Senator Chris Evans that I would be bringing up this matter tonight in case he wanted to come down for some reason or other.

para.tab: I decided to go into the matter and find out why Senator Chris Evans believed the WA government was creating a tax evasion scheme. I have found out that the WA government, like all responsible state governments, will use any legal means possible to make taxpayers' dollars go as far as possible by minimising expenditure. The agreements Senator Evans referred to were prepared in line with current legislation of the Keating government. They were also checked by the Australian Taxation Office for full compliance before being brought into use and were found to conform totally to current tax law. Apparently other states have gone further in their interpretation of taxation laws, so WA is not alone in using this scheme of workplace agreements and making greater use of current tax provisions to maximum advantage.

But I would like Senator Evans—wherever he is—to listen to this: he should remember that that salary packaging was in fact pioneered by the Labor government's masters in the trade union movement. That is something he was unaware of. I though he might have known that, because he worked in the Fire Brigade Union. If he was aware of it, then I would like him to come down and apologise for misleading the Senate last Tuesday evening.

I ask Senator Chris Evans: what was all the fuss about in your adjournment speech last week? It was union pioneered salary packaging carried out within the framework of laws which the majority of his colleagues and the Australian Taxation Office have supported. Senator Chris Evans, it is all legal; it is all aboveboard; it is saving taxpayers money. Senator Chris Evans should have been praising these commendable measures rather than accusing the WA coalition government, led by Mr Court, of being tax evaders. I would certainly like him to come down and apologise to the state government of Western Australia for his remarks and to the Senate for misleading it.

speech.speaker: Bell Sen R.J.

talk.start.para: —On 6 September this year, Senator Coulter wrote on behalf of Senator Spindler and I to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) in the following terms:

speech.para: Dear Gareth,
We have just returned from Tahiti where the local resistance to the resumption of nuclear testing by the French is very strong and growing.

An alliance of over 60 politicians representing more than 20 countries joined with the local population to express our unanimous opposition to these tests. The Australian delegation with 35 members from each of the parties and each of the states was particularly warmly received as was the large Japanese delegation which also included the Minister for Finance.

We now learn that the materials used in the final stages of preparing the nuclear explosives are flown to Mururoa at the last minute and that this requires an overflight of US air space. We understand that on three occasions in the past the Americans have refused permission for these overflights forcing the French to send these materials by sea. This has significantly slowed the tests down. If invoked again it would allow time for the objections to grow even stronger.

We ask you to urgently press the US to
trigger this device
once again.
Yours sincerely,
John Coulter
Sid Spindler
Robert Bell
On 7 December, Senator Coulter received the following response:
Dear Senator Coulter

Thank you for your letter of 6 September, with which Senators Spindler and Bell were also associated, concerning the reported use of United States air space by French supply flights associated with France's nuclear testing program in the South Pacific.
My information is that France now normally uses an all-French route (through the Caribbean) to transport nuclear material to Mururoa.

I understand that the three occasions referred to in your letter on which the United States allegedly refused overflight permission date back to the period of French atmospheric testing in the South Pacific. On these occasions, the French authorities apparently dismantled the aircraft which were to have been involved in the tests and transported them by sea.

If France were for any reason to seek permission to overfly the US for purposes associated with its weapons testing program, and the US refused that permission, France could simply fall back on the all-French air route available to it: it would not need to revert to sending any material by sea, and no significant delay would be caused to its testing program.
Yours sincerely
GARETH EVANS

I am not convinced that the minister's answer is properly informed. The
New Scientist
magazine, which I quoted in question time today, took particular trouble to find information on this matter, including the fact that between 15 and 18 French military aircraft have been allowed to fly through American airspace on their way to the South Pacific since May. Also, it noted that three of those aircraft were carrying military equipment, although the French did not declare it as hazardous.

para.tab: The minister's answer—both in the letter that he addressed to Senator Coulter and in the answer that he gave today—did not reveal his sources and did not reveal a rigorous questioning of the glib assurances that he has received. This matter deserves an aggressive and thorough questioning and pursuit. It is quite apparent to all who are interested in this topic that a vast majority of Australians demand strong Australian efforts and persistence with regard to this issue.

I need to know from the minister—as does the vast majority of Australians—whether the minister has asked whether there have been any flights through Guadeloupe, for example—the stopover point mentioned by the minister in his answer as being a likely all-French route. The majority of Australians need to know whether the minister has read the article in
Le Monde
newspaper, to which I referred in my question, which asserts that the plutonium for the Mururoa bombs is flown over the US, although not in a single load. This article, which does not quote any sources, says that the two-bomb subassemblies needed for each test are carried on separate top-secret flights and are put together at the last moment on the atoll. That sort of information which is referred to in that article should be researched by an active and interested Australian foreign affairs minister, who should be attempting to verify the sources that are quoted by such a respected publication as
Le Monde
.

We really need to know whether the minister has suggested to the United States that, if they wanted to reflect and support worldwide opinion on this matter, they should consider the action as has been suggested to Senator Evans by Senator Coulter. Unless we see evidence that these sorts of actions have taken place, we would have to conclude that the minister is easily convinced by the glib assurances that he gave us that all is well, that no action can take place and that the conducting of the French tests is inevitable. Unless we see evidence that he has taken strong, aggressive action on this matter, we can only describe his actions as being less than that.

Some people have been unkind in the language they have used in that regard. I will not do that. But what I will say is that we do not see evidence of strength and persistence. When we see publications such as that contained in the
New Scientist
of 16 September this year, in which we can conclude that there has been an unhealthy cooperation between members of the nuclear club who have looked after each other, as evidenced by this apparent United States cooperation here, but we do not have our minister aggressively following them through to determine whether they are accurate or not, then the conclusion speaks for itself.

talk.start.para: —I call Senator Watson.

—Firstly, on a personal note, I congratulate you, Madam Deputy President, on the important office that you now hold and the way you are discharging your responsibilities with great dignity and professionalism. Tonight I also wish to draw the Senate's attention to a diverse range of problems associated with what is colloquially referred to as the superannuation 10 per cent rule. Honourable senators would be aware that there is a scale of age based tax deductible contributions which are available for self-employed persons where outside salary income is earned by a self-employed taxpayer.

para.tab: In the 15th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, the AMA drew the committee's attention to the provisions of subsection 82AAS(2) and (3) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. These provisions can have serious implications on the personal superannuation of, say, a visiting medical officer who works in a public hospital. Where the income from the hospital exceeds 10 per cent of their gross income, the tax deduction from superannuation contributions, which are available to them as self-employed persons, is denied.

The AMA submission stated that this income tax 10 per cent limitation rule can put VMOs at a significant disadvantage compared with other practitioners who gain tax concessions for superannuation contributions and can act as a disincentive for practitioners to enter into or remain in public hospitals. In addition, building design professions have expressed similar reservations to those expressed by the AMA. The building design professions recommended that the government establish an equitable system where everybody is entitled to the same deductibility of contributions up to a certain limit regardless of their source of income.

Since that time I have been advised that other professional people working for government boards and agencies are similarly affected. In fact, one was forced to resign as chair of a government board where he brought particular expertise, coupled with a very deep social and community consciousness. In that case the loss of tax deductions incurred a tax liability by an amount exceeding 170 per cent of his remuneration. This denial of the deduction of personal superannuation from a person earning more than 10 per cent of his or her income from salary of employment is of concern to the general community.

I also remind the Senate that after a long fight the superannuation guarantee charge was removed from local government councillors' allowances to be a sensible protection from the tax office for self-employed people who act in a largely honorary capacity. I acknowledge the work of my colleague Senator Macdonald in bringing about this amendment. However, superannuation support is required in circumstances where those councillors are effectively full-time employees. That issue has never been in doubt.

It seems extraordinary that, despite the committee's report and assurances from the Australian Taxation Office that enforcements were under way, there is nowadays a massive dispute between at least two government departments—on the one hand, the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Veterans' Affairs and, on the other hand, a state instrumentality in New South Wales, the New South Wales Department of Health. This defence related department and the New South Wales Department of Health look after the hospital needs of their clients. Both departments of state refused to make superannuation contributions—that is, Veterans' Affairs and the New South Wales Department of Health. Both departments have a similar argument. They argue that these visiting medical officers are independent contractors.

It is all very well for them to take that view, but I take exception to the fact that in the private sector, because the definition in the act is particularly wide, independent contractors as such do come under the ambit of the superannuation guarantee charge. In fact, prosecutions have been instigated for non-compliance in the private sector, but here nothing is done. We expect government agencies to know the law laid down by another arm of government.

Despite the fact that both departments refuse to make superannuation contributions, the ATO is arbitrarily—this is the nub—amending assessments and denying deductions in VMOs' personal returns, despite no contributions from the government hospitals. So they are getting it twice. Reliable sources suggest to me that from one tax office alone there are over 1,000 medical practitioners who have no access to any form of superannuation tax support and the Taxation Office is arbitrarily amending their assessments because they believe the health department or the Department of Defence should have made these sorts of deductions, and had they made those deductions, they would not have made the 10 per cent rule.

The issue is very serious and must be resolved very quickly because the lack of enforcement by one government agency of another in respect of a legal liability is particularly serious. If ordinary citizens are expected to know and obey the law, so should Commonwealth and state departments. That is one issue. The second issue is that the 10 per cent rule is clearly very unsatisfactory and itself in need of review.

The matter is not only a superannuation guarantee charge and income tax problem; it is an issue which is resulting from community-minded citizens being forced, as I said in the case of this legal practitioner, to resign from positions of use to the government and the community where their services and their expertise are often required. People in their mid-50s often scale down their work-related expenses and give part of their time to community involvement, not necessarily working for full remuneration for government agencies, government boards and so on, and the agencies are expected to take out superannuation. But under the 10 per cent rule we are not going to get these community-minded experts who could offer their expertise to the community and to governments—federal, state and even local—when this 10 per cent rule can put them at such a tax disadvantage that they are forced to resign, as in the example that I gave, at a time when they are able to build up superannuation for retirement but may have a declining income which makes them doubly vulnerable.

The Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), being a doctor of many years standing, would be aware of the problem. I ask that on behalf of your colleagues you look at this problem because it is not only a problem related to the medical profession but it is a problem that goes across a lot of professions where these good people are being forced to give up responsibilities to government agencies because of what is known as the hideous taxation effect of the 10 per cent rule.

speech.speaker: Ellison Sen C.M.

talk.start.para:
—Today in the Senate I asked a question of Senator Gareth Evans as the Leader of the Government in the Senate as to why the government had not tackled the harder issue of sorting out the uncertainty that exists in relation to land tenure pursuant to the Native Title Act. The government has recently published its proposed amendments which relate to the application and processing of native title claims. I do not criticise the government for that, but I do criticise the government for not going far enough. Today in Australia there is a great deal of uncertainty surrounding this legislation and the government has failed to address that. This was the subject of an article in last week's
Australian Financial Review
, dated 18 September 1995, headed `Mabo process in tatters'. The article was written by Michael Dwyer and states:

para.tab: The euphoria surrounding the passage of the Mabo legislation has given way to frustration and uncertainty, with the mechanism set up to implement Mr Keating's grand vision lurching towards total gridlock.

speech.para: Further on in the same article Mr Dwyer stated:

para.tab: The key issue for the mining industry was the reluctance by the Commonwealth to resolve the question of whether pastoral leases extinguished native title.

speech.para: Similarly, in that same article he stated:

para.tab: And State governments continue to lobby the Commonwealth to legislate to clear up the vexing problem of whether pastoral leases extinguish native title.

speech.para: In that regard he referred to the Wik case and the Mirriuwung Gajerrong claim which is pending in Western Australia. It is true, as Senator Evans said today in his answer to me, that there are pending cases in relation to the certainty of land tenure. Those two cases are cases which are touching upon the question of whether pastoral leases extinguish native title. In Western Australia we have the question of whether reservations on pastoral leases equally extinguish native title.

para.tab: It is shirking the responsibility that the government has to clear this up to say simply, `It is in the courts; let the courts decide.' That point was made in the very lengthy debate that we had on the native title legislation in this very chamber. When these queries were put to the government, the government said, `Let the courts decide.' It is now nearly two years later and the courts have not decided, and it does not look as though they are going to decide for another year.

talk.start.para: —Did he say that during the debate two years ago?

—He said that during the debate two years ago. During questions without notice the government also indicated that it was confident that pastoral leases extinguished native title. That is not the case because history has shown that the stand that the coalition took was correct and the uncertainty that the coalition said would come about as a result of this complex legislation was, indeed, correct.

para.tab:
I take no satisfaction from saying that the coalition was right and that we had it right all along. We now have a situation where the High Court has said there is native title, that the Native Title Act, apart from section 12, is valid and we have to get on with the job of making it work. But, of course, this government is not doing that. It is only approaching the edges. It is tinkering with it, if you like, looking at the process, looking at the application, but not dealing with the essential matters such as certainty of land title. Indeed, Rick Farley—he is a member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and also a former lobbyist for the National Farmers Federation—stated in the
Financial Review
of the same date:

speech.para: Parliament and the courts so far have failed to define native title precisely. No one yet knows exactly where the native title exists, or even who the claimants might be.

Those are the real issues. That is what people want to know. This government is failing to address that. I note that it is convenient for the government simply to look at the question of application and process and leave the more difficult questions until after the next election. Why won't the government tell the people of Australia, the Aboriginal community, the mining and pastoral industries, exactly what it intends to do about this uncertainty? It simply cannot say, `This is pending, the courts will decide and you will have to wait and see,' because in a year's time I will be making this same address to the Senate. In a year's time, we will still see mining interests, farmers and pastoralists scratching their heads and asking what it all means. In fact, in that article in the
Financial Review
by Mr Dwyer, he states:
Uncertainty over native title has seen mineral exploration activity drop by up to 20 per cent with many mining companies looking off-shore for "greenfield" development.

With the current balance of payments in the drastic state that it is in, we can hardly afford to have mining companies going offshore. We can hardly afford to lose that investment and development which could make Australia one of the wealthiest countries in the world. Indeed, the government made much of the results last week which said that assets-wise Australia is the richest country in the world. Of course, it is not going to be if we cannot develop our natural assets.

para.tab: I do not say that we should do that in an irresponsible fashion. Of course, you should have regard to sustained development and approach it on the basis of what is good for the country at large. Of course, you look to the Aboriginal groups in these areas and accommodate their interests as well. But, above all, you approach it in a balanced, rational manner and, most of all, in a way that will make the system work, so that the Aboriginal community, the mining community and the pastoralists all have their interests accommodated.

So far, this government has been good on the rhetoric, good on the sorts of principles and what sounds high and mighty, but it has been very thin indeed on the detail and on how this is all going to work. It is nearly two years later and we still find that the government cannot answer the questions that the coalition put to it during that debate—the longest debate, I believe, in this country's history. What we were trying to do then was to flush out this detail, to say to the government, `How is this going to work?'. But still today, the government cannot answer these questions, nor is it attempting to answer these questions.

Although looking at the amending of the application process and the processing of claims is perhaps a step in the right direction, and I note that His Honour Mr Justice French has made some worthwhile suggestions in this regard, we are still only scratching the surface. We have to get into the detail of this legislation and make it work, because if we do not, we will cause division in the community. If we do not, we will frustrate the Aboriginal community. If we do not, we will see that mining developers will go offshore and we will lose that much valued development. As well as that, we will frustrate our pastoralists and, furthermore, create division in our rural sector. That adds up to disaster for this country. I believe that if it is not addressed by this government, if it does not take up the responsibility of addressing this matter, we will see more division in the community, less development and the rights of Australians across the board ignored.

I say to the government: you might boast that you have made some step towards amending the application process for native title, but you have only scratched the surface and you have got a long way to go yet.

talk.start.para: —I call Senator Teague.

—Madam Deputy President, I congratulate you on being chosen to act as President of the Senate. I think the opening of today's Senate proceedings was the first time that senators observed you—and we happily observed you—as the first woman senator to take the place of a President of the Senate and read the Lord's Prayer.

para.tab: I rise to talk about the Royal Australian Navy's Hydrographic Service. It was my pleasure to be the guest of the Hydrographic Service last Friday, 22 September, in the visit I made to Wollongong. With the approval off the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) I was able to get a comprehensive view of the work of this important facility within the defence sector. It is of vital importance for the navy but it is equally essential for our civil maritime community. None of the shipping in Australia could operate without accurate charts. I do not need to remind the Senate that over 80 per cent of Australia's trade products are taken by ship and these ships require accurate charts.

The Hydrographic Office is a multi-storey building that has been newly established at Wollongong—it was in Sydney—and was opened 10 months ago by the Minister for Defence as a new building. Being a senator interested in defence, I went to see this facility.
I was welcomed by the officer in charge of the office, Captain Geoff Geraghty. During the next few hours he introduced me to virtually all the staff in the building on many levels, all of whom analyse the data that is put together by the survey staff of the Hydrographic Service, which is then interpreted, with a great amount of checking, to ensure there are verified modern charts for use in Australian waters.

The assets of the service include two survey ships, the
Moresby
and the
Flinders
, one of which is at least 30 years old and is about to be replaced by an even more efficient survey vessel. On the
Moresby
there are three motor boats for survey use and a helicopter. In addition to these two main ships there are four survey motor launches which are catamarans, and six motor boats, including a seventh which is especially set up for Antarctic survey.

There are 120 uniformed members of the Hydrographic Service in the Navy and 100 civilian staff. There is a budget of $50 million which is applied through the office. These survey assets bring up-to-date charts for the use of our defence and civilian communities. There is also a fixed wing aircraft which is a laser airborne depth sounder unit, which has a facility on a truck which is full of computers to take data from the aircraft. It was my pleasure to see how the data that is collected by these survey assets and dispersed around Australia is received, checked and then interpreted into charts for the use of the Australian people.

The area that is the responsibility of the Hydrographic Office is no less than one-eighth of the Earth's surface. It includes all Australian waters, Papua New Guinea, Antarctica, halfway into the Indian Ocean and halfway to New Zealand—a vast area. Of course, as anyone who has seen a recent chart of Australian waters knows, it is an indication that a fair amount of surveying has been done since Captain Cook, Captain Flinders and the other earliest explorers. There have been certain additions in the last 12 months.

I am wearing the tie given to me by the hydrographics service in memory of my visit on Friday, and I wear it proudly as an Australian senator. I was referring to the charting of Australian waters. Even a superficial survey would indicate that there are some gaps but, in all the vital places, there are increasingly accurate charts.

The earlier charts, which were in fathoms and even achieved by lead lines, are being replaced by metric measured charts and, more than that, by an electronic chart display and information system. As is evident from the words, that system uses the GPS system—the global positioning system, which can be accurate to within 10 metres of an absolutely truly defined place on the earth—to build in information not only about the coastline, depth and tides but also about various hazards and navigational aids, such as lighthouses and buoys. I have a recent survey of Arnhem Land which is in the new format. It happens to be of the Gugari Rip—or what is colloquially called `the hole in the wall'—which is some of the islands to the north of Arnhem Land.

One project that was brought to my attention was the discovery of a reef 14 metres below the surface and a matter of 20 miles off Port Lincoln and right in the middle of the main shipping lane. This reef had never been discovered until 1992 but was picked up by sonar systematic soundings. It is a conical shaped reef—like a great pimple coming out of the bottom of the seabed—and would be quite dangerous if a major ship were travelling immediately above it. Also discovered recently was a bank in the Torres Strait just off the main shipping lane that goes around the Gulf of Carpentaria.

Commodore John Leech is currently the hydrographicer of the RAN and is responsible for the whole of navy's responsibilities. He gave his apologies for not being present when I visited the Hydrographic Office. Captain Geraghty, along with all the other staff, made sure that I was welcome, but their commanding officer was attending one of his international committees.

Let me briefly list the seven committees on which he an Australian representative, because it gives an indication of the range of public service activity which is of benefit to the nation. He is a member of the Intergovernmental Committee on Surveying and Mapping, the Permanent Committee on Tides and Mean Sea Level, the Steering Committee of the National Tidal Facility, the Association of Australian Ports and Marine Authorities, the Maritime Services Advisory Committee (Navigational Safety), the Heads of Commonwealth Marine Science Agencies and the Commonwealth Spatial Data Committee. Time does not allow me to elaborate on that information, but it is clear that Defence is using its assets not only to its own benefit but also to the benefit of the civil community.

I conclude by thanking those who received me at Wollongong in this marvellous new facility. I thank my second son, university student Matthew Teague, for accompanying me on this journey. He happens to be a keen sailor and, like me, is a user of the charts produced by this facility. I also thank the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) for his blessing of my visit and all of the staff representing the hydrographic service who welcomed me on Friday.

answer.to.qon.title: Indian Ocean Centre for Peace Studies

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 29 August 1995:

para.tab: With reference to the department's review of the Indian Ocean Centre for Peace Studies at the University of Western Australia established by Mr Kevin Clements in 1994, and the submissions put to the review:
(1)(a) Why have the findings of this review not been made public; and (b) how has the department tried to address any of the issues which came to light as a result of the review.

(2)(a) How much money has the department given to the Indian Ocean Centre for Peace Studies at the University of Western Australia in 1995; (b) where has this money gone; (c) how has it been used; and (d) has any or all of the money allocated to the Indian Ocean Centre for Peace Studies in 1995 been transferred to Curtin University.
(3) Since the Indian Ocean Centre for Peace Studies at the University of Western Australia has changed its leadership, is the department going to continue funding it.

answer.speaker: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

para.tab: (1)(a) The terms of reference for this review required an evaluation of the effectiveness of the Indian Ocean Centre for Peace Studies (IOCPS) in meeting its stated objectives. The report of the review was finalised in June 1994. It was not widely distributed since it was a specific purpose evaluation with no system-wide implications. Copies of the report were provided to the universities that participated in the review.

(b) The recommendations arising from the review were primarily directed at the IOCPS and covered issues such as organisational structure and administration, staffing, accommodation, research, publications, education, community outreach, national and international networks, policy relevance and conferences. The key recommendation directed at the Commonwealth was that Commonwealth funding for the Centre should be extended for a further five years. This recommendation was not supported by the Commonwealth.

While the Commonwealth had agreed to maintain funding for the IOCPS from the National Priority (Reserve) Fund (NP(R)F) until the end of 1995 to enable the Centre to consolidate its position as a self-funding organisation, funding beyond this point from the NP(R)F would have constituted recurrent funding. The NP(R)F program guidelines allow grants to be made for the "developmental, pilot or introductory phase of an activity" and do not allow grants for the "on-going recurrent costs of an activity".

While the Commonwealth agreed to maintain funding of the IOCPS from the NP(R)F until 1995 to enable the Centre to consolidate its position and seek out alternative funding sources, funding beyond this would have constituted recurrent funding and would, therefore, have been in breach of the program guidelines.
(2)(a) The 1995 NP(R)F grant to the Centre was $150,000 which was paid on 8 December 1994.

(b) The grant was paid to the University of Western Australia which administers the grant. The Centre, however, is a cooperative venture between the University of Western Australia and Curtin University of Technology and has operated under a Memorandum of Agreement between the two universities.

(c) The Centre is not required to report to the Department on the 1995 expenditure until 30 June 1996.
